notesStmt.note: The first book printed in British North America, commonly known as the Bay Psalm book. Translated by Richard Mather, John Eliot, and Thomas Weld, among others. The preface is usually attributed to Mather, but this is disputed by Zoltan Haraszti, who attributes it to John Cotton. Cf. Haraszti's The enigma of the Bay Psalm book, 1956, p. 12-27.
Printed at the press in Cambridge supervised by Stephen Day (variously Daye). Day's son Matthew may have been responsible for the actual printing.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE VVHOLE BOOKE OF PSALMES Faithfully TRANSLATED into ENGLISH Metre.
Whereunto is prefixed a discourse declaring not only the lawfullnes, but also the necessity of the heavenly Ordinance of singing Scripture Psalmes in the Churches of God.

q.p: Let the word of God dwell plenteously in you, in all wisdome, teaching and exhorting one another in Psalmes, Himnes, and spirituall Songs, singing to the Lord with grace in your hearts.
〈◊〉 any be afflicted, let him pray, and if any be merry let him sing psalmes.

div.p: Imprinted 1640

div.head: The Preface.
div.p:
THe singing of Psalmes, though it 〈…〉 nothing but holy harmony, and 〈…〉 such is the subtilty of the enemie, 〈…〉 of our nature against the Lord, & his 〈…〉 our hearts can finde matter of discord in 〈…〉 , and crotchets of division in this 〈…〉 . -for- There have been three questiō
〈…〉 stirrīg cōcerning singing. First▪
〈…〉 are to be sung in churches? whether 〈…〉 scripture psalmes, or the psalmes 〈…〉 the gifts of godly men in every age of the 〈◊〉 Secondly, if scripture psalmes, whet •••
〈…〉 owne words, or in such meter as english 〈…〉 wont to run in? Thirdly· by whom are they • o be sung? whether by the whole churches togeth • r with their voices? or by one man singing alōe a • d the rest joynīg in silēce, & in the close sayīg amen.

Touching the first, certainly the singing of Davids psalmes was an acceptable worship of God, not only in his ow • e, but in succeeding ti • e •
▪ as in Solomons time 2 Chron. 5.13. in 〈◊〉 time 2 chron. 20.31. in Ez ••
〈◊〉 time Ez • a 3.10, 11. and the text is evi •• nt in Hezekiahs time they are commanded to sing praise in the words of David and Asaph, 2 chron. 29, 30. which one place may serve to resolve two of the questions (the first and the last) at once▪ for this commandement was it cerimoniall
or morall? some things in it i • deed were cerimoniall, as their musicall instruments &c but what cerimony was there in singing prayse with the wo • ds of David and Asaph? what if David was a typeof Christ, was Asaph also? was every thing of David typicall? are his words (which are of morall, universall, and perpetuall authority in all nations and ages) are they typicall? what type can be imagined in making use of his songs to prayse the Lord? If they were typicall b • cause the cerimony of musicall instruments was joyned with them, then their prayers were alsotypicall, because they had that ceremony of incense admixt with them: but wee know that prayer then was a morall duty, notwithstanding the incense; and soe singing those psalmes notwithstanding their musicall instruments. Beside, that which was typicall (as that they were sung wi • h musicall instruments, by the twenty-foure orders of Priests and Levites. 1 chron 25.9.) must have the morall and spirituall accom • lishment in the new Testament, in all the Churches of the Saints principally, who are made kings & priests Reu. 1.6. and are the first fruits unto God. Reu. 1 • 4. as the Levites were Num. 3.45. with hearts & lippes, in stead of musicall instruments, to prayse the Lord; who are set forth (as some iudiciously thinke) Reu. 4.4. by twēty foure Elders, in the ripe age of the Church, Gal. 4.1, 2, 3. answering to the twenty foure order • of Priests and Levites 1 chron. 25.9. Therefore not some select
members, but the whole Church is 〈◊〉 to teach one another in all the special singing of Davids psalmes, some being called by the • th •
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : psalms, some 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 Hymns some 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : spirituall songs. • oe that if the singing Davids psalmes be a morall duty & therfore perpetuall; then wee under the new Testamēt are bound to sing them as well as they under the old: and if wee are expresly commanded to sing Psalmes, Hymnes, and spirituall songs, then either wee must sing Davids psalmes, or else may affirm they are not spirituall songs: which being penned by an extraordīa • y gift of the Spirit, for the sak • especially of Gods spirtuall Israell; not to be read and preached only (as other parts of holy writ) but to be sung also, they are therefore most spirituall, and still to be sung of all the Israell of God: and verily as their sin is exceeding great, who will allow Davids psalmes (as other scriptures) to be read in churches (which is one end) but not to be preached also, (which is another end foe their sin is crying before God, who will allow them to be read and preached, but seeke • o deprive the Lord of the glory of the third 〈◊〉 of them, which is to sing them in christian 〈…〉 obj. 1 If it be sayd • hat the Saints in the 〈◊〉 Church did compile spirituall songs 〈…〉 owne inditing, and sing them before the 〈◊〉 1 Cor. 14, 15, 16.

Ans. We answer first, that those Saints co • piled these spirituall songs by the extraordinary gifts of
the spirit (common in those dayes) whereby they were inabled to praise the Lord in strange tongues, wherin learned Para • s proves those psalme • were uttered, in his Commēt on that place
• ers 14 which extraordinary gifts, if they were still in the Churches, wee should allow them the like liberty now. Secondly, suppose those psalmes were sung by an ordinary gift (which wee suppose cannot be • victed) doth it therefore follow that they did no • , & that we ought not to sing Davids psalmes? must the ordinary gifts of a private man quench the spirit still speaking to us by the extraordin
• ry gifts of his servant David? there is not the l •• st foot-step of example, or precept, or colour ••• son for such a bold practise.
obj. 2. Ministers are allowed to pray conceived • rayers, and why not to sing conceived psalmes? must wee not sing in the spirit as well as pray in the spirit?

Ans. First because every good minister hath not a gift of spirituall poetry to compose extemporary psalmes as he hath of prayer. Secondly. Suppose he had, yet seeing psalmes are to be sung by a • oynt consent and harmony of all the Church in heart and voyce (as w • e shall prove) this cannot be done except he that composeth a psalme, bring
• th into the Church set formes of psalmes of his o • ne invētion; for which wee finde no warrant or president in any ordinary officers of the Church • h • oughout the sciptures. Thirdly. Because the book • of psalmes is so compleat a System of
psalmes, which the Holy-Ghost himselfe in 〈◊〉 wisdo • e hath made to suit all the conditions, necessityes, temptations, affections, &c. of men in all ages; (as most of all our interpreters on the psalmes have fully and p • rticularly cleare where fore by this the Lord seemeth to stoppeth mens mouths and mindes ordinarily to compile or sing any other psa • mes (under colour that the ocasions and conditions of the Church are new) &c. for the publick use of the Church, seing, let our condition be what it will, the Lord himselfe hath supplyed us with farre better; and therefore in Hezekiahs time, though doubtlesse there were among them those which had extraoridnary gifts to compile new songs on those new ocasions, as Isaiah and Micah &c. yet wee read that they are commanded to sing in the words of David and Asaph, which were ordinarily to be used in the publick worship of God: and wee doubt not but those that are wise will easily see; that those set formes of psalmes of Gods owne appoyntment not of mans conceived gift or humane imposition were sung in the Spirit by those holy Levites, as well as their prayers were in the spirit which themselves conceived, the Lord not then binding them therin to any set formes; and shall set formes of psalmes appoynted of God not be sung in the spirit no • , which others did then?

Queston. But why may not one cōpose a psalme & sing it alone with a loud voice & the r • st joyne
with him in silence and in the end say Amen?

Ans. If such a practise was found in the Church of Cori • th, when any had a psalme suggested by an extraordinary gift; yet in singing ordinary psalmes the whole Church is to ioyne together in heart and voyce to prayse the Lord. -for- First. Davids psalmes as hath beene shewed, were sung in heart and voyce together by the twenty foure orders of the musicians of the Temple, who typed out the twenty foure Elders all the members especially of christian Churches R ••
5. • . who are made Kings and Priests to God to prayse him as they did: for if there were any other o • der of singing Choristers beside the body of the people to succeed those, the Lord would doubtlesse have given direction in the gospell for their quallification, election, maintainance &c. as he did for the musicians of the Temple, and as his faithfullnes hath done for all other church officers in the new Testament. Secondly. Others beside the Levites (the chiefe Singers) in the • ewish Church did also sing the Lords songs; else why are they commanded frequently to sing: as in ps. 100, 1, 2, 3. ps 95, 1, 2, 3. ps. 102. title. with vers 18. & Ex. 15.1. not only Moses but all Israell sang that song, they spake saying (as it is in the orig.) all as well as Moses, the women also as well as the men. v. 20 21. and deut. 32. (whereto some thi • ke, Iohn had reference as well as to Ex. 15.1. when he brings in the protestant Churches getting the victory over the
Beast with harps in their hands and singing the song of Moses. Reu, 15.3.) this song Moses is commanded not only to put it into their hearts butinto their mouths also: deut. 31.19. which argues, they were with their mouths to sing i. together as well as with their hearts.

Thirdly. Is • iah foretells in the dayes of the new-Testament that Gods watchmen and desolate lost soules, (signified by wast places) should with their voices sing together, Isa. 52.8, 9. and Reu- 7.9, 10. the song of the Lamb was by many together, and the Apostle expresly commands the singing of Psalmes, Himnes, &c. not to any select christians, but to the whole Church Eph. 5.19 coll. 3.16. Paule & Silas sang together in private Acts. 16.25. and must the publick heare ōly one man sing? to all these wee may adde the practise of the primitive Churches; the testimony of anci • nt and holy Basil is in stead of many Epist. 63 When one of us (saith he) hath begun a psalme, the rest of us set in to sing with him, all of us with one heart and one voyce; and this saith he is the common practise of the Churches in Egypt, Lybi • , Thebes, Palestina, Syria and those that dwell on Euphrates, and generally every where, where singing of psalmes is of any account. To the s • me purpose also Eusebius gives witnes, E • cl • s. H • st. lib. 2. cap. 17. The objections made against this doe most of them plead against joyning to sing i • heart as well as in voyce, as that by this meanes oth • rs out of the C • urch will sing
as also that wee are not alway in a sutable est • te to the matter sung, & likewise that all cannot s • ng with understanding; shall not therefore all that have understanding ioyne in heart and voyce together? are not all the creatures in heaven, earth, seas: men, beasts, fishes, foules &c. commanded to praise the Lord, and yet none of these but men, and godly men too, can doe it with spirituall understanding?

As for the scruple that some take at the translatiō of the book of psalmes into mee • er, because Davids psalmes were sung in his owne words without meeter: wee answer- First· There are many verses together in several psalmes of David which run in rithmes (as those that know the hebrew and as Buxtorf shews Thesau. pa. 62 • .) which shews at least the lawfullnes of singing psalmes in english rithmes.

Secondly. The psalmes are pen • ed in such verses as are sutable to the poetry of the hebr • w Language, and not in the common style of such other bookes of the old Testament as are not poeticall; now no protestant doubteth but that all the bookes of the scripture should by Gods ordinance be extant in the mother tongue of each nation, that they may be understood of all, hence the psalmes are to be translated into our english tongue; and if in our english tongue wee are to sing them, then as all our english songs (according to the course of our english poetry) do run in metre, soe ought Davids p • almes to be translated
into meeter, that soe wee may sing the Lords songs, as in our eng • ish tongue soe in such verses as are familar to an english eare which are commonly metricall: and as it can be no just offence to any good conscience to sing Davids hebrew songs in english words, soe neither to sing his poeticall verses in english poeticall metre: men might as well stumble at singing the hebrew psalmes in our english tunes (and not in the hebrew tunes) as at singing them in english meeter, (which are our verses) and not in such verses as are generally used by Davi • accordi • g to the poetry of the hebrew language: but the truth is, as the Lord hath hid from us the hebrew tunes, lest wee should think our selves bound to imitate them; soe also the course and frame (for the most part) of their hebrew poetry, that wee might not think our s • lves bound to imitate that, but that every n • tion without scruple mi • ht follow as the graver s • rt of tunes of their owne country songs, soe the graver sort of verses of their owne country poetry.

Neither let any think, that for the meetre sake wee ha • e taken liberty or poeticall licence to depart from the true and proper sence of Davids words in the h • brew verses, noe; but it hath beene one part of our religious care and faithfull in •• avour, to keepe close to the originall text.

As for oth • r obiections tak • n from the difficulty of Amsworths tunes, and the corruptions in
our common psalme books, wee hope they are answered in this new edition of psalmes which wee here present to God and his Churches. For although wee have cause to blesse God in many respects for the religious indeavours of the translaters of the psalmes into meetre usually annexed to our Bibles, yet it is not unknowne to the godly learned that they have rather presented a paraphrase then • he words of David translated according to the rule 2 chron. 29.30. and that their addition to the words, detr • ctions from the words are not seldome and rare, but very frequent and many times needles, (which we suppose would not be approved of if the psalmes were so translated into prose) and that their variations of the sense, and alterations of the sacred text too frequently, may iustly minister matter of offence to them that are able to compare the translation with the text; of which failings, some iudicious have oft complained, others have been grieved, wherupon it hath bin generally desired, that as wee doe inioye other, soe (if it were the Lords will) wee might inioye this ordinance also in its native pu • ity: wee have therefore done our indeavour to make a plaine and familiar translation of the psalmes and words of D • vid into english metre, and have not soe much as presumed to paraphrase to give the sense of his meaning in other words; we have therefore attended heerin as our chief guide the originall, sh ••• ing all additions, except such as even the best
tran • lators of them in prose supply, avoiding all materiall detractions from words or sence. The word 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 which wee translate and as it is redundant sometime in the Hebrew, soe somtime (though not very often) it hath been left out, and yet not then, if the sence were not faire without it.

As for our translations, wee have with our english Bibles (to which next to the Originall wee have had respect) used the Idioms of our owne tongue in stead of Hebraismes, lest they might seeme english barbarismes. Synonimaes wee use indifferently: as folk for people, and Lord for Iehovah, and somtime (though seldome) God for Iehovah; for which (as for some other interpretations of places cited in the new Testament) we have the scriptures authority ps. 14. with 53. Heb. 1. • . with psalme 97. Where a phrase is doubtfull wee have followed that which (in our owne apprehensiō) is most genuine & edifying:

Somtime wee have contracted, somtime dilated the same hebrew word, both for the sence and the verse sake: which dilatation wee conceive to be no paraphrasticall addition no more then the contraction of a true and full translation to be any unfaithfull detraction or diminution: as when wee dilate who healeth and say he it is who healeth; soe when wee contract, those that stand in awe of God and say Gods fearers.

Lastly. Because some hebrew words have a
more full and emphaticall signification then any one english word can or doth somtime expresse, hence wee have done that somtime which faithfull translators may doe, viz. not only to translate the word but the emphasis of it; as 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
mighty God, for God. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 humbly blesse for blesse; rise to stand, psalm 1. for stand truth and faithfullnes for truth. Howbeit, for the verse sake wee doe not alway thus, yet wee render the word truly though not fully; as when wee somtime say reioyce for shout for ioye.

As for all other changes of numbers, tenses, and characters of speech, they are such as • ither the hebrew will, u • forcedly beare, or our english forceably calls for, or they no way change the sence; and such are printed usually in an other character.

If therefore the verses are not alwayes so smooth and elegant as some may desire or expect; let them consider that Go • s Altar needs not our pollishings: Ex. 20. for wee have respected rather a plaine translation, then to smooth ou • verses with the sweetnes of any paraphrase, and soe have attend • d Conscience rather then Elegance, fidelity rather then poetry, in translating the hebrew words into english language, and Davids poetry into english meerre;
that soe wee may sing in Sion the Lords songs of pray • e according to his owne will; untill hee take us from hence, and wip • away all our teares, & bid us enter into our masters ioye to sing eternall Halleluiahs.

div.head: PSALME I
div.l: O Blessed man, that in th'advice
of wicked doeth not walk:
nor stand in sinners way, nor sit
in chayre of scornfull folk.
verse 2 But in the law of Iehovah,
is his longing delight:
and in his law doth m • ditate,
by day and eke by night.
verse 3 And he shall be like to a tree
planted by water-rivers:
that in his season yeilds his fruit,
and his leafe never withers.
verse 4 And all he doth, shall prosper well,
the wicked are not so:
but they are like vnto the chaffe,
which winde drives to and fro.
verse 5 Therefore shall not ungodly men,
rise to stand in the doome,
nor shall the sinners with the just,
in their assemblie come.
verse 6 For of the righteous men, the Lord
acknowledgeth the way:
but the way of vngodly men,
shall vtterly d • cay.

div.head: PSALM II
div.l: WHy rage the Heathen furiously▪
muse vaine things people do;
verse 2 Kings of the earth doe set themselves,
Princes consult also:
with one consent against the Lord,
and his anoynted one.
verse 3 Let us asunder break their bands,
their cords bee from us throwne▪
verse 4 Who sits in heav'n shall laugh; the lord
will mock them; then will he
verse 5 Speak to them in his ire, and wrath:
and vex them suddenlie.
verse 6 But I annoynted have my King
upon my holy hill
verse 7 of Zion: The established
counsell declare I will.
God spake to me, thou art my Son:
this day I thee begot.
verse 8 Aske thou of me, and I will give
the Heathen for thy lot:
and of the earth thou shalt possesse
the utmost coasts abr • ad.
verse 9 thou shalt them break as Potters sherds
and crush with yron rod.
verse 10 And now yee Kings be wise, be learn'd
yee Iudges of th'earth (Heare.)
verse 11 Serve yee the lord with revere • ce,
rej • yce in him with feare.
verse 12 Kisse yee the Sonne, lest he be wroth,
and yee fall in the way.
when his wrath quickly burnes, oh blest?
are all that on him stay.

div.head: Psalme 3 1 A psalme of David when he fled from the face of Absalom his Sonne.
div.l: O Lord, how many are my foes?
how many up against me stand?
verse 2 Many say to my soule noe helpe
in God for him at any hand.
verse 3 But thou • ord art my shield, my g • ory
and the-uplifter of my • ead,
verse 4 with voyce to God I cal'd, who from
his holy hill me answered.
verse 5 I layd me downe, I slept, I wakt,
for I • hovah did me up beare:
verse 6 People that set against me ro •• d,
ten thousand of them I'le not feare.
verse 7 Arise o Lord, s • ve me my God,
for all mine enimies thou hast stroke
upon the cheek-bone: & the teeth
of the ungodly thou hast broke.
verse 8 This, and all such salvation,
thy blessing is, and let it be
upon thine owne people. Selah.

div.head: Psalme 4 To the cheife Mus cian on Neginoth, a psalme of David.
div.l: GOD of my • ustice, when I call
• nswer me: when distr • st
thou hast inl • rg'd • e, s •• w me grace,
and he • re thou my request.
verse 2 Ye Sonnes of men, my glory turne
to shame how long will you?
how long will ye love vanity,
and still deceit pursue?
verse 3 But know, the Lord doth for himselfe
set by his gracious saint:
the Lord will heare when I to him
doe poure out my complaint.
verse 4 Be stirred up, but doe not sinne,
consider seriouslie:
within your heart upon your bed;
and wholly silent be.
verse 5 The sacrifices of justice,
let sacrificed be,
and confidently put your trust
on Iehovah doe ye.
verse 6 Many there be that say o who,
will cause us good to see:
the light, Lord, of thy countenance
let on us lifted be.
verse 7 Thou hast put gladnesse in my heart,
more then the time wherein
their corne, and also their new wine,
have much increased bin.
verse 8 In peace with him I will lye downe,
and take my sleepe will I:
For thou Lord mak'st me dwell alone
in confident safety.

div.head: Psalme 5 1 To the cheife Musi • ian upon Nehiloth, a ps • lme of David.
div.l: Heare thou my words and understand
my meditation, Iehovah.
verse 2 My King, my God, attend the voyce
of my cry: for to thee I pray.
verse 3 At morn Iehovah, thou shalt heare
my voyce: to thee I will addresse
verse 4 at morn, I will looke up. For thou
art not a God lov'st wickednesse
neither shall evil with thee dwell.
verse 5 Vaine glorious fooles before thine eyes
shall never stand: for thou hatest
all them that worke iniquities.
verse 6 Thou wilt bring to distruction
the speakers of lying-falshood,
the lord will make to be abhor'd
the man deceitfull, and of blood.
verse 7 But I will come into thine house
in multitude of thy mercy:
and will in feare of thee bow downe,
in temple of thy sanctity.
verse 8 Lead me forth in thy rightousnes,
because of mine observing spies,
O Iehovah doe thou thy wayes
make straight, and plaine, before mine eyes
verse 9 For there no truth is in his mouth,
their inward part iniquities;
their throat an open sepulchre,
their tongue is bent to flatteries.
verse 10 O God make thou them desolate
from their owne plo • s let them fall far,
cast them out in their heapes of sinnes,
for they against thee Rebells are.
verse 11 And all that trust in thee sh • ll joy,
and shout for joy eternallie,
and thou shalt them protect: & they
th • t love thy name shall jo in thee.
verse 12 For • ho • Iehovah, wilt bestow
a blessing on the rightous one:
and wilt him crowne as with a shield,
with gracio • s acceptation.

div.head: Psalme 6 To the chief Mu • ician on Neginoth upon - Sheminith, a psalme of D • vi • .
div.l: LORD in thy wrath rebuke me not,
nor in thy hot wrath chasten me
verse 2 Pitty me Lord, for I am weak,
Lord heale me, for my bones vext be.
verse 3 Also my soule is troubled sore:
how long Lord wilt thou me fors • ke?
verse 4 Returne o Lord, my soule release:
o save me for thy mercy sake.
verse 5 In death no mem'ry is of thee
and who • h • ll prayse thee in the grave?
verse 6 I faint with groanes, all night my bed
swims, I with te • rs my couch wash have.
verse 7 mine eye with grief is dim • e and old:
bec • us • of all mine enimies.
verse 8 Bu • no • dep • rt aw • y fom me,
all yee that work iniqui • ies:
for Iehov • h ev'n no • hath heard

the voyce of these 〈◊〉
• eepi • g t • ares.
verse 9 Iehova • he • re my hu •• le suit,
Iehovah doth receive my prayers.
verse 10 Let all mine enimies be asham'd
• nd greatly troubled let them be:
yea let them be returned back,
and be • shamed suddenlie.

div.head: Psalme 7 Shiggajon of David which he sāg to Iehovah upō the words of Cush the Benjamite.
div.l: O LORD my God in thee
I doe my trust repose,
save and deliver me from all
my persecuting foes.
verse 2 I est like a Lion hee
my soule in peeces teare:
rending asunder, while there is
not one d • liverer.
verse 3 Iehovah o my God
if this thing done have I:
if so t • ere be within my hands
wrongfull iniquity
verse 4 If I requited ill
the man with me at peace,
(yea I have him delivered
that was my foe causlesse:)
verse 5 Let foe pursue my soule,
and take, and tread to clay
my life: and honor in the dust
there let him wholly lay
verse 6 Arise Lord in thy wrath
for th' enimies fiercenesse:
be thou lift up, & wake to me,
judgement thou did'st expresse.
verse 7 So thee encompasse round
shall peoples assembly;
and for the same doe thou returne,
vnto the place on high.
verse 8 The Lord shall judge the folke;
Iehovah judge thou me.
according to my righteousness • ,
and mine integritie.
verse 9 Let ill mens m • lice cease,
but doe the just confirme,
for thou who art the righteous God▪
dost hearts and reins discerne.
verse 10 For God my sheild, the right
in heart he saved hath.
verse 11 The God that doth the rightous judge,
yet daily kindleth wrath.
verse 12 If he doe not returne,
his sword he sh • rp will whet:
his bow he bended hath, and he
the s • me hath ready set.
verse 13 For him h • hath prepar'd
the instruments of death,
for them that hotly persecute,
his arro • s he sh • rpneth.
verse 14 Behold he travelleth
of vaine iniquity:
a toylesome mischeife he conceiv'd,
but sh • ll bring forth a lye.
verse 15 A pit he digged h • th,
and delved deepe the same:
But fall'n he is into the ditch,
that he • imselfe did frame.
verse 16 His mischeivous labour

shall on his head turn down •
▪
and his injurious viole • ce
shall fall upon his crowne▪
verse 17 Iehovah I will prayse
for • is just equi • y;
and I will si • g unto the name
of I • hovah most high.

div.head: Psalme 8 To the chiefe Musician upon Gittith. a psalme of David.
div.l: O • ORD our God in all the earth
• ow's thy name wondrous great?
who hast thy glorious ma • esty
above the heavens set.
verse 2 out of the mouth of sucking babes.
thy strength thou didst ordeine,
that thou mightst still the enemy,
and them that thee disdaine.
verse 3 when I thy fi • gers work, thy Heav'ns,
the moo • e and st • rres consider:
verse 4 which thou hast set. What's wretched man,
that thou dost him r • m • mber?
or what's the Son of man, that thus
him vis • ted thou hast?
verse 5 For next to A • gells, thou hast him
a litle lower plac't
and hast with glory crowned him,
and comely ma • esty:
verse 6 And on thy works hast given him,
lordly authority.
verse 7 All hast thou put under his feet;
all sheep and oxen, yea
verse 8 and beasts of field. Foules of the ayre▪
and fishes of the sea;
and all that passe through paths of seas.
verse 9 O Iehovah our Lord,
how wondrously-magnificent
is thy name through the world?

div.head: Psalme 9 To the chiefe Musician upon Muth-Labben a psalme of David

lg.l: LORD I'le the prayse, with all my heart;
thy wonders all proclaime.
verse 2 I will be glad and joy in thee;
most high, I'le sing thy name.
verse 3 In turning back my foes, they'le fall
and perish at thy sight.
verse 4 For thou maintaines my right, & cause:
In throne sits judging right.
verse 5 Thou t' heathen checkst, & th'wicked stroyd;
their names raz'd ever aye.
verse 6 Thy ruines, foe, for aye are done;
thou madst their townes decaye;
their memory with them is lost.
verse 7 Yet ever sits the Lord:
• is throne to judgement he prepares.
verse 8 With right he'l judge the world:
he to the folke shall minister
judgement in uprightnesse.
verse 9 The Lord is for th'oprest a fort:
a fort in times of stresse.
verse 10 Who knowe • thy name, will trust in th • e:
nor dost thou, Lord forsake,
verse 11 them that th • e seek. Psalmes, to the Lord
that dwells in Sion, make:
declare among the folk his works.
verse 12 For blood when he doth seeke,
he them remembers: nor forgets
the crying of the meeke.
verse 13 Iehovah, mercy on me have,
from them that doe me hate
marke mine afflictions that arise,
thou lift'st me from deaths-gate.
verse 14 That I may tell in the gates of
the Daughter of Sion,
thy prayses all. and may rejoyce
in thy salvation.
verse 15 The heathen are sunk downe into
the pit that they had made:
their owne foot taken is ith'net
which privily they layd.
verse 16 By judgement which he executes
Iehovah is made know • e:
the wicked's snar'd in's ow • e hand work.
deepe meditation.
verse 17 The wic • ed shall be turn'd to hell,
all ands that God forget.
verse 18 Forgot the nee • y shall • e're be:
poores hope • e'r • faild him yet.
verse 19 Arise, o Lord, lest men prevaile,
judge t' heathen in thy sight.
verse 20 That they may know they b • but men,
the nations Lord affright. Selah
WHy standst thou Lord a far? why hyd'st
thy selfe in times of streight?
verse 2 In pride the wick • d persecutes
the poore afflicted wight:
snare them in their contrived plots.
verse 3 For of his hearts desire
the wicked boasts, and covetous
blesseth, stirring Gods ire.
verse 4 The wicked one by reason of
his counten • nces pride

will not seek after Go •
: not Go •
so all his thoughts abide.
verse 5 his wayes doe • lwayes bring forth griefe▪
on high thy ju • gements bee
above his fight: 〈◊〉 pressing foes
puffe at them all will hee.
verse 6 Within his heart he thus hath sayd,
I move • shall not bee:
fro • aye to aye because I am
not in adversitie
verse 7 His mouth with cu • sing filled is,
deceits, an • fallacy:
under his tongue perversnes is,
also iniqui • y.
verse 8 In the •• ose places of the townes
he sits, in secret dens
he slays the harmlesse: 'gainst the poo • e
slyly his eyes downe bends.
verse 9 He closely lurks as lion lurks
in den, the poore to catch
he lurks, & trapping them in 's net
th' afflicted poore doth snatch.
verse 10 Downe doth he crowtch, & to the dust
humbly he bowes with-all:
that so a multitude of poore
in his strong pawes may fall.
verse 11 He saith in heart, God hath forgot:
he hides his face away,
so that he will not see this thing
unto eternall aye.
verse 12 Iehovah rise thou up, o God
lift thou thine hand on hy,
let not the meek afflicted one
be out of memory.
verse 13 Wherefore doth the ungodly man
contemne th' almighty one?
he in his heart saith, thou wilt not
make inquisition.
verse 14 Thou seest, for thou markst wrong, & spight,
with thy hand to repay:
the poore leavs it to thee, thou art
of fatherlesse the stay.
verse 15 Break thou the arme of the wicked,
and of the evil one.
search thou out his impiety,
untill thou findest none.
verse 16 Iehovah king for ever is,
and to eternall aye:
out of his land the heathen folke
are perished away.
verse 17 The meeke afflicted-mans desire
Iehovah, thou dost heare:
thou firmly dost prepare their heart,
thou makst attent thine eare.
verse 18 To judge the fatherlesse & poore:
that ad no more he may
sorrowfull man out of the land
with terror to dismay.

div.head: Psalme 11 To the chiefe Musician a psalme of David.
div.l: I In the Lord do trust, how then
to my soule doe ye say,
as doth a litle bird unto
your mountaine flye away?
verse 2 For loe, the wicked bend their bow,
their arrows they prepare
on string; to shoot in dark at them
in heart that upright are.
verse 3 If that the firme foundationes,
utterly ruin'd bee:
as for the man that righteous is,
what then performe can hee?
verse 4 The Lor • in's holy temple is,
the Lords throne in heaven:
• is eyes will view, and his eye li • s
will prove the Sonnes of men.
verse 5 The man that truly-righteous is
ev'n him the Lord will prove;
his soule the wicked hates, & him
that violence doth love.
verse 6 Snares, fire, & brimstone he will raine,
ungodly men upon:
and burning tempest; of their cup
shall-be their portion.
verse 7 For Iehovah that righteous is,
all righteousnesse doth love:
his countenane the upright one
beholding, doth approve.

div.head: Psalme 12 To the chiefe Musician upon Shemin • th a psalme of David.
div.l: HElpe Lord: for godly men doe cease:
faithfull faile men among.
verse 2 Each to his freind speaks vanity;
with flattring lips, and tongue
and with a double heart they speake.
verse 3 All flatt'ring lips the Lord
shall cut them of, with every tongue
that speaketh boasting word.
verse 4 Thus have they sayd, we with our tongue,
prevailing pow're shall get:
are not our lips our owne for Lord
who over us is set?
verse 5 Thus saith the Lord, for sighs of them
that want, for poor opprest,
I'le now arise, from such as puffe,
will set him safe at rest.
verse 6 Pure are the words the Lord doth speak:
as silver that is tryde
in e • rthen furnace, seven times
th • t h • th been purifyde.
verse 7 Thou sh • lt them keep, o Lord, thou shalt
preserve them ev'ry one,
For eve • more in safety from
this generation.
verse 8 The wicked men on evry side
doe walk presumptuously,
when as the vilest sons of men
exalted are on hye.

div.head: Psalme 13 To the chiefe Musician: a psalme of David.
div.l: O IEHOVAH, how long
wilt thou forget me aye?
how long wilt thou thy countenance
hide from me farre away?
verse 2 H •• long shall I counsell,
in my soule take, sorrow
in my heart dayly? o're me set
how long shall be my foe?
verse 3 Iehovah, o my God,
behold me answer make,
Ill • minate mine eyes, lest I
the sleepe of death doe take.
verse 4 Lest my foe say, I have.
• revaild 'gainst him: & me
those • ho doe trouble, doe rejoyce,
w • en I shall moved • ee▪
verse 5 But I as • red trust
have put in thy mercy;
my heart in thy salvation
shall joy exceedingly.
verse 6 Vnto Iehovah I
will sing, because that hee,
for evil bountifully hath
r • warded good to mee.

div.head: Psalme 14 To the chiefe Musician a psalme of Dauid.
div.l: THe foole in's heart saith ther's no God▪
they are corrupt, have done
abominable-practises,
that doth good there is non • .
verse 2 The Lord from heaven looked down •
on Sonnes of men: to see,
if any that doth understand,
that seeketh God there bee.
verse 3 All are gone back, together they

ev' •
filthy are become:
and there is none 〈◊〉 doeth good,
noe not s • much as one.
verse 4 The workers o • iniquityes,
have they no k • owledge all?
that eate my people: they eate bread,
and on God doe not call.
verse 5 There with a very grievous feare
affrighted sore they were,
for God in generation is
of such as righteous are▪
verse 6 The counsell yee would make of hi •
that poore afflicted is,
to be asham'd & that because,
the Lord his refuge is.
verse 7 Who Israels health from Syon gives?
his folks captivitie
when God shall turne: Iacob shall joye
glad Israel shall be.

div.head: Psalme 15 A psalme of David.
div.l: IEHOVAH, who shall in thy tent
sojourne, and who is hee
shall dwell within thy holy mount?
verse 2 He that walks upright lie,
And worketh justice, and speaks truth
verse 3 in' • heart, And with his tongue
he doth not slander, neither doth
unto his neighbour wrong,
And 'gainst his neighbour that doth not
take up reproachfull lyes.
verse 4 Hee that an abject person is
contemn'd is in his eyes;
But he will highly honour them
that doe Iehovah feare:
and changeth not, though to his losse,
i • tha • he once doe swe • re.
verse 5 Nor gives his coyne to v • ury,
and bribe he doth not take
against the harmelesse▪ he that doth
these things shall • ever shake.

div.head: Psalme 16 Michtam of David
div.l: O Mighty God, preserve thou mee,
for on thee doe I rest.
verse 2 Thou art my God, vnto the Lord
my soule thou hast profest:
My goodnes reacheth not to thee.
verse 3 But to the Saints upon
the earth & to the excellent,
whome all my joye is on.
verse 4 They who give gifts to a strange God,
their sorrowes multiplye:
their drink oblations of blood
offer up will not I.
Neither will I into my lips
the names of them take up.
verse 5 Iehovah is the portion
of my part, & my cup:
Thou art maintainer of my lot.
verse 6 To me the lines fal'n bee
in pleasant places: yea, faire is
the heritage for mee.
verse 7 I will Iehovah humbly-blesse,
who hath mee counselled:
yea in the nights my reines have mee,
chastising nurtured.
verse 8 Iehovah I have alwayes set
as present before mee:
because he is at my right hand
I shall not moved bee.
verse 9 Wherefore my heart rejoyced hath,
and glad is my glory:
moreover also my flesh shall
in hope lodge securely.
verse 10 Because thou wilt not leave my sou • e
within the grave to bee,
nor wilt thou give thine holy one,
corruption for to see.
verse 11 Thou wilt shew me the path of life,
of joyes abundant-store
before thy face, at thy right hand
are plea • ures evermore.

lg.l: HArken, o Lord, unto the right,
attend vnto my crye,
give eare vnto my pray'r, that goes
from lips that doe not lye.
verse 2 From thy face let my judgement come.
thine eyes the right let see.
verse 3 Thou provst mine heart, thou visitest
by night, and tryest mee.
yet nothing find'st, I have resolvd
my mouth shall not offend.
verse 4 From mens works: by word of thy lips
I spoylers paths attend.
verse 5 Stay my feet in thy paths, lest my
verse 6 steps slip. I cal'd on thee,
for thou wilt heare, God, heare my speec • ,
incline thine eare to mee.
verse 7 O thou that sav'st by thy right hand,
thy merveilous-mercyes,
shew vnto them that trust in thee,
from such as 'gainst them r • se.

verse 8 As apple of thine eye mee keep •
▪
In thy wings shade mee hide.
verse 9 From wicked who mee wast: my foe •
in heart are on each side.
verse 10 Clos'd in their fat they are: & they
speak with their mouth proudly.
verse 11 They round us in our stepps: they set
on earth their bow'd downe eye.
verse 12 His likenes as a lion is,
that greedy is to teare,
in secret places lurking as
hee a young lion were.
verse 13 Him, in his sight, rise, disappoynt
make him bow downe o Lord,
doe thou my soule deliver from
the wicked one, thy sword,
verse 14 From mortall men thine hand, o Lord,
from men that mortall are,
and of this passing-world, who hav •
within this life their share,
with thy hid treasure furthermore
whose belly thou fillest:
their sonnes are fil'd, & to their babes
of wealth they leave the rest.
verse 15 In righteousnes, thy favour I
shall very clearely see,
and waking with thine image, I
shall satisfied bee.

div.head: Psalme 18 To the chiefe Musician, a psalme of Dauid, the s • rvant of the Lord, who spake the words of this Song, in the day that the Lord deliuered him from the hands of all his enemies, & from the hand of Saule▪ and he • Sayde,

lg.l: IL'e dearely love thee, Lord, my strength.
The Lord is my rock, and my towre,
and my deliverer, my God,
I'le trust in him who is my powre,
My shield, & my salvationes-horne,
verse 3 my high-fort; Who is prayse worthy,
I on the Lord will call, so shall
I bee kept from mine enemye.
verse 4 Deaths sorrowes mee encompassed,
mee fear'd the floods of ungodlie,
verse 5 Hells pangs beset me round about,
the snares of death prevented mee.
verse 6 I in my streights, cal'd on the Lord,
and to my God cry'd: he did heare
from his temple my voyce, my crye,
before him came, unto his eare.
verse 7 Then th' earth shooke, & quak't, & moūtaines
roots moov'd, & were stird at his ire,
verse 8 Vp from his nostrils went a smoak,
and from his mouth devouring-fire:
By it the coales inkindled were.
verse 9 Likewi • e the heavens he downe-bow'd,
and he descended, & there was
under his feet a gloomy cloud.
verse 10 And he on cherub rode, and flew;
yea he flew on the wings of winde.
verse 11 His secret place hee darknes made
his covert that him round confinde,
Dark waters, & thick clouds of skies.
verse 12 From brightnes, that before him was,
his thickned clouds did passe away,
hayl-stones and coales of fire did passe.
verse 13 Also Iehovah thundered,
within the heavens, the most high
likewise his angry-voyce did give,
hayl-stones, and coales of fire did fly.
verse 14 Yea he did out his arrows send,
and bruising he them scattered,
and lightnings hee did multiply,
likewise he them discomfited.
verse 15 The waters channels then were seene,
and the foundationes of the world
appear'd; at thy rebuke, at blast,
of the breath of thy nostrils Lord.
verse 16 Hee from above sent hee me took:
• e out of waters-great he drew.
verse 17 Hee from mine enemies-strong, & from
them which me hated did rescue.
For they were mightyer then I.
verse 18 They mee prevented in the day
of my cloudy calamity;
but for me was the Lord a stay.
verse 19 And hee me to large place brought forth:
hee sav'd mee, for he did delight
verse 20 in mee. The Lord rewa • ded me
according as I did aright,
Acco • ding to the cle • n • esse of
my hands, he recompenced mee.
verse 21 For the wayes of the Lord I kept:
nor from my God went wickedlie.
verse 22 For all his judgements mee before:
nor from me put I his decree.
verse 23 With him I upright was, and kept
my selfe from mine iniquitie.
verse 24 The Lord hath recompenced mee,
after my righteousnes therefore:
according to the cleannesse of
my hands that was his eyes before.
verse 25 With mercifull, thou mercifull,
with upright thou deales uprightly.
verse 26 With pure thou pure, thou also wilt
with froward turne thy selfe awry.
verse 27 For thou wilt save th'afflicted folke:
but wilt the lofty looks suppresse.
verse 28 For thou wilt light my lampe: the Lord▪
my God will lighten my darknesse.
verse 29 For by thee rann through a troupe,
and by my God leapt o're a wall.
verse 30 Gods way is perfect: Gods word tryde▪
that trust in him hee's shield to all.
verse 31 For who is God except the Lord?
or who a rock, our God except?
verse 32 Its God that girdeth me with strength,
and hee doth make my way perfect.
verse 33 Like to the hyndes he makes my feet:
and on my high place maks me stand.
verse 34 Mine armes doe break a bow of brasse;
so well to warre he learnes my hand.
verse 35 The shield of thy salvation
thou furthermore hast given 〈◊〉 :
and thy right-hand hath mee up • eld,
thy meeknes made mee great to bee.
verse 36 Vnder m • e thou makst large my steps.
so that mine anckles did not slyde
verse 37 My foes pursu'de I, & them caught:
nor turn'd I till they were destroyd.
verse 38 I wounded them & they could 〈◊〉
rise up: under my feet they fell.
verse 39 Because that thou hast girded mee
with fortitude to the battel▪
Thou hast subdued under mee,
those that did up against me ri •• .
verse 40 And my foes necks thou gavest mee,
that I might wast mine enemyes.
verse 41 They cryde but there was none to save,
to God, yet with no answer meet.
verse 42 I beat them then as dust i'th winde
and cast them out as dirt i'th str ••• .
verse 43 And thou from the contentions
hast of the people mee set free;
thou of the h •• then mad'st me h • ad▪
people I knew not shall serve mee.
verse 44 They'le at first hearing me obey:
strangers shall yield themselvs to m • e.
verse 45 The strangers shall consume away,
and from their closets frighted bee.
verse 46 The Lord lives, and blest be my Ro • k,
let my healths God exa • ted • ee.
verse 47 It's God for m •• that ve • geance works,
and brings dow • e p • ople under mee.
verse 48 Mee from mine enemies he doth save:
and above those that 'gainst me went,
thou lift'st me up; and thou hast freed
mee from the man that's violent.
verse 49 I with confession will therefore
unto thee render thanksgiving,
o Lord▪ among the heathen folk;
and to thy name I'le prays • s 〈◊〉 .

verse 50 He giv •• h great delivera •••
▪
to his King, and doth shew mercy
to his annoynted, to David,
and to his see • e • ernally.

div.head: Psalme 19 To the chiefe musician a psalme of David.

lg.l: THe heavens doe declare
the majesty of God:
also the firmament sh • ws fo • th
his • and • -work abroad.
verse 2 Day speaks to day, knowledge
night hath to night declar'd.
verse 3 There neither speach nor language i • ,
where their voyce is not heard.
verse 4 Through all the earth their line
is gone forth, & unto
the utmost end of all the world,
their speaches reach also:
• Ta bern • cle hee
in them pitcht for the Sun.
verse 5 Who Bridegroom like front's chamber goes
glad Giants-race • o run.
verse 6 From heavens utmost end,
his course and compassing;
to ends of it, & from the • ea •
thereof is hid nothing.
verse 7 The Lords law perfect is,
the soule converting back:
Gods testimony faithfull is,
makes wise who-wisdome-lack.
verse 8 The statutes of the Lord,
are right, & glad the heart:
the Lords commandement is pure,
light doth to eyes impart.
verse 9 Iehovahs feare is cleane,
the judgements of the Lord a • e true,
and righteous altogether.
verse 10 Then gold, then much fine gold,
more to be prized are,
then hony, & the hony-comb,
sweeter they are by farre.
verse 11 Also thy servant is
admonished from hence:
and in the keeping of the same
is a full recompence.
verse 12 Who can his errors know?
from secret faults cleanse mee.
verse 13 And from presumptuous-sins, 〈…〉
〈…〉 thy servant bee:
Let them not beare the rule
in me, & then shall I
be perfect, and shall cleansed bee
from much iniquity.
verse 14 Let the words of my mouth,
and the thoughts of my heart,
be pleasing with thee, Lord, my Rock
who my redeemer art.

div.head: Psalme 20 To the chiefe Musician, a psalme of D • vid.
div.l: IEHOVAH heare thee in the day
of sore calamity,
the name of the God ofIacob
defend thee mightily.
verse 2 Send thee help from his holy place:
from Sion strengthen thee.
verse 3 Minde all thy gifts, thy sacrifice
accepted let it bee. Sela • .
verse 4 Grant thee according to thy heart,
all thy counsell fulfill.
verse 5 In thy perfect salvation
with singing joy we will:
And we in the name of our God
our banners will erect:
when as all thy petitions
Iehovah shall effect.
verse 6 Now I know, that Iehovah doth
save his annoynted-Deare:
with saving strength of his right hand
from 〈…〉 heav'n will heare.
verse 7 In charrets some their confidence, 〈◊〉
and some in horses set:
but we the name of Iehovah
our God will not forget.
verse 8 They are brought downe & fal'n: but we,
rise and stand stedfastly.
verse 9 Save Lord, & let the King us heare
when as to him we cry.

div.head: Psalme 21 To the chiefe Musician a psalme of David.
div.l: IEHOVAH, in thy strength
the King shall joyfull bee;
and joy in thy salvation
how vehemently shall hee?
verse 2 Thou of his heart to him
hast granted the desire:
and thou hast not witholden back,
what his lips did require. Selah.
verse 3 For thou dost with blessings
of goodnes prevent him:
thou on his head of finest gold
hast set a Diadem.
verse 4 Of thee hee asked life,
to him thou gav'st it free,
even length of days for evermore
unto eternitie.
verse 5 In thy salvation
his glory hath bene great:
honour, and comely dignity
thou hast upon him set.
verse 6 For thou him blessings setst
to perpetuitie:
Thou makst him with thy countenance
exceeding glad to bee.
verse 7 Bec • use that in the Lord
the King doth trust, & hee
through mercy of the highest one,
shall not removed bee.

verse 8
〈…〉 shall finde out all
that are thine enemies:
thy right hand also shall finde ou •
those that doe thee despise.
verse 9 Thou setst as fiery oven
them in times of thine ire:
the Lord will swallow them in's wrath
and them consume with fire.
verse 10 Thou wilt destroy the fruit,
that doth proceed of them,
out of the earth: & their seed from
among the Sonnes of men.
verse 11 Because they evill have
intended against thee:
a wicked plot they have devis'd,
but shall not able bee.
verse 12 For thou wilt as a butt
them set; & thou wilt place
thine arrows ready on thy string,
full right against their face.
verse 13 Lord, in thy fortitude
exalted bee on high:
and wee will sing; yea prayse with psalmes▪
thy mighty powr will wee.

div.head:
Psalme 22 To the chiefe musician upon Aijeleth Sh • ba •
a psalme of David.

lg.l: MY God, my God, wherefore hast thou
forsaken mee? & why,
art thou so farre from helping mee,
from the words of my cry?
verse 2 O my God, I doe cry by day,
but mee thou dost not heare;
and eke by night, & unto mee
no quiet rest is there.
verse 3 Neverthelesse thou holy art,
who constantly dost dwell,
within the thankfull prayses of
thy people Israell.
verse 4 Our fore-fathers in thee have put
assured confidence:
they trusted have, & thou to them
didst give deliverance.
verse 5 Vnto thee they did cry aloud,
and were delivered:
in thee they put their confidence,
and were not confounded.
verse 6 But I a worme, & not a man;
of men an opprobrie,
and also of the people am
despis'd contemp • uouslie.
verse 7 All they that doe upon mee look,
a scoffe at mee doe make:
they with the lip doe make a mow,
the head in scorne they shake.
verse 8 Vpon the Lord he rold himselfe,
let him now rid him quite:
let him deliver him, because
in him he doth delight.
verse 9 But thou art hee that me out of
the belly forth didst take:
when I was on my mothers breasts,
to hope thou didst mee make.
verse 10 Vnto thee from the tender-womb
committed been have I:
yea thou hast been my mighty-God
from my mothers belly.
verse 11 Be thou not farre away from mee,
for tribulation
exceeding great is neere at hand,
for helper there is none.
verse 12 Mee many buls on every side
about have compassed:
the mighty-buls of Bashan have
mee round invironed.
verse 13 They have with their wide-opened-mouths
so gaped mee upon;
like as it were a ravening
and a roaring Lion.
verse 14 As water I am poured-out,
and all my bones sundred:
my heart in midst of my bowels,
is like to wax melted.
verse 15 My strength like a potsherd is dryde;
and my tongue fast-cleaveth
unto my jawes, & thou hast brought
me to the dust of death.
verse 16 For dogs have compast me about;
th' assembly me beset
of the wicked; they pierced through
my hands, also my feet.
verse 17 My bones I may them number all:
they lookt, they did me view.
verse 18 My cloths among them they did part:
and lot for my coat threw.
verse 19 But thou Lord be not far, my strength,
to help me hasten thou.
verse 20 My soule from sword, my darling from
the powre of dogs rescue.
verse 21 And from the mouth of the Lion
give me salvation free:
for thou from hornes of Vnicornes
answer hast given mee.
verse 22 Thy name, I will declare to them
that Brethren are to mee:
in midst of congregation
I will give prayse to thee.
verse 23 Yee that doe feare the Lord prayse him;
all Iacobs seed prayse yee,
him glorify, & dread him all
yee Israels seed that bee.
verse 24 For he the poors affliction
loaths not, nor doth despise;
nor hides his face from him, but hears
when unto him hee cryes.
verse 25 Concerning thee shall be my prayse
in the great assembly:
before them that him reverence
performe my vowes will I.
verse 26 The meek shall eat & be suffic'd:
Iehovah prayse shall they
that doe him seek: your heart shall live
unto perpetuall aye.
verse 27 All ends of th'earth remember shall
and turne unto the Lord:
and thee all heathen-families
to worship shall accord.
verse 28 Because unto Iehovah doth
the kingdome appertaine:
and he among the nations
is ruler Soveraigne.
verse 29 Earths-fat-ones, eat & worship shall:
all who to dust descend,
(though none can make alive his soule)
before his face shall bend.
verse 30 With service a posterity
him shall attend upon;
to God it shall accounted bee
a generation.
verse 31 Come shall they, & his righteousnes
by them declar'd shall bee,
unto a people yet unborne,
that done this thing hath hee.

div.head: 23 A Psalme of David.
div.l: THe Lord to mee a shepheard is,
want therefore shall not I.
verse 2 Hee in the folds of tender-grasse,
doth cause mee downe to lie:
To waters calme me gently leads
verse 3 Restore my soule doth hee:
he doth in paths of righteousnes:
for his names sake leade mee.
verse 4 Yea though in valley of deaths shad
I walk, none ill I'le feare:
because thou art with mee, thy rod,
a • d staffe my comfort are.
verse 5 For mee a table thou hast spread,
in presence of my foes:
thou d • st annoynt my head with oyle,
my cup it over-flowes.
verse 6 Good • es & mercy surely shall
all my dayes follow mee:
and in the Lords house I shall dwell
so long as d • yes shall bee.

div.head: Psalme 24 A psalme of david.
div.l: THe earth Iehovahs is,
and the fulnesse of it:
the ••• itable world, & they
tha • there upon doe sit.
verse 2 Becaus • upon the seas,
hee hath it firmly layd:
and it upon the water-floods
most sollidly hath stayd.
verse 3 The mountaine of the Lord,
who shall thereto ascend?
and i • his pl • ce of hol • nes,
who is it that shall stand?
verse 4 The cleane in hands, & pure
in heart; to vanity
who hath not lifted up his soule,
nor sworne deceitfully.
verse 5 From God he shall receive
a benediction,
and righteousnes from the strong-God
of his salvation.
verse 6 This is the progenie
of them that seek thy face:
of them that doe inquire for him:
of Iacob 'tis the race. Sela • .
verse 7 Yee gates lift-up your heads,
and doors everlasting,
• e yee lift up: & there into
shall come the glorious-King.
verse 8 Who is this glorious King?
Iehovah, puissant,
and valiant, Iehovah is
in battel valiant.
verse 9 Yee gates lift-up your heads,
and door • everlasting,
doe yee lift-up: & there into
shall come t • e glorious-King▪
verse 10 Who is his glorious-King?
loe, it i • Iehovah
of w • rlike • rmies, hee the King
of glory is; Selah.

lg.l: I Lift my soule to thee o Lord.
My God I trust in thee,
let mee not be asham'd: nor let
my foes joy over mee.
verse 3 Yea, all that wait on thee shall not,
be fill'd with shamefulnes:
but they shall be ashamed all,
who without cause transgresse.
verse 4 Thy wayes, Iehovah, make mee know,
thy paths make me discerne.
verse 5 Cause mee my steps to order well,
in thy truth, & mee learne,
For thou God of my saving health,
on thee I wait all day.
verse 6 Thy bowels, Lord, & thy mercyes
minde; for they are for aye.
verse 7 Sinnes of my youth remember not,
neither my trespasses:
after thy mercy minde thou mee
o Lord for thy goodnes.
verse 8 Good and upright God is, therefore
will sinners teach the way.
verse 9 The meek he'l • guide in judgemen • : &
will teach the meek his way.
verse 10 I • hovahs paths they mercy are,
• ll of • hem • ruth also,
to • hem th • t keep his covenant,
and testimo • ies do.
verse 11 F • r t • y nam • sake o Iehovah,
freely doe thou 〈◊〉
mine owne perverse iniquitie:
because that great is it.
verse 12 Who fears the Lord, him hee will teach
the way that he shall chuse.
verse 13 his soule shall dwell at ease, his seed
as heirs the earth shall vse.
verse 14 The secret of God is with those
that doe him reverence:
and of his covenant he them
will give intelligence.
verse 15 Mine eyes continually are
upon Iehovah set:
for it is hee that will bring forth
my feet out of the net.
verse 16 Vnto me-wards turne thou thy face,
and on mee mercy show:
because I solitary am
afflicted poore also.
verse 17 My hearts troubles inlarged are;
from my distresse me bring.
verse 18 See mine affliction, & my paine;
and pardon all my sin.
verse 19 Mark my foes; for they many are,
and cruelly mee hate,
verse 20 My soule keep, free mee; nor let mee
be sham'd, who on thee wait.
verse 21 Let soundnes, & uprightnesse keep
mee: for I trust in the • .
verse 22 Israel from his troubles all,
o God, doe thou set fr • e.

div.head: 26 A 〈…〉 .
div.l: IVdge mee, o Lord, for I have walkt
in mine integrity:
and I have trusted in the Lord,
therefore slyde shall not I.
verse 2 Examine mee, Lord, & mee prove;
my reins, & my heart • ry.
verse 3 For thy grace is before mine eyes;
and in thy truth walk I▪
verse 4 I sat not with vaine men, nor goe
with men themselves that hide.
verse 5 Evill mens company I hate:
nor will with vile abide.
verse 6 In cleannesse, Lord, I'le wash mine hands,
so I'le thine altar round:
verse 7 That I may preach with thankfull-voyce,
and all thy prayses sound.
verse 8 The habitation of thy house,
Lord, dearly love doe I,
the place and tabernacle of
thy glorious majesty.
verse 9 My soule with sinners gather not,
with men of blood my life.
verse 10 In whose hand 's guile, in whose right hand
bribery is full rife.
verse 11 Redeeme, & pitty mee; for I'le
walk in mine uprightnesse.
verse 12 My foot stands right: in th'assembly
I will Iehovah blesse.

lg.l: THe Lord my light, & my health is,
what shall make me dismaid?
The Lord is my lifes-strength, of whom
should I then be afrayd?
verse 2 When wicked men, mine enemies,
and my foes in battel;
against mee come, to eate my flesh,
themselves stumbled & fell.
verse 3 If that an hosta against mee camp,
my heart undaunted is:
if war against mee should arise,
I am secure in this.
verse 4 One thing of God I asked have,
which I will still request:
that I may in the house of God,
all dayes of my life rest:
To see the beauty of the Lord,
and in his Temple seeke.
verse 5 For in his tent in th'evill-day,
hidden hee will mee keepe:
Hee will me hide in secrecy
of his pavillion:
and will me highly lift upon
the rocks-munition.
verse 6 Moreover at this-time my head
lifted on high shall bee,
above mine enemies, who doe
about encompasse mee.
Therefore in's tent I'le sacrifice,
of joye an offering,
into Iehovah, sing will I,
yea, I will prayses sing.
verse 7 When as I with my voyce doe cry,
mee, o Iehovah, heare▪
have mercy also upon mee,
and unto mee answer.
verse 8 When thou didst say, seek yee my face,
my heart sayd unto thee,
thy countenance, o Iehovah,
it shall be sought by mee.
verse 9 Hide not thy face from mee, nor off
in wrath thy servant cast:
God of my health, leave, leave not mee,
my helper been thou hast.
verse 10 My father & my mother both
though they doe mee forsake,
yet will Iehovah gathering
unto himselfe me take.
verse 11 Iehovah, teach thou mee the way,
and be a guide to mee
in righteous path, because of them
that mine observers bee.
verse 12 Give mee not up unto the will
of my streight-enemies:
for witnesse false against me stand,
and breath out cruelties.
verse 13 I should haue fainted, had not I
believed for to see,
Iehovahs goodnes in the land
of them that living bee.

verse 14 Doe thou upon Iehovah wait •
▪
bee stablished, & let
thine heart be strengthened, & thine hope
upon Iehovah set.
IEHOVAH, unto thee I cry,
my Rock, be thou not deafe me fro:
lest thou be dumb from mee & I
be like them downe to pit that go.
verse 2 Heare thou the voyce of my request
for grace, when unto thee I cry:
when I lift up mine hands unto
thine Oracle of Sanctity.
verse 3 With ill men draw me not • way,
with workers of unrighteousnes,
that with their neighbours peace doe speak,
but in their hands is wickednes.
verse 4 Give thou to them like to their works
and like the evill of their deeds:
give them like to their handy-works,
and render unto them their meeds.
verse 5 Because unto Iehovahs work
they did not wise-attention yeild,
neither unto his handy work,
them he will wast, but not up-build.
verse 6 The Lord be blest, for he hath heard
the voyce of my requests for grace.
verse 7 God is my strength, my shield, in him
my heart did trust, & helpt I was:
Therefore my heart will gladnes shew,
and with my song I'le him confesse▪
verse 8 The Lord of his annoynted ones
their strength, & towre of safety is.
verse 9 Salvation to thy people give,
and blesse thou thine inheritance,
and ev'n unto eternity
doe thou them feed & them advance.

lg.head: This. After the common tunes.
lg.l: Save Lord, thy people, & doe thou
blesse thine inheritance:
and unto all eternity
them feed & them advance.

div.head: Psalme 29 A psalme of David.
div.l: VNto the Lord doe yee ascribe
(o Sonnes of the mighty)
unto the Lord doe yee ascribe
glory & potency.
verse 2 Vnto the Lord doe yee ascribe
his names glorious renowne,
in beauty of his holynes
unto the Lord bow downe.
verse 3 The mighty voyce of Iehovah
upon the w • ters is:
the God of glory thund • reth,
God on great waters is.
verse 4 Iehovahs voyce is powerfull,
Gods voyce is glorious,
verse 5 Gods voyce breaks Cedars: yea God breaks
Cedars of Lebanus.
verse 6 He makes them like a calfe to skip:
the mountaine Lebanon,
and like to a young Vnicorne
the hill of Syrion.
verse 7 Gods voyce divides the flames of fire.
verse 8 Iehovahs voyce doth make
the desart shake: the Lord doth cause
the Cadesh-desart shake.
verse 9 The Lords voyce makes the hindes to calve,
and makes the forrest bare:
and in his temple every one
his glory doth declare.
verse 10 The Lord sate on the flouds: the Lord
for ever sits as King.
verse 11 God to his folk gives strength: the Lord
his folk with peace blessing.

div.head: Psalme 30 A Psalme & Song, at the dedication of the house of David.
div.l: IEHOVAH, I will thee extoll,
for thou hast lift up mee;
and over mee thou hast not made
my foes joyfull to bee.
verse 2 O Lord my God, to thee I cry'de
and thou hast made mee whole.
verse 3 Out of the grave, o Iehovah,
thou hast brought up my sou • e:
Thou mad'st mee live, I went not downe
verse 4 to pit. Sing to the Lord,
(yee his Saints) & give thanks when yee
his holynes record.
verse 5 For but a moment in his wrath;
life in his love doth stay:
weeping may lodge with us a night
but joye at break of day.
verse 6 I sayd in my prosperity,
I shall be moved never.
verse 7 Lord by thy favour thou hast made
my mountaine stand fast ever:
Thou hidst thy face, I troubled was.
verse 8 I unto thee did cry,
o Lord: also my humble suit
unto the Lord made I.
verse 9 What gaine is in my blood; when I
into the pit goe downe?
shall dust give glory unto thee?
shall it thy truth make knowne?
verse 10 Doe thou mee o Iehovah, heare,
and on mee mercy have:
Iehovah, o bee thou to mee
an helper me to save.
verse 11 Thou into dancing for my sake
converted hast my sadnes:
my sackcloth thou unloosed hast,
and girded me with gladnes:
verse 12 That sing to thee my glory may,
and may not silent bee:
o Lord my God, I will give thanks
for evermore to thee.

div.head: Psalme 31 To the chief Musician, a psalme of David.

lg.l: IN thee, o Lord, I put my trust,
let me be shamed never:
according to thy righteousnes
o doe thou mee deliver.
verse 2 Bow downe to mee thine eare, with speed
let mee deliverance have:
be thou my strong rock, for an house
of defence mee to save.
verse 3 Because thou unto mee a rock
and my fortresse wilt bee:
therefore for thy names sake doe thou,
leade mee & guide thou mee.
verse 4 Doe thou mee pull out of the net,
which they have for mee layd
so privily: because that thou
art to mee a sure ayd.
verse 5 Into thy hands my spirit I
reposing doe commit:
Iehovah God of verity,
thou hast redeemed it.
verse 6 I hated them that have regard
to lying vanity:
verse 7 but I in God trust. I'le be glad,
and joy in thy mercy:
Because thou hast considered
my afflicting distresse;
thou hast my soule acknowledged
in painfull anguishes;
verse 8 And thou hast not inclosed mee
within the enemies hand:
thou mad'st my feet within the place
of liberty to stand.
verse 9 Have mercy upon mee, o Lord,
for in distresse am I,
with grief mine eye consumed is,
my soule & my belly.
verse 10 For my life with grief & my years
with sighs are consumed:
because of my sin, my strength failes,
and my bones are wasted.
verse 11 To all my foes I was a scorne,
chiefly my neighbours to;
a feare to freinds: they that saw mee
without, did flye me fro.
verse 12 I am forgot as a dead man
that's out of memory:
and like a vessel that is broke
ev'n such a one am I.
verse 13 Because that I of many men
the slandering did heare,
round about me on every side
there was exceeding feare:
While as that they did against mee
counsell together take,
they craftily have purposed
my life away to make.
verse 14 But o Iehovah, I in thee
my confidence have put
verse 15 I sayd thou art my God. My times
within thy hand are shut:
From the hands of mine enemies
doe thou deliver mee,
and from the men who mee against
my persecuters bee.
verse 16 Thy countenance for to shine forth
upon thy servant make:
o give to me salvation
even for thy mercy sake.
verse 17 Let me not be asham'd, o Lord,
for cal'd on thee I have:
let wicked men be sham'd, let them
be silent in the grave.
verse 18 Let lying lips be silenced,
that against men upright
doe speak such things as greivous are;
in pride, & in despight.
verse 19 How great 's thy goodnes, thou for thē
that feare thee hast hidden:
which thou work'st for them that thee trust,
before the Sonnes of men.
verse 20 Thou in the secret of thy face,
shalt hide them from mans pride:
in a pavillion, from the strife
of tongues, thou wilt them hide.
verse 21 O let Iehovah blessed be;
for he hath shewed mee
his loving kindnes wonderfull
in a fenced-cittie.
verse 22 For I in hast sayd, I am cast
from the sight of thine eyes:
yet thou hear • st the voyce of my fuit,
when to thee were my cryes.
verse 23 O love the Lord all ye his Saints;
because the Lord doth guard
the faithfull, but the proud doer
doth plenteously reward.
verse 24 See that yee be encouraged,
and let your heart wax strong:
all whosoever hopefully
doe for Iehovah long.

div.head: 32 A psalme of David, Maschil,
div.l: O Blessed is the man who hath
his trespasse pardoned,
and he whose aberration
is wholly covered,
verse 2 O blessed is the man to whom
the Lord imputes not sin:
and he who such a spirit hath
that guile is not therein.
verse 3 When I kept silence then my bones,
began to weare away,
with age; by meanes of my roaring
continuing all the day.
verse 4 For day & night thy hand on mee,
heavily did indure:
into the drought of Summer time
turned is my moisture. Selah.
verse 5 My aberration unto thee
I have acknowledged,
and mine iniquity I have
not closely covered:
Against my selfe my sin, sayd I,
I will to God confesse,
and thou didst the iniquitie
forgive of my trespasse. Selah.
verse 6 For this each godly one to thee
in finding time shall pray.
surely in floods of waters great,
come nigh him shall not they.
verse 7 Thou art my hyding-place, thou shalt
from trouble save me out:
thou with songs of deliverance
shalt compasse me about.
verse 8 I will instruct thee, also teach
thee in the way will I
which thou shalt goe, I will to thee
give counsell with mine eye.
verse 9 Like to the horse & mule, which have
noe knowledge be not yee:
whose mouths are held with bridle-bit,
that come not neere to thee.
verse 10 To those men that ungodly are,
their sorrows doe abound:
but him that trusteth in the Lord,
mercy shall compasse round.
verse 11 Be in Iehovah joyfull yee,
yee righteous ones rejoyce;
and all that are upright 〈◊〉 heart
shout yee with joyfull voyce.

lg.l: YEe just in God rejoyce,
pr • yse well th'upright doth sure:
verse 2 Prayse God with Harp, with psaltry 〈◊〉
to him, on ten string 'd lute.
verse 3 Sing to him a new song,
aloud play skilfully.
verse 4 For the Lords word is right: and all
his works in verity.
verse 5 He loveth righteousnes,
and also equity:
the earth replenished is with
the Lords benignity.
verse 6 By the word of the Lord
the heavens had their frame,
and by the spirit of his mouth,
all the host of the same.
verse 7 The waters of the seas,
he gathers as an heape;
together as in store-houses
he layeth up the deepe.
verse 8 Be all the earth in feare,
because of Iehovah:
let all the dwellers of the world
before him stand in awe.
verse 9 Because he did but speak
the word, & it was made:
he gave out the commandement,
and it was firmly stay'd.
verse 10 The Lord to nought doth bring
the nations counsell; hee
devises of the people makes
of none effect to bee.
verse 11 The counsell of the Lord
abide for ever shall,
the 〈◊〉 of his heart
to generations all.
verse 12 O blessed nation,
whose God Iehovah is:
and people whom for heritage
chosen hee hath for his.
verse 13 The Lord from heaven looks,
all Sonnes of men views well.
verse 14 From his firme dwelling hee looks forth,
on all that on earth dwell.
verse 15 The hearts of all of them
alike he fashioneth:
and all their operations
he well considereth.
verse 16 By multitude of boast
there is no King saved▪
nor is by multitude of strength
the strong delivered.
verse 17 A horse a vaine thing is
to be a saviour:
nor shall he work deliverance
by greatnes of his power.
verse 18 On them that doe him feare
loe, is Iehovahs eye:
upon them that doe place their hope
on his benignity.
verse 19 To save alive in dearth,
•• d their soule from death • ree.
verse 20 Our soule doth for Iehovah way • ,
our help, & shield is hee.
verse 21 For our heart joyes in him:
for in's pure name trust wee.
verse 22 Let thy mercy (Lord) be on us:
like as we trust in thee.

div.head: Psalme 34 A psalme of David, whē he changed his behaviour before Abimelech, who drove him away & he departed.

lg.l: ILe blesse God alwayes, his prayse shall
still in my mouth be had.
verse 2 My soule shall boast in God: the meeke
shall heare this & bee glad.
verse 3 Exalt the Lord with mee, his name
let us together advance.
verse 4 I sought, God heard, who gave from all
my fears deliverance.
verse 5 Him they beheld, & light'ned were,
nor sham'd were their faces.
verse 6 This poore man cry'd, the Lord him heard,
and freed from all distresse.
verse 7 His camp about them round doth pit • h
the Angell of the Lord;
who doe him feare; and to them doth
deliverance afford.
verse 8 O • ast, also consider yee,
that God is good: o blest,
that man is ever whose hope doth
for safety in him rest.
verse 9 O stand in feare of Iehovah,
his holy ones who bee.
because that such as doe him feare
not any want shall see.
verse 10 The Lions young doe suffer lack,
and suffer hungering:
but they that seek Iehovah, shall
not want any good thing.
verse 11 I will you teach to feare the Lord:
come children hark to mee.
verse 12 Who is the man that willeth life:
and loves good dayes to see?
verse 13 Thy tongue from evill, & thy lips
from speaking guile keep thou.
verse 14 Depart from evill & doe good:
seek peace, and it follow.
verse 15 Vpon the men that righteous are
the Lord doth set his eye:
and likewise he doth bow his eare
when unto him they cry.
verse 16 Iehovahs face is set against
them that doe wickedly:
that he of them from off the earth
may cut the memory.
verse 17 They cry'd, God heard, & set them free,
from their distresses all.
verse 18 To broken hearts the Lord is neere,
and contrite save he shall.
verse 19 The just mans sorrows many are,
from all God sets him free.
verse 20 Hee kepeth all his bones, that none
of them shall broken bee.
verse 21 Evill shall certainly bring death
the wicked man upon:
and those that hate the just shall come
to desolation.
verse 22 The soules of them that doe him serve,
Iehovah doth redeeme:
nor • ny shall be desolate,
that put their trust in him.
PLead, • ord, with them that with me plead:
fight against them that fight with mee.
verse 2 Of shield & buckler take thou hold,
stand up my helper for to bee.
verse 3 Draw out the speare & stop the way
'gainst them that my pursuers bee:
and doe thou say unto my soule
I am salvation unto thee.
verse 4 Let them confounded be, & sham'd,
that seek my soule how they may spill:
l • t them be turned back & sham'd
that in their thoughts devise mine ill.
verse 5 As chaffe before the winde, let them
be, & Gods Angell them driving.
verse 6 Let their way dark & slippery bee,
and the Lords Angell them chasing.
verse 7 For in a pit without a cause,
they hidden have for me a net:
which they without a cause have digg'd
that they there in my soule may get.
verse 8 Let unknowne ruin come on him,
and let his net that he doth hide,
himselfe insnare: let him into
the very same destruction slyde.
verse 9 My soule shall in the Lord be glad:
in his s • lvation joyfull bee
verse 10 And all my bones shall also say,
o Lord, who is like unto thee?
Who from the stronger then himselfe
the poore afflicted settest free:
the poore afflicted & needy,
from such as spoylers of him bee.
verse 11 False witnesses did up arise:
what I knew not they charg'd on mee.
verse 12 Evill for good they mee repay'd,
whereby my soule might spoyled bee,
verse 13 But I, when they were sick, was cloath'd
with sackcloath, & I afflicted
my soule with fasting, & my pray'r
into my bosom returned.
verse 14 I walked as if he had been
my neere freind or mine owne brother:
I heavily bow'd downe as one
that mourneth for his owne mother.
verse 15 But they in mine adversity
rejoyced, & they gathered
themselves together: yea abjects
themselves against mee gathered;
And I was ignorant hereof;
and they unceasantly mee teare,
verse 16 With hypocrites, mockers in feasts;
at me their teeth they gnashing were.
verse 17 How long o Lord wilt thou look on?
my soule from their destructions,
o doe thou set at liberty,
my only one from the Lions.
verse 18 I freely will give thanks to thee
within the congregation great:
and I thy prayses will set forth
where there be many people met.
verse 19 Those that are wrongfully my foes,
let them not rejoyce over mee:
neither let them wink with the eye,
that are my haters causlesly.
verse 20 Because that they doe not speak pe • ce▪
but in their thoughts they doe invent
deceitfull matters against them
that in the land for peace are bent.
verse 21 Gainst me they op'ned their mouths wid •
& sayd, ah, ah our eye it saw.
verse 22 Thou saw'st it (Lord) hold not thy peace:
Lord, from me be not far away.
verse 23 Stirre up & wake to my judgement,
my God & my Lord, to my plea.
verse 24 After thy justice, judge me, Lord
my God, lest or'e me joy should they.
verse 25 Let them not say within their hearts,
aha, our soules desire have wee:
we now have swallowed him up,
o let them never say of mee.
verse 26 Sham'd let them be & confounded
joyntly, who at my hurt are glad:
let them that 'gainst me magnify,
with shame & dishonour be clad.
verse 27 Let them for joy shout, & be glad
that favour doe my righteous • ause:
yea, let them say continually,
extolled be the Lord with prayse,
Who doth in the prosperity
of his servants his pleasure stay
verse 28 And my tongue of thy justice shall,
and of thy prayse speake all the day.

div.head: Psalme 36. To the chief Musician a psalme of David, the servant of the Lord.

lg.l: THe trespasse of the wicked one
saith in assured-wise:
within my heart, the feare of God
is not before his eyes.
verse 2 For in his eyes he sooths himselfe:
his sin is found meane while
verse 3 hatefull. The words of his mouth are
iniquity & guile:
He to be wise, to doe good leaves.
verse 4 He mischief plotts on's bed,
he sets himselfe in way not good:
he hath not ill hated.
verse 5 Thy mercy (Lord) in heaven is,
to clouds thy faithfullnes.
verse 6 Thy judgements a great deep, like great
mountains thy righteousnes:
Thou savest m • n & beast, o Lord.
verse 7 Ho • pretious is thy grace,
ther • fore i • shadow of thy wings
mens sonnes their trust doe place.
verse 8 They of the fa •• es of thy-house
unto the full shall take:
and of the river of thy joyes
to drink thou shalt them make.
verse 9 For with thee is the spring of life:
in thy light wee'll see light.
verse 10 To them that know thee stretch thy grace;
to right in heart thy right.
verse 11 Let no proud foot against me come,
nor wicked hand move mee.
verse 12 Wrong doers there are fal'n cast downe,
and rays'd they cannot bee,
FRet not thy selfe because of those
that evill workers bee,
nor envious bee against the men
that work iniquitie.
verse 2 For like unto the grasse they shall
be cut downe, suddenly:
and like unto the tender herb
they withering shall dye.
verse 3 Vpon the Lord put thou thy trust,
and bee thou doing good,
so shalt thou dwell within the land,
and sure thou shalt have food.

verse 4 Se •
• hat thou set thy hearts delight
also upon the Lord,
and the desyers of thy heart
to thee he will afford.
verse 5 Trust in the Lord: & hee'l it work,
to him commit thy w • y.
verse 6 As light thy justice hee'l bring forth,
thy judgement as noone day.
verse 7 Rest in Iehovah, & for him
with patience doe thou stay:
fret not thy selfe because of him
who prospers in his way,
Nor at the man, who brings to passe
the crafts he doth devise.
verse 8 Cease ire, & wrath leave: to doe ill
thy selfe fret in no wife.
verse 9 For evil doers shall be made
by cutting downe to fall:
but those that wayt upon the Lord,
the land inherit shall.
