verse 10 Gods cov'nant they kept not: to walk
in his law they denyde▪
verse 11 His works, & wonders, they forgot,
that he to them descryde.
verse 12 Things that were mervielous he did
within their fathers sight:
in Egipts land, within the field
of Zoan, by his might.
verse 13 He did devide the sea, also
he caus'd them through to passe:
& he the waters made to stand
that as an heap it was.
verse 14 With cloud by day, with fire all night
verse 15 he led them; Rocks he clave
in wildernes, as from great deep •
drink unto them he gave.
verse 16 Ev'n from out of the stony rock
streames he did bring also,
& caused water to run downe
like as the rivers do.
verse 17 Moreover they did adde yet more
against him for to sin:
by their provoaking the most high
the wildernes within.
verse 18 And also th • y within their heart
did tempt the God of might:
by asking earnestly for meat
for their soules appetite:
verse 19 Moreover they against God spake:
they s • yd can God be able
within the desart wildernes
to furnish us a table▪
verse 20 Loe, he the rock smote, thence gusht out
waters, & streames did flow:
for his folk can he flesh provide,
can he give bread also?
verse 21 The Lord heard, he was wroth for this,
so kindled was a fire
'gainst Iacob: & 'gainst Israell
there came up wrathfull ire.
verse 22 For they in God believed not:
nor in his health did hope:
verse 23 Though from above he charg'd the clouds:
& doores of heav'n set ope:
verse 24 Manna to eate he raind on them;
& gave them the heavns wheat.
verse 25 Each man of them ate Angells food:
to th'full he sent them meate.
verse 26 Ith heav'ns he made the East-winde blow:
brought South-winde by his powre.
verse 27 He flesh on them like dust: wing'd foules
like the seas sand did showre.
verse 28 And in the middest of their camp
he caused it to fall,
ev'n round about on every side
their dwelling places all.
verse 29 So they did eate, they filled were
abundantly also:
for that which was their owne desire
he did on them bestow:
verse 30 Howbeit they were not estrang'd
from their lustfull desire:
but while their meat was in their mouths,
verse 31 Vpon them came Gods ire,
And slew their fat ones: & smote downe
of Israell the choise men.
verse 32 Still for all this they sin'd: nor did
believe his wonders then.
verse 33 Therefore he did in vanity
the dayes of their life spend,
and hastily he brought their yeares
vnto a fearfull end.
verse 34 When he them slew, then after him
they sought with their desire:
and they return'd, early also
did after God enquire.
verse 35 Likewise that God was their strong rock
they cal'd to memoree:
and • hat the mighty God most high,
was their Redeemer free.
verse 36 Yet with their mouth they flattred him:
and to him their tongues lyde.
verse 37 For right their heart was not in them:
nor did in's cov'nant byde.
verse 38 But full of mercy, he forgave
their sin, & stroyd them not;
yea, oft he turn'd his wrath aside,
nor rays'd all's anger hot.
verse 39 For he, that they were but fraile flesh,
and as it were a winde
that passeth, & comes not againe,
recalled unto minde·
verse 40 How oft in desart vext they him:
and made him there to moane?
verse 41 Yea, they turn'd, tempted God: & did
stint Isr'ells holy one.
verse 42 His hand they did not, nor the day
keep in their remembrance:
wherein he from the enemy
gave them deliverance:
verse 43 And how his signes miraculous
in Egipt he had showne:
and his most fearfull prodigies
within the field of Zoan:
verse 44 Also how he their rivers had
converted into bloud:
& (that they could not drink therof)
the waters of their floud.
verse 45 Amongst them, which did them devoure,
he sent forth divers flies:
& them amongst, which them destroyd,
he sent forth frogs likewise.
verse 46 He gave their fruit to th'Caterpillar:
their labour to th'Locust.
verse 47 He did their Vines destroy with hail • :
their Sycamores with frost.
verse 48 Also unto the haile he did
their cattell shut up fast:
likewise their heards of cattell to
the fiery thunder blast,
verse 49 He cast on them fierce ire, & wrath,
& indignation,
& sore distresse: by sending forth
ill Angells them upon.
verse 50 He made a way unto his wrath▪
and their soule did not sav •
from death: also their life over
to Pestilence he gave,
verse 51 He within Egipt land also
all the first borne did smite:
those that within the tents of Ham
were chiefest of their might▪
verse 52 But he made like a flock of sheep
his owne folk forth to go:
like to a flock ith wildernes
he guided them also.
verse 53 And he in safety did them lead
so that they did not dread:
within the sea their enemies
he also covered.
verse 54 And to the border he did bring
them of his holy place:
unto this mountaine which he did
by his right hand purchase.
verse 55 Fore them he cast the heathen out,
their lot he did devide
by line: & Isr'ells tribes he made
in their tents to abide.
verse 56 Yet they tempted the most high God,
& griev'd him bitterly:
also his testimonyes they
kept not attentively:
verse 57 But like their fathers back they turn'd
and faithlesnesse did show:
they turned were aside ev'n like
to a deceitfull bowe.
verse 58 For they to anger did provoake
him with their places hye:
& with their graven Images,
mov'd him to jealousy.
verse 59 God hearing this, was wroth, & loath'd
Isr'ell with hatred great:
verse 60 So Shiloh s tent he left: the tent
which men amongst he set,
verse 61 And he delivered his strength
into captivity:
also into the enemies hand
his beautifull glory.
verse 62 To th'sword he gave his folk: & was
wroth with his heritage.
verse 63 Fire their young men devour'd: their maides
none gave to marriage.
verse 64 Their Priests fell by the sword: also
their widdows did not weepe.
verse 65 Then did the Lord arise as one
awakned out of sleepe:
Like a strong man that after wine
verse 66 doth shout. He also smote
his foes behinde: & so he gave
them an eternall blot.
verse 67 Then he did Iosephs tent refuse:
nor Ephr'ims tribe approv'd.
verse 68 But he the tribe of Iudah chose:
moun • Sion which he lov'd.
verse 69 And he his Sanctuary built
like unto places high:
like to the earth which he did found
to perpetuity.
verse 70 Of David also his servant
election he did make,
and from the place of folding up
the sheep he did him take.
verse 71 From following the ewes with young
he did him then advance;
to feed Iacob his folk, also
Isr'ell his heritance.
verse 72 So he according to his hearts
integrity them fed:
and by the wise disrcetion
of his hands he them led.
O GOD▪ the heathen entred have
thine heritance, & defylde
thine holy temple: they on heaps
Ierusalem have pylde.
verse 2 The dead bodyes of thy servants
they given have for meate
to th' fowles of heav'n: flesh of thy Saints
for be • sts of earth to eat • .
verse 3 Their bloud they have forth powred • ound
about Ierusal • m
like unto waters: & there was
none for to bury th • m.
verse 4 To those that neere unto us dwell
reproach become are wee:
a scoffing & a scorne to them
that round about us bee▪
verse 5 How long, I • hovah, wilt thou still
continue in thine ire,
for ever? shall thy jealousie
bu • ne like as doth the fire?
verse 6 Vpon the heathen poure thy wrath
which never did thee know,
upon the kingdomes that have not
cal'd on thy name also.
verse 7 Because they Iacob have devour'd:
his habitation
they also wondrously have brought
to desolation.
verse 8 Minde not against us former sins,
let thy mercies make hast
us to prevent: because we are
neere utterly layd waste.
verse 9 God of our safety, help thou us
for thy names glory make,
us free also, & purge away
our sin for thy names sake.
verse 10 Why say the heathen where's their God?
with heathen let be knowne
before our eyes, the vengeance of
thy servants bloud out flowne.
verse 11 Before thee let the prisoners sighs
come up, accordingly
as is thy mighty arme: save those
that are design'd to dye,
verse 12 And to our neighbours seven fold,
into their bosome pay,
that their reproach, with which o Lord,
reproached thee h • ve th • y.

verse 13 S •
• e thy folk & p • sture sheep •
▪
will give thee th • n • s 〈◊〉

〈◊〉 unto generations 〈◊〉
▪
wee will shew forth thy 〈◊〉

div.head: Psalme • 0 To • he c • ief musici • n upon 〈◊〉 F • du • h, a psalme of As •• h.

lg.l: that Ioseph leadst about
like as a •• ock: that dwelst betweene
the Cherubims, shine out.
verse 2 Before Ephr •• m & Benjamin,
Manasseh s • ribe also,
doe thou stir up thy strength, & come,
and to us safety show.
verse 3 O God returne thou us againe,
and cause thy countenance
to shine forth upon us; so wee
shall have deliverance.
verse 4 Lord God of hoasts, how long wilt thou
be wroth at thy folks prayrs?
verse 5 Thou feedst with bread of tears, & them
to drink giv'st many teares.
verse 6 A strife unto our neighbours us
thou dost also expose:
and scornefully amongst themselves
laugh at us doe our foes.
verse 7 O God of hoasts, turne us againe,
& cause thy countenance
to shine forth upon us, so wee
shall have deliverance.
verse 8 Thou hast brought out of Egipt land
a Vine, thou diddest cast
the heathen people forth, also
this vine thou planted hast.
verse 9 Bef • re it thou prepared hast
a roome where it might stand:
deep root thou didst cause it to take
and it did fill the land.
verse 10 Her s • ade hid hills, & her boughs did
like Cedars great extend.
verse 11 Her boughs to th'sea, & her branch • s
she to the floud did send.
verse 12 Why hast thou then her hedg •• mad •
quite broken downe to lye,
so that all those doe pluck at her
that in the way passe by?
verse 13 Th • Boare from out the wood he doth
by wasting it annoy:
& wilde beasts of the field doe i •
devouringly destroy.
verse 14 Wee doe beseech thee to returne
o God of hoasts, incline
to look from heaven, & behould,
& visit thou this vine.
verse 15 The vineyard which thou hast also
with thy right hand set fast,
that branch likewise which for thy self •
strongly confirm'd thou hast.
verse 16 It is consumed with the fire
and utterly cut downe,
perish they doe, & that because
thy countenance doth frowne.
verse 17 Vpon the man of thy right hand
let thine hand present bee:
upon the son of man whom thou
hast made so strong for thee
verse 18 So then from henceforth wee will not
from thee goe back at all:
o doe thou quick • n us, & wee
upon thy name will call.
verse 19 Lord God of hoasts, turne us againe,
and cause thy countenance
to shine forth upon us, so wee
shall have deliverance.

div.head: Psalme 81 To the chi • fe musician upon Gi • ti • h, a psalme of Asaph.

lg.l: SIng unto God who is our strength,
and that with a loud voyce:
unto him that is Iacobs God
make yee a joyfull noyse.
verse 2 Take up a psalme of melodie,
and bring the Timbrel hither:
the Harp which soundes so pleasantly
with Psaltery together.
verse 3 As in the time of the new moone
with Trumpet sound on high:
in the appoynted time & day
of our solemnity.
verse 4 Because that unto Israell
this thing a statute was;
and by the God of Iacob this
did for a judgement pass.
verse 5 This witnesse he in Ioseph set
when as through Egipt land
he went: I there a language heard
I did not understand.
verse 6 I from the burden which he bare
his shoulder did set free:
his hands also were from the pots
deli • ered by mee.
verse 7 Thou cal'dst in streights, & I thee freed:
in thunders secret way
I answred thee, I prov'd thee at
waters of Meribah. Selah.
verse 8 Heare o my people, & I will
testifie unto • hee:
o Israell, if that thou wilt
attention give to mee.
verse 9 Any strange god there shall not be
in midst of thee at all:
nor unto any forrein god
thou bowing downe shalt fall.
verse 10 I am the Lord thy God who thee
from land of Egipt led:
thy mouth ope wide, & thou by me •
with plenty shalt be fed.
verse 11 My people yet would not give eare
unto the voyce I spake:
and Israell would not in mee▪
quiet contentment take.
verse 12 So in the hardnes of their heart▪
I did them send away,
in their owne consultations
likewise then walked they.
verse 13 O that my people unto mee
obedient had bin:
and o that Israell he had
walked my wayes within.
verse 14 I should within a little time
have pulled downe their foes:
I should have turn'd my hand upon
such as did them oppose.
verse 15 The haters of the Lord to him
obedience should have faynd:
but unto perpetuity
their time should have remaind.
verse 16 And with the finest of the wheat
have nourisht them should hee:
with honie of the rock I should
have satisfied thee.
THe mighty God doth stand within
th'assemblie of the strong:
and he it is that righteously
doth judge the gods among.
verse 2 How long a time is it that yee
will judge unrighteouslie?
& will accept the countenance
of those that wicked bee?
verse 3 See that yee doe defend the poore,
also the fatherlesse:
unto the needy justice doe,
and that are in distresse.
verse 4 The wasted poore, & those that are
needy deliver yee;
and them redeeme out of the hand
of such as wicked bee.
verse 5 They know not, nor will understand,
in darknes they walk on:
all the foundations of the earth
quite out of course are gone.
verse 6 I sayd that yee are gods, & sonnes
of th'highest yee are all.
verse 7 But yee shall dye like men, & like
one of the princes fall.
verse 8 That thou mayst judge the earth o God,
doe thou thy selfe advance;
for thou shalt have the nations
for thine inheritance.

div.head: Psalme 83 A psalme or song of Asaph,

lg.l: O GOD, doe not thou silence keep:
o doe not thou refraine
thy selfe from speaking, & o God.
doe not thou dumb remaine.
verse 2 For loe, thine enemies that be
doe rage tumultuously:
& they that haters be of thee
have lift the head on hye.
verse 3 Against those that thy people be
they crafty counsell take;
also against thy hidden ones
they consultation make.
verse 4 They sayd, lest they a nation be,
let's cut them downe therefore,
that in remembrance Isr'elss name
may not be any more.
verse 5 For they together taken have
counsell with one consent,
and in confederation
against thee they are bent.
verse 6 The tabernacles of Edom
and of the Ishmaelites:
the people of the Haggarens
& of the Moabites.
verse 7 The men of Gebal, with Ammon,
and Amaleck conspire,
the Philistims, with them that be
inhabitants of Tyre.
verse 8 Assyria morover is
conjoyned unto them:
& help they have administred
unto Lots childerren.
verse 9 As thou didst to the Middianites,
so to them be it done:
as unto Sisera & Iabin
at the Brook of Kison
verse 10 Who neere to Endor suddenly
were quite discomfited:
who also did become as dung
that on the earth is spred.
verse 11 Like unto Oreb, & like Zeeb
make thou their Nobles fall,
yea, as Zeba & Zalmunna
make thou their Princes all.
verse 12 Who sayd, for our possession
Gods houses let us take.
verse 13 My God, thou like a wheel, like straw
before the winde them make.
verse 14 As fire doth burne a wood, & as
the flame sets hills on fire:
verse 15 So with thy tempest them pursue,
& fright them in thine ire.
verse 16 Doe thou their faces all fill full
of ignominious shame:
that so they may o Lord, be made
to seek after thy name.
verse 17 Confounded let them ever be,
and terriblie troubled:
yea, let them be put unto shame,
and bee extinguished.
verse 18 That men m • y know; that thou whose name
IEHOVAH is only,
art over all the earth throughout
advanc • d the most high.

div.head: Psalme 84 To the chief musician upon Gittith a psalm for the sonnes of Kor • h.

lg.l: HOw amiable Lord of hoasts
thy tabernacles bee?
verse 2 My soule longs for Iehovahs courts,
yea it ev'n faints in mee.
Mine heart, my flesh also cryes out
after the living God:
verse 3 Yea ev'n the sparrow hath found out
an house for hir abo • d.
Also the swallow findes her nest
thine Altars neere unto
where shee her young layes: Lord of hoasts,
my King, my God also.
verse 4 Blest they that dwell within thy house:
still they will give thee prayse. Selah.
verse 5 Blest is the man whose strength's in thee,
in whose heart • re their wayes.
verse 6 Who as they passe through Baca's Vale
doe make it a fountaine:
also the pooles that are therin
are filled full of raine:
verse 7 From strength to strength they go: to God
in Sion all appeare.
verse 8 Lord God of hoasts, o heare my pra'yr,
o Iacobs God, give eare. Selah.
verse 9 Behould o God our shield: the face
of thine annoynted see.
verse 10 For better's in thy courts a day,
then elswhere thousands bee:
I rather had a doore-keeper
be it'h house of my God:
then in the tents of wickednes
to settle mine aboad.
verse 11 Because the Lord God is a Sun,
he is a shield also:
Iehovah on his people grace
and glory will bestow:
No good thing will he hould from them
that doe walk uprightlee.
verse 12 O Lord of hoasts, the man is blest
that puts his trust in thee.

div.head: Psalme 85 To the chiefe musician, a psalme for the sonnes of Korah.

lg.l: O LORD, thou hast been to the land
gracious: Iacobs captiuity
thou hast returned with thy hand.
verse 2 Thou also the iniquity
of thy people hast pardoned:
thou all their sin hast covered. Selah.
verse 3 Thou all thine anger didst withdraw:
from thy fierce indignation
thou hast thy selfe turned away.
verse 4 O God of our salvation
convert thou us; & doe thou make
thine anger toward us to slake.
verse 5 Shall thy wrath ever be us on?
wilt thou thine indignation
draw out to generation?
and unto generation?
verse 6 Wilt thou not us reviv'd let bee,
that thy folk may rejoyce in thee.
verse 7 Lord on us shew thy mercy; eke
thy saving health on us bestow.
verse 8 I'le hark what God the Lord will speak,
for hee'l speak peace his folk unto,
and to his Saints: but let not them
to foolishnes returne agen.
verse 9 Surelyhis saving health is nigh
unto all them that doe him feare;
that in our land may dwell glory.
verse 10 Mercy & truth met together,
prosperity & righteousnes

embracing did each othe •
kiss.
verse 11 Truth springs out of the earth: also
from heaven looketh righteousn • s.
verse 12 Yea, God shall that that's good b • stow;
our land eke shall give her increase.
verse 13 Iustice shall goe before his face,
& in the way her steps shall place.

lg.head: Another of the same
lg.l: O LORD, thou favour'd hast thy land:
Iacobs captivity.
verse 2 Thou hast brought back: thou pard'ned hast
thy folks iniquity:
Thou hast close coverd all thei • sin.
verse 3 Thy wrath away all cast
thou hast: from fiercenes of thine ire

thy selfe return'd thou has •
▪
verse 4 Convert us back, o thou the God
of our salvation:
& toward us cause t • ou to cease.
thi • e indignation
verse 5 Wilt thou be angry s • ill with us
for evermore? what shall?
thine anger be by the • drawne-out
to generations all?
verse 6 Wilt thou not us revive? in thee
thy folk rejoyce shall so.
verse 7 Shew us thy mercy, Lord; on us
thy saving health bestow.
verse 8 I'le heare what God the Lord will speak:
for to his people peace
hee'l speak; & to his Saints: lest they
returne to foolishnes.
verse 9 Surely naere them that doe him fear •
is his salvation:
that glory may within our land
have habitation.
verse 10 Mercy & truth doe joyntly meet:
justice & peace doe kisse.
verse 11 Truth springs from earth▪ & rightousnes
from heaven looking is.
verse 12 Yea what is good the Lord shall give:
and yeild her fruit our land.
verse 13 Iustice shall 'fore him goe: & make
her steps i'th way to stand.
BOw downe o Lord, thine eare,
& harken unto mee:
because that I afflicted am,
also I am needie.
verse 2 Doe thou preserve my soule,
for gracious am I:
o thou my God, thy servant save,
that doth on thee rely.
verse 3 Lord pitty me, for I
cry daily thee unto.
verse 4 Rejoyce thy servants soule: for Lord,
to thee mine lift I do.
verse 5 For thou o Lord, art good,
to pardon prone withall:
and to them all in mercy rich
that doe upon thee call.
verse 6 Iehovah, o doe thou
give eare my pray'r unto:
& of my supplications
attend the voyce also.
verse 7 In day of my distresse,
to thee I will complaine:
by reason that thou unto mee
wilt answer give againe.
verse 8 Amongst the gods, o Lord,
none is there like to thee:
neither with thine are any works
that may compared bee.
verse 9 All nations o Lord,
whom thou hast made, the same
shall come & worship thee before:
and glorify thy Name.
verse 10 Because thou mighty art,
the things that thou hast done
are wonderfull, thou art thy selfe
the mighty God alone.
verse 11 Iehovah, unto mee
o make thy way appeare,
walk in thy truth I will; mine heart
unite thy name to feare.
verse 12 Withall mine heart I will
o Lord my God, thee prayse:
& I will glorify thy name,
for evermore alwayes.
verse 13 Because that unto mee
thy mercy doth excell;
also thou hast delivered
my soule from lowest hell.
verse 14 O God, the proud, & troups
of violent rose 'gainst mee,
after my soule they sought: nor have
before them placed thee.
verse 15 But Lord thou art a God,
tender, & gracious;
longsuffring, & in mercy thou
& truth art plenteous.
verse 16 O turne thou unto mee,
and mercy on mee have:
unto thy servant give thy strength:
thine handmaides son do save.
verse 17 Mee shew a signe for good,
that mine haters may see,
and be asham'd; because Lord, thou
dost help, & comfort mee.

div.head: Psalme 87 A psalme or song for the sonnes of Korah.
div.l: AMong the holy hills
is his foundation.
verse 2 More then all Iacobs tents, the Lord
loves the gates of Sion.
verse 3 Things glorious spoken are
o Gods citty, of thee. Selah.
verse 4 I'le mention Rahab, & Babel,
to them that doe know mee;
Behold Philistia,
Tyrus citty likewise,
with Ethiopia; that this man
by birth did thence arise.
verse 5 Also it shall be sayd,
of Sion that borne there
this & that man was, & the high'st
himselfe shall stablish her.
verse 6 Iehovah he shall co unt,
ev'n at that time when as,
the people he doth number up,
that there this man borne was. Selah
verse 7 Both those that singers are
as also there shall bee,
those that on instruments doe play:
all my springs are in thee.

div.head: Psalme 88 A song or psalme for the sons of Korah, to the chief musician upō Mahalath Leannoth, Maschil of Heman the Ezrahite.

lg.l: LORD God of my salvation,
before thee day & night cryde I.
verse 2 Before thee o let my pray'r come:
incline thine eare unto my cry.
verse 3 Because my soule is troubled so:
and my life draws nigh to the grave.
verse 4 Counted with them to'th pit that go:
I'me as a man that no strength have.
verse 5 Free among those men that be dead,
like slaine which in the grave are shut;
by thee noe more remembered:
and by thy hand off are they cut.
verse 6 Thou hast mee layd i'th pit most low
in dakrnesses, within deep caves.
verse 7 Hard on mee lyes thy wrath, & thou
dost mee afflict with all thy waves. Selah·
verse 8 Men that of mine acquaintance bee
thou hast put far away mee fro:
unto them loathsome thou madst mee,
I am shut up nor forth can go.
verse 9 Because of mine affliction,
mine eye with mourning pines away:
Iehovah, I call thee upon:
& stretch my hands to thee all day;
verse 10 Shew wonders to the dead wilt thou?
shall dead arise & thee confess? Selah.
verse 11 I'th grave wilt thou thy kindenes show?
in lost estate thy faithfullnes?
verse 12 Thy works that wonderfull have been
within the dark shall they be knowne?
& shall thy righteousnes be seene
in the land of oblivion?
verse 13 But Lord I have cryde thee unto
at morne, my pray'r prevent shall thee.
verse 14 Lord why casts thou my soule thee fro?
why hidest thou thy face from mee?
verse 15 I'me poore afflicted, & to dye
am ready, from my youthfull yeares,
I am sore troubled doubtfully
while I doe beare thy horrid feares.
verse 16 Thy fierce wrath over mee doth goe,
thy terrors they doe mee dismay.
verse 17 Encompasse mee about they doe,
close mee together all the day.
verse 18 Lover & friend a far thou hast
removed off aw • y from mee,
& mine acquaintance thou hast cast
into darksom obscurite • .

div.head: Psalme 89 Maschil of Ethan the Ezrahite.

lg.l: THe mercyes of Iehovah sing
for evermore will I:
I'le with my mouth thy truth make known
to all posterity.
verse 2 For I have sayd that mercy shall
for ever be up built;
establish in the very heav'ns
thy faithfullnes thou wilt.
verse 3 With him that is my chosen one
I made a covenant:
& by an oath have sworne unto
David mine owne servant.
verse 4 To perpetuity thy seed
establish-sure I will:
also to generations all
thy throne I'le build up still. Selah.
verse 5 Also the heav • ns thy wonders Lord,
they shall with prayse confess;
in the ass • mblie of the Saints▪
also thy faithfullnes.
verse 6 For who can be compar'd unto
t • e Lord the heav'ns within?
'mong sonnes of mighty to the Lord
who is't that's like to him.
verse 7 I'th Saints assemblie greatly God
is to be had in feare:
• nd to be reverenc't of all those
that round about him are.
verse 8 Lord God of hoasts, what Lord like thee
in power doth abide?
thy faithfullnes doth compasse thee
also on every side.
verse 9 Over the raging of the sea,
thou dost dominion beare:
when as the waves therof arise,
by thee they stilled are.
verse 10 Like to one slaine, thou broken hast
in pieces Rahab quite:
thou hast disperst thine enemies
ev'n by thine arme of might.
verse 11 The heav'ns together with the earth,
thine are they: thine they bee;
the world, with fullnes of the same,
founded they were by thee.
verse 12 The North together with the South
thou didst create the same:
Tabor together with Hermon,
rejoyce shall in thy Name.
verse 13 Thou hast a very mighty arme,
thy hand it is mighty,
and also thy right hand it is
exalted up on high.
verse 14 Iustice & judgement of thy th • one
are the prepared place:
mercy & truth preventing shall
goe forth before thy face.
verse 15 O blessed are the people that
the joyfull sound doe know,
Lord, in thy countenances light
they up & downe shall goe:
verse 16 They shall in thy name all the day
rejoyce exceedingly:
and in thy righteousnes they shall
be lifted up on high.
verse 17 Because that thou art unto them
the glory of their powre:
our horne shall be exalted high,
also in thy favour.
verse 18 Because Iehovah is to us
a safe protection;
and he that is our Soveraigne,
is Isr'ells Holy-one.
verse 19 Then didst thou speake in vision,
unto thy Saint, & sayd,
I upon one that mighty is
salvation have layd:
One from the folk chose, I set up.
verse 20 David my servant I
have found: him I annoynted with
mine oyle of sanctity.
verse 21 With whom my hand shall stablisht be▪
mine arme him strengthen shall.
verse 22 Also the enemy shall not
exact on him at all:
Nor shall the Son of wickednes
afflict him any more.
verse 23 Be • ore him I'le beat downe his foes,
and plague his haters sore.
verse 24 My mercy, truth, shall be with him;
& in my name shall be
verse 25 his horne exalted. And I'le s • t
• is hand upon the sea:
I'th rivers also his right hand.
verse 26 He shall cry mee unto,
thou art m • Father: & my God,
Rock of my health also.
verse 27 Also I will make him to be
my first begotten one:
higher then those that Princes are,
who dwell the earth upon.
verse 28 My mercy I will keep for him
to times which ever last:
also my covenant with him
it s •• ll stand very fast.
verse 29 And I will make his s • ed indu • e
to perpetuitee:
his throne likewise it like unto
the dayes of heav'n shall b • e.
verse 30 If that his sons forsake my l • w,
& from my judgements swerve:
verse 31 If they my stattutes break, & my
comm • ndes doe not observe:
verse 32 Then will I visit with the rod
their bold transgression,
as also their iniquity
with sore stripes them upon.
verse 33 But y • t my loving kindenes, it
I'le not tak • utterly
away from him: nor will suffer
my faithfullnes to lye.
verse 34 The covenant I made with him
by mee shall not be broke:
neither will I alter the thing
which by my lips is spoke.
verse 35 Once sware I by my holines,
if I to David lye:
verse 36 His seed afutedly shall last
to perpetuity:
And like the Sun 'fore mee his throne.
verse 37 It like t • e moone for aye
shall be establish't, like a true
witnesse in heav'n: Selah.
verse 38 But thou hast cast off, & us had
in detestation:
exceedingly thou hast been wroth
with thine annoynted one.
verse 39 Thou hast made voyd the covenant
of thy servant, his crowne
thou hast prophan'd unto the ground
by casting of it downe.
verse 40 Thou hast broke all his hedges downe:
his forts thou ruin'd hast.
verse 41 All those doe make a spoyle of him
who by the way have past:
Hee's a reproach to his neighbours.
verse 42 Of them that him annoy
thou hast advanced their right hand:
& made all's foes to joy▪
verse 43 The sharp edge also of hi • sword
thou hast turn'd backward qui • e:
and in the battell thou hast not
made him to stand upright.
verse 44 Thou hast made also for to cease
his glorious renowne:
unto the very earth his throne
thou also hast c • st downe.
verse 45 And of his youthfull yeares the dayes
thou hast diminished;
with very great confusion
thou hast him covered. Selah.
verse 46 How long? Iehovah, wilt thou hide
thy selfe for evermore?
burne like unto consuming fire
shall thy displeasure sore?
verse 47 To thy remembrance doe thou call
how short a time have I;
wherefore hast thou created all
mens sonnes to vanity?
verse 48 What strong man is there that doth live,
& death shall never see?
from the strong power of the grave
shall he his soule set free?
verse 49 Thy former loving kindenesses
o Lord, where are they now?
which in thy truth & faithfullnes
to David thou didst vow.
verse 50 Lord, the reproach of thy servants
unto remembrance call:
how I it beare in my bosome
from mighty people all.
verse 51 Wherewith thy adversaryes Lord,
have cast r • proach upon,
wherewith they have reproacht the steps
of thine annointed one.
verse 52 O let Iehovah be blessed
to all eternitee:
Amen, so let it be, also
Amen, so it shall bee.

div.head: Psalme 90. A prayer of Moses the man of God.

lg.l: O LORD, thou hast been unto us
from generation,
to generation, a place
of fixed mansion.
verse 2 Before the mountaines were brought forth,
ere earth & world by thee
were form'd: thou art eternally
God to eternite • .
verse 3 Thou dost unto destruction
turne miserable men:
and then thou sayst yee sonnes of men
doe yee returne agen.
verse 4 For why o Lord, a thousand yeares
are but within thy sight
as yesterday when it is past:
and as a watch by night.
verse 5 By thee like as it were a flood
they quite away are borne,
they like a sleep, & as the grasse
that grows up in the morne.
verse 6 It in the morning flourisheth,
it also up doth grow;
it in the ev'ning is cut downe
it withereth also.
verse 7 Because wee by thine anger are
consumed speedily:
and by thy sore displeasure wee
are troubled suddenly.
verse 8 Thou hast set our iniq ••• yes
before thee in thy fight:
our secret evills are within
thy countenances light.
verse 9 Because in thine exceeding wrath
our dayes all passe aw • y:
our years wee have consumed quite,
ev'n as a tale are they.
verse 10 Threescore & ten yeares are the dayes
of our yeares which remaine,
& if through strength they fourscore be,
their strength is grief & paine:
For it's cut off soone, & wee flye
verse 11 away: Who is't doth know
thine angers strength? according as
thy feare, thy wrath is so.
verse 12 Teach us to count our dayes: our hearts
so wee'l on wisdome set.
verse 13 Turne Lord, how long? of thy servants
let it repent thee yet?
verse 14 O give us satisfaction
betimes with thy mercee:
that so rejoyce, & be right glad,
through all our dayes may wee.
verse 15 According to the dayes wherin
affliction wee have had,
and yeares wherin wee have seen ill,
now also make us glad.
verse 16 Vnto those that thy servants be
doe thou thy work declare:
also thy comely glory to
those that thy children are.
verse 17 Let our Gods beauty be on us,
our handy works also
stablish on us; our handy work
establish it doe thou.
HE that within the secret place
of the most high doth dwell,
he und • r the Almightyes shade
shall lodge himselfe full well.
verse 2 My hope he is, & my fortresse,
I to the Lord will say:
he is my God; & I in him
my confidence will stay.
verse 3 Surely out of the fowlers snare
he shall deliver thee,
also thee from the Pestilence
infectious s • all free.
verse 4 He with his feathers hide thee shall,
under his wings shall bee
thy trust: his truth shall be a shield
and buckler unto thee.
verse 5 Thou shalt not • e dismaide with feare
for terrour by the night:
nor for the arrow that with speed
flyeth in the day light:
verse 6 Nor for the Pestilence that doth
walk in the darknes fast:
nor for the sore destruction
that doth at noone day wast.
verse 7 A thousand shall fall at thy side,
& ten thousand also
at thy right hand, but it shall not
approach thee neere unto:
verse 8 Only thou with thine eyes this thing
attentively shalt view:
also thou shalt behold how that
the wicked have their due.
verse 9 Because Iehovah who hath been
my safe protection,
ev'n the most high, thou h • st him made
thine habitation.
verse 10 Not any thing that evill is
there shall to thee b • fall,
neither shall any plague come nigh
thy dwelling place at all.
verse 11 Because th • t he his Angells will
command concerning thee:
in all thy wayes where thou dost walk
thy keeper for to bee.
verse 12 They shall support thee in their hands:
lest thou against a stone
verse 13 shouldst dash thy foot. Thou trample shalt
on th'Adder, & Lion:
The Lion young & Dragon thou
shalt tread under thy feet.
verse 14 I will deliver him, for hee
on mee his love hath set:
Because that he hath knowne my Name,
I will him set on high.
verse 15 Vpon mee he shall call in pray'r,
and answer him will I:
I will be with him when he is
in troublesome distresse,
& I to him will honour give,
when I shall him release.
verse 16 Wi • h dayes of long continuance
I'le give to him his fill:
& also my salvation
decl • re to him I will.

div.head: Psalme 92. A ps • lme or song for the Sabbath day.

lg.l: IT is a good thing to give thanks
Iehovah thee un • o:
unto thy Name prayses to sing,
o thou most high also.
verse 2 Thy loving kind • nes to shew forth
within the morning light▪
also thy truth, & faithfullnes,
to shew forth every night.
verse 3 Vpon a ten string'd instrument,
and Psaltery upon:
upon the solemne sounding Harp,
a meditation.
verse 4 For through thy work, o Lord, thou hast
mee caused to rejoyce:
and in the workings of thy hands
I will triumph with voyce.
verse 5 O Lord, how mighty are thy works:
thy thoughts are very deepe.
verse 6 The bruitish knows not; nor the foole
this in his heart doth keepe.
verse 7 When as the wicked doe spring-up
ev'n like the grasse unto,
& all that work iniquity
when as they flourish do:
It's that they then may be destroy'd
to perpetuity.
verse 8 But thou Iehovah dost abide
for evermore most high.
verse 9 For loe, thy foes, for loe, o Lord,
thy foes they perish shall:
the workers of iniquity
they shall be scattred all.
verse 10 But like the Vnicornes my horne
thou shalt exalt on high:
& • ith fresh oyle in mine old age
annoynted be shall I.
verse 11 Also mine eye shall see my wish
upon mine enemyes:
mine eare shall heare of wicked ones,
that up against me rise.
verse 12 Like to the Palme tree▪ flourish shall
he that is righteous:
like to a Ceadar he shall grow
that is in Lebanus.
verse 13 They that within Iehovahs house
are planted stedfastly:
within the Courts of our God they
shall flourish pleasantly
verse 14 Their fruit they shall in their old age
continue forth to bring:
they shall be fat, yea likewise they
shall still be flourishing:
verse 15 To shew that upright is the Lord:
my refuge strong is hee,
also that there is not in him
any iniquitee.

div.head: Psalme 93.
div.l: THe Lord reigns, cloth'd with majesty:
God cloath'd with strength, doth gird
himselfe: the world so stablisht is,
that it cannot be stir'd.
verse 2 Thy throne is stablished of old:
verse 3 from aye thou art. Their voyce
the flouds lift up, Lord, flouds lift up,
the flouds lift up their noyse.
verse 4 The Lord on high then waters noyse
more strong then waves of sea:
verse 5 T • y words most sure: Lord, holines
becomes thine house for aye.

lg.l: O LORD God, unto whom there doe
revenges appertaine:
o God, to whom vengeance belongs,
clearly shine forth againe.
verse 2 Exalt thy selfe, o thou that art
Iudge of the earth throughout:
render a recompence unto
all those that are so stout.
verse 3 Iehovah, o how long shall they
th • t doe walk wickedly?
how long shall those that wicked are
rejoyce triumphingly?
verse 4 How long shall those men utter forth
& speake things that hard bee?
& shall all such thus boast themselve •
that work iniquitee?
verse 5 Lord, they thy folk in pieces break:
& h • ri •• ge oppress.
verse 6 They sl • y the widdow' & stranger,
& kill the fatherless.
verse 7 Th • Lord they say, yet shall not see:
nor Iacobs God it minde.
verse 8 Learne vulg • r So • s: also yee fooles
when will yee wisdome finde?
verse 9 Who pl • n • s the eare, sh • ll he not heare?
who f • rmes the eye, not see?
verse 10 Who heathen smites, shall he not check?
mans teacher, knows not hee?
verse 11 The Lord doth know the thoughts of man,
that they are very vaine.
verse 12 Blest man whom thou correctst, o Lord;
& in thy law dost traine.
verse 13 That thou mayst give him quiet from
dayes of adversity:
untill the pit be digged for
such as doe wickedly.
verse 14 Because Iehovah he will not
his people cast away,
neither will hee forsake his owne
inheritance for aye.
verse 15 But judgement unto righteousnes
it shall returne agen:
also all upright ones in heart
they shall pursue it then.
verse 16 Against the evill doers, who
will up for mee arise?
who will stand up for mee 'gainst them
that work iniquityes?
verse 17 Had not the Lord me helpt: my soule
had neere in sil • nce dwel'd.
verse 18 When a • I sayd, my foot slips: Lord,
thy mercy mee upheld.
verse 19 Amidst the multitude of thoug • ts
of mine within my minde,
still from thy consolations
my soule delight doth finde.
verse 20 Shall the throne of iniquity
have fellowship with thee:
which frameth molestation
and that by a decree?
verse 21 They joyntly gathered themselves,
together they withstood
the soule of him that righteous is:
& condemne guiltlesse blood.
verse 22 But yet Iehovah unto mee
he is a refuge high:
also my God he is the rock
of my hopefull safety.
verse 23 Their mischief on them he shall bring,
& in their wickedness
he shall them cut off: yea, the Lord
our God shall them suppress.

div.head: Psalme 95.
div.l: O Come, let us unto the Lord
shout loud with singing voyce.
to the rock of our saving health
let's make a joyfull noyse.
verse 2 Before his presence let us then
approach with thanksgiving:
also let us triumphantly
with Psalmes unto him sing.
verse 3 For the Lord a great God & great
King above all gods is.
verse 4 In whose hands are deepes of the earth,
& strength of hills are his
verse 5 The sea to him doth appertaine,
also he made the same:
& also the drye land is his
for it his hands did f • ame.
verse 6 O come, & let us worship give,
& bowing downe adore:
he that our maker is, the Lord
o let us kneele before.
verse 7 Because he is our God, & wee
his pasture people are,
& of his hands the sheep: to da •
if yee his voyce will heare,
verse 8 As in the provocation,
o harden not your heart:
as in day of temptation,
within the vast desart.
verse 9 Whē mee your fathers tryde, & pro'vd,
& my works lookt upon:
verse 10 Fourty yeares long I griev'd was with
this generation:
And sayd, this people erre in heart:
my wayes they doe not know.
verse 11 To whom I sware in wrath: if they
into my rest should goe.

lg.l: SIng to the Lord a new song: sing
all th'earth the Lord unto:
verse 2 Sing to Iehovah▪ blesse his Name,
still his salvation show.
verse 3 To'th heathen his glory, to all
people his wonders spread.
verse 4 For great's the Lord, much to be prays'd,
above all gods in dread.
verse 5 Because vaine Idols are they all
which heathens Gods doe name:
but yet Iehovah he it is
that did the heavens frame.
verse 6 Honour & comely majesty
abide before his face:
both fortitude & beauty are
within his holy place.
verse 7 Yee kindreds of the people all
unto the Lord afford,
glory & mightynes also
give yee unto the Lord.
verse 8 The glory due unto his name
give yee the Lord unto;
offer yee an oblation,
enter his courts also.
verse 9 In beauty of his holynes
doe yee the Lord adore:
the universall earth likewise
in feare stand him before.
verse 10 'Mong heathens say, Iehovah reigns:
the world instablenes
shall be, unmov'd also: he shall
judge fo • k in righteousnes.
verse 11 O let the heav'ns ther at b • glad,
& let the earth rejoyce:
o let the sea, & •• 's fullnes
with roaring make a noyse.
verse 12 O let the field be full of joye,
& all thi • gs there about:

then all th •
〈◊〉 that be i'th wood
they joyfully shall shout
verse 13 Before Iehovah, for he comes,
he comes earths judge to bee:
the world with justice, & the folke
judge with his truth shall hee.

div.head: Psalme 97▪
div.l: THe Lord doth reigne, the earth
o let heerat rejoyce:
the many Isles with mirth
let them lift up their voyce.
verse 2 About him round
dark clouds there went,
right & judgement
his throne doe found.
verse 3 Before him fire doth goe,
& burnes his foes about.
verse 4 The world was light also
by lightnings he sent out:
the earth it saw
& it trembled.
verse 5 The hills melted
like wax away
At presence of the Lord:
at his presence who is
of all the earth the Lord.
verse 6 That righteousnes of his
the heavens high
they doe forth show:
all folk also
see his glory.
verse 7 Who graven Images
doe serve, on them remaine
let dreadfull shamefullnes:
& who in Idols vaine
themselves doe boast;
with worship bow
to him all you
Gods Angells hoast.
verse 8 Sion heard, & was glad,
glad Iudahs daughters were,
this cause, o Lord, they had,
thy judgements did appeare.
verse 9 For Lord thou high
all earth set o're:
all Gods before
in dignity.
verse 10 Yet that doe love the Lord,
the evill hate doe yee;
to his Saints soules afford
protection doth hee:
he will for them
freedome command
out of the hand
of wicked men.
verse 11 For men that righteous are
surely there is sowne light:
& gladnes for their share
that are in heart up • ight.
verse 12 Ioy in the Lord,
yee Iust confesse;
his holynesse
while yee record.

div.head: Psalme 98. A Psalme
div.l: A New song sing unto the Lord,
for wonders he hath done:
his right hand & his holy arme
him victory hath wonne.
verse 2 Iehovah his salvation
hath made for to be knowne:
his righteousnes i'th heathens sight
hee openly hath showne.
verse 3 To Isr'ells house of his mercy
& truth hath mindefull been:
the ends of all the earth they have
our Gods salvation seene.
verse 4 Vnto Iehovah all the earth,
make yee a joyfull noyse:
make yee also a cheerfull sound,
sing prayse, likewise rejoyce.
verse 5 With Harp sing to the Lord; with Harp,
also with a Psalms voyce.
verse 6 With Trumpets, Cornets sound; before
the Lord the King rejoyce.
verse 7 The sea let with her fullnes roare:
the world, & there who dwell.
verse 8 O let the flouds clap hands: let hills
rejoyce together well
verse 9 Before the Lord, for he doth come
to judge the earth: rightly
with justice shall he judge the world,
& folk with equity.

div.head: Psalme 99.
div.l: IEHOVAH 'tis that reigns,
let people be in dread:
'midst Cherubs he remaines,
th'earth let itbe moved.
verse 2 Iehovah is
in Sion great,
in highnes set
he is likewise
Above all the people.
verse 3 Let them confesse thy Name
so great & terrible:
for holy is the same.
verse 4 The King his might
doth love justice:
thou dost stablish
things that be right:
Iudgement thou dost, also
in Iacob righteousnes.
verse 5 The Lord our God doe you
set up in his highnes,
& worship yee
his footstoole at:
by reason that
holy is hee.
verse 6 Moses also Aron
among his Priests, likewise
Samuell all those among
that to his name send cryes:
called they have
the Lord upon,
and be alone
them answer gave.
verse 7 He un • o them • id speake
it'h cloudy pillar: then
they kept his records, eke
his ord'nance he gave them.
verse 6 Lord, thou who art
our God didst heare,
& di • st answer
to them impart,
Thou wast a • od pard'ning
them, although thou vengeance
upon their works didst bring.
verse 9 The Lord our God advance,
& bow yee dow • e
at's holy hill:
for our God's still
th • Holy-one.

lg.l: MAke yee a joyfull sounding noyse
unto Iehovah, all the earth.
verse 2 Serve yee Iehovah with gladnes:
before his presence come with mirth.
verse 3 Know, that Iehovah he is God,
who hath us formed it is hee,
& not our selves: his owne people
& sheepe of his pasture are wee.
verse 4 Enter into his gates with prayse,
into his Courts with thankf • llnes:
make yee confession unto him,
& his name reverently blesse.
verse 5 Because Iehovah he is good,
for evermore is his mercy:
& unto generations all
continue doth his verity.

lg.head: Another of the same.
lg.l: MAke yee a joyfull noyse unto
Iehovah all the earth:
verse 2 Serve yee Iehovah with gladnes:
before him come with mirth.
verse 3 Know, that Iehovah he is God,
not wee our selves, but hee
hath made us: his people, & sheep
of his pasture are wee.
verse 4 O enter yee into his gates
wi • h prayse, & thankfullnesse
into his Courts: confesse to him,
& his Name doe yee b • esse.
verse 5 Because Iehovah he is good,
his bounteous-mercy
is everlasting: & his truth
is to eter • ity.

div.head: Psalme 101. A psalme of David.
div.l: MErcy & judgement I will sing,
Lo • d, I will sing to thee.
verse 2 I'le wisely doe in perfect way:
when wilt thou come to mee?
I will in midst of my house walk
in my hearts perfect •• s:
verse 3 I will not set before mine eyes
matter of wi • kednes:
I hate their worke that turne aside,
it shall not cleave m • e to.
verse 4 Froward in heart from mee shall part,
none evill will I know.
verse 5 I'le cut him off, that slaundereth
his neighbour privily:
I cannot beare the proud in hearr,
nor him that looketh high.
verse 6 Vpon the faithfull in the land
mine eyes shall be, that they
may dwell with mee: he shall mee serve
that walks in perfect way.
verse 7 Hee that a worker is of guile,
shall not in my house dwell:
before mine eyes he shall not be
setled, that lies doth tell.
verse 8 Yea, all the wicked of the land
early destroy will I:
to cutt off from Gods citty all
that work iniquity.

div.head: Psalme 102 A prayer of the afflicted when he is overwhelmed, & poureth out his complaint before the Lord.

lg.l: LORD, heare my supplication,
& let my cry come thee unto:
verse 2 I'th day when trouble is on mee
thy face hide not away mee fro:
Thine eare to mee doe thou incline,
i'th day I cry, soone answer mee:
verse 3 For as the smoake my dayes consume,
& like an hearth my bones burnt bee.
verse 4 My heart is smote, & dryde like grasse,
that I to eate my bread forget:
verse 5 By reason of my groanings voyce
my bones unto my skin are set.
verse 6 Like Pelican in wildernes,
like Owle in desart so am I:
verse 7 I watch, & like a sparrow am
on house top solitarily.
verse 8 Mine enemies daily mee reproach:
'gainst mee they rage, 'gainst mee they sweare:
verse 9 That I doe ashes eate for bread:
& mixe my drink with weeping-teare.
verse 10 By reason of thy fervent wrath
& of thy vehement-disdaine:
for thou hast high advanced mee,
& thou hast cast mee downe againe.
verse 11 My dayes as shaddow that decline:
& like the withered grasse am I.
verse 12 But thou, Lord, dost abide for aye:
& thy Name to eternity.
verse 13 Thou wilt arise, & wilt shew forth
thy tender-mercy on Sion:
for it is time to favour her,
yea the set time is now come on.
verse 14 For in her stones thy servants doe
take ple • sure, & her dust pitty.
verse 15 And heathens shall the Lords Name feare.
& all Kings of th'earth thy glory.
verse 16 When as the Lord shall Sion build
hee in his glory shall appeare.
verse 17 The poor's petition hee'l regard,
& hee will not despise their pray'r.
verse 18 This shall in writing be inroll'd
for the succeeding-after-race:
that people also which shall bee
created, they the Lord may prayse.
verse 19 For from his Sanctuary high
from heavn's the Lord the earth doth see:
verse 20 To heare the groanes of prisoners:
to loose them that deaths children bee.
verse 21 The Lords prayse in Ierusalem:
his Name in Sion to record.
verse 22 when people are together met,
& Kingdomes for to serve the Lord.
verse 23 He weakned hath i'th way my strength,
& shortened my dayes hath hee.
verse 24 I say • , in midd • st of my dayes
my God doe not away take mee:
Thy yeares throughout all ages are.
verse 25 Thou h • st the earth's foundation layd
for elder time: & heavens bee
the work which thine owne hands have ma • e.
verse 26 They perish shall, but thou sh • lt stand:
they all as garments shall decay:
& as a we • ring v • stiment
thou shalt thē change, & chang'd are they.
verse 27 But thou art ev'n the same: thy yeares
they never shall consumed bee.
verse 28 Thy servants children shall abide,
& their seed stablisht before thee.
O Thou my soule, Iehovah blesse,
& all things that in me
most inward are, in humblenes
his Holy-Name blesse ye
verse 2 The Lord blesse in humility,
o thou my soule: also
put not out of thy memory
all's bounties, thee unto.
verse 3 For hee it is who pardoneth
all thine iniquityes:
he it is also who healeth
all thine infirmityes.
verse 4 Who thy life from destruction
redeems: who crowneth thee
with his tender compassion
& kinde benignitee.
verse 5 Who with good things abundantlee
doth satisfie thy mouth:
so that like as the Eagles bee
renewed is thy youth.
verse 6 The Lord doth judgement & justice
for all oppressed ones.
verse 7 To Moses shew'd those wayes of his:
his acts to Isr'ells sonnes.
verse 8 The Lord is mercifull also
hee's v • ry gracious:
and unto anger hee is slow,
in mercy plenteous.
verse 9 Contention he will not maintaine
to perpetuity:
nor he his anger will retaine
unto eternity.
verse 10 According to our sins likewise
to us hee hath not done:
nor hath he our iniquityes
rewarded us upon.
verse 11 Because even as the heavens are
in height the ear • h above:
so toward them that doe him feare
confirmed is his love.
verse 12 Like as the East & West they are
farre in their distances:
he hath remov'd away so far
from us our trespasses.
verse 13 A fathers pitty like unto,
which he his sonnes doth beare:
like pitty doth Iehovah show
to them that doe him feare.
verse 14 For he doth know this frame of ours:
he minds that dust wee bee.
verse 15 Mans dayes are like the grasse: like flowrs
in field, so flourisheth hee.
verse 16 For over it the winde doth passe,
& it away doth goe;
also the place wheras it was
noe longer shall it know.
verse 17 But yet Gods mercy ever is,
shall be & • ye hath been
to them th • t feare him; and's justice
unto childrens children.
verse 18 To such as keepe his covenant,
that doe in minde up lay
the charge of his commandement
that it they may obey.
verse 19 The Lord hath in the heavens hye
established his throne:
and over all his Royallty
doth beare dominion.
verse 20 O yee his Angells that excell
in str • ngth, blesse yee the Lord,
that doe his word, that harken well
unto the voyce of 's word.
verse 21 All yee that are the Lords armies,
o blesse Iehovah st • ll:
& all yee ministers of his,
his pleasure that fullfill.
verse 22 Yea, all his works in places all
of his dominion,
blesse yee Iehov • h o my Soul,
Iehovah blesse alone.
THe Lord blesse, o my Soule, o Lord
my God, exceedi • gly
great art thou: thou with honour art
cloath'd & with mai • s • y.
verse 2 Who dost thy selfe with light, as if
it were a garment cover:
who like unto a curtaine dost
the heavens stretch all over.
verse 3 Who of his chambers layes the beames
ith waters, & hee makes
the cloudes his Charrets, & his way
on wings of winde hee takes.
verse 4 His Angells Spirits, his ministers
who makes a fiery flame.
verse 5 who earths foundations layd, that ne're
should be remov'd the same.
verse 6 Thou with the deep (as with a robe)
didst cover the dry land:
above the places mountainous
the waters they did stand.
verse 7 When as that thou rebukedst them
away then fled they fast:
they also at thy thunders voyce
with speed away doe hast.
verse 8 Vp by the mountaines they asscend:
downe by the valleys go,
the place which thou didst found for them
untill they come unto.
verse 9 Thou hast to them a bound prefixt
which they may not passe over:
so that they might noe more returne
againe the earth to cover.
verse 10 who springs into the valleys sends,
which run among the hills.
verse 11 whence all beasts of the field have drink:
wilde asses drink their fills.
verse 12 Heavns fowles dwell by them, which do sing
among the sprigs with mirth.
verse 13 Hee waters from his lof • s the hills:
thy works fruit fill the earth.
verse 14 For beasts hee makes the grasse to grow,
herbs also for mans good:
that hee may bring out of the earth
what may be for their food:
verse 15 Wine also th • t mans heart may glad,
& oyle their face to bright:
and bread which to the heart of man
may it supply with might.
verse 16 Gods trees are sappy: his planted
Cedars of Lebanon:
verse 17 Where birds doe nest: as for the Storke,
Firres are her mansion.
verse 18 The wilde Goates refuge are the hills:
rocks Conies doe inclose.
verse 19 The Moone hee hath for seasons set,
the Sun his setting knows.
verse 20 Thou makest darknes, & 'tis night:
when wood beasts creep out all.
verse 21 After their prey young Lions roare:
from God for food • hey call.
verse 22 The Sun doth rise, then in their dennes
they couch, when gone aside.
verse 23 Man to his work & labour goes,
untill the ev'ning-tide.
verse 24 O Lord, how many are thy works!
all of them thou hast wrought
in wisdome: with thy plenteous store
the earth is fully fraught.
verse 25 So is this great & spatious sea,
wherin things creeping bee
beyond all number: beasts of small
& of great quantitee.
verse 26 There goe the ships: Leviathan,
therin thou madst to play.
verse 27 These all wayt on thee, that their meate
in their time give thou may.
verse 28 They gather what thou givest them:
thy hand thou op'nest wide,
& they with such things as are good
are fully satisfyde.
verse 29 Thou hid'st thy face, they troubled are,
their breath thou tak'st away,
then doe they dye: also returne
unto their dust doe they.
verse 30 They are created, when thou makst
thy spirit forth to go:
thou of the earth dost make the • ace
to be renew'd also.
verse 31 The glory of Iehovah shall
for evermore indure:
in his owne works Iehovah shall
joyfully take pleasure.
verse 32 The earth doth tremble, when that hee
upon the same doth look,
the mountaines he doth touch, likewise
they therupon do smoak.
verse 34 Full sweet my meditation
concerning him shall be:
so that I in Iehovah will
rejoyce exceedinglee.
verse 35 Let sinners be consum'd from th'earth,
& wicked be no more:
blesse thou Iehovah, o my soule,
prayse yee the Lord therefore.
O Prayse the Lord, call on his Name.
'mong people shew his facts.
verse 2 Sing unto him, sing psalmes to him:
talk of all's wondrous acts.
verse 3 Let their hearts joy, that seek the Lord:
boast in his Holy-Name.
verse 4 The Lord seek, & his strengh: his face
alwayes seek yee the same.
verse 5 Those admirable works that hee
hath done remember you:
his wonders, & the judgements which
doe from his mouth issu • .
verse 6 O yee his servant Abrahams seed:
sonnes of chose Iacob yee.
verse 7 He is the Lord our God: in all
the earth his judgements bee.
verse 8 His Covenant for evermore,
and his comanded word,
a thousand generations to
he doth in minde record,
verse 9 Which he with Abraham made, and's oath
verse 10 to Isack. Made it fast,
a law to Iacob: & Isr'ell
a Cov'nant aye to last.
verse 11 He sayd, I'le give thee Canans land:
by lot, heirs to be there.
verse 12 When few, yea very few in count
and strangers in't they were;
verse 13 When they did from one nation
unto another pass:
when from one Kingdome their goings
to other people was,
verse 14 He suffred none to doe them wrong:
Kings checkt he for their sake:
verse 15 Touch not mine oynted ones; none ill
unto my Prophets make.
verse 16 He cal'd for Famine on the land,
all staffe of bread brake hee.
verse 17 Before them sent a man: Ioseph
sold for a slave to bee.
verse 18 Whose feet they did with fetters hur • :
in yr'n his soule did lye.
verse 19 Vntill the time that his word came:
the Lords word did him trye.
verse 20 The King the peoples Ruler sent,
loos'd him & let him go.
verse 21 He made him Lord of all his house:
of all's wealth ruler too:
verse 22 At's will to binde his Peers: & teach
verse 23 his Ancients skill. Then came
Isr'ell to Egypt: & Iacob
sojourn'd i'th land of Ham.
verse 24 H • e much increast his folk: & made
them stronger then their foe,
verse 25 Their heart he turn'd his folk: to hate:
to's servants craft to show.
verse 26 Mose • his servant he did send:
& Aaron whom he chose.
verse 27 His signes & wonders them amongst,
they in Hams land disclose.
verse 28 Hee darknes sent, & made it dark:
nor did they's word gain-say.
verse 29 Hee turn'd their waters into bloud:
& he their fish did sl • y.
verse 30 Great store of Frogs their land brought forth
in chambers of their Kings.
verse 31 He spake, there came mixt swarmes, & lice
in all their coasts he brings.
verse 32 He gave them haile for raine: & in
their land fires fl • me did make.
verse 33 And smote their Vines & their Figtree • :
& their coast-tr • es he brake.
verse 34 He spake, & then the Locusts came:
& Caterpillars, such
the number of them was as none
could reckon up how much,
verse 35 And ate all their lands herbs: & did
fruit of their ground devoure.
verse 36 All first borne in their land he smot • :
the chief of all their powre.
verse 37 With silver also & with gold
he them from thence did bring:
& among all their tribes there was
not any one weak • ling.
verse 38 Egypt was glad when out they went:
for on them fell their dread.
verse 39 A cloud for cov'ring, & a fire
to light the night he spred.
verse 40 They askt, & he brought quailes: did them
with heav'ns bread satisfy,
verse 41 He op't the rock and waters flow'd:
flouds ran in places dry.
verse 42 For on his holy promise, hee
and's servant Abraham thought.
verse 43 With joye his people, and with songs
forth he his • hosen brought.
verse 44 He of the heathen people did
the land on them bestow:
the labour of the people they
inherited also.
verse 45 To this intent that his statutes
they might observe alwayes:
also that they his lawes might keepe.
doe yee I • hovah prayse.
PRayse yee the Lord, o to the Lord
give thanks, for good is hee:
for his mercy continued is
to perpetuitee.
verse 2 Who can the Lords strong acts fo • th tell?
or all his prayse display?
verse 3 Blest they that judgement keep: & wh •
doth righteousnes alway.
verse 4 With favour of thy people, Lord,
doe thou remember mee:
and mee with that salvation
visit which is of thee:
verse 5 To see thy chosens good, to joy
in gladnes of thy nation:
that with thine owne inheritance
I might have exultation.
verse 6 As our fore-fathers so have wee
sinned erroniously:
wee practis'd have iniquity,
wee have done wickedly.
verse 7 Our fathers did not understand
thy wonders in Egypt,
nor was thy mercyes multitude
in their remembrance kept:
But at the sea at the red sea
verse 8 vext him. Yet for his owne
Names sake he • av'd them that he migh •
his mighty powre make knowne.
verse 9 The red sea also he rebuk't,
and dryed up it was:
so that as through the wildernes,
through depths he made them pass.
verse 10 And from the hand of him that did
them hate, he set them fr • e:
and them redeemed from his hand
th •• was their enemee.
verse 11 The waters covered their foes:
of them there was left none.
verse 12 They did believe his word; they sang
his prayses therupon.
verse 13 They soone forgot his words; nor would
they for his counsell stay:
verse 14 But much i'th wildernes did lust;
i'th desart God tryde they.
verse 15 And he their suite them gave; but sent
leannes their soule into.
verse 16 They envi'd Moses in the camp,
Aaron Gods Saint also.
verse 17 The opned earth, Dathan devour'd;
and hid Abirams troup.
verse 18 And fire was kindled in their rout:
flame burnt the wicked up.
verse 19 In Horeb made a calfe; also
molt image worshipt they.
verse 20 They chang'd their glory to be like,
an oxe that eateth hay.
verse 21 They God forgot their saviour; which
in Egipt did great acts:
verse 22 Works wondrous in the land of Ham:
by th'red sea dreadfull facts.
verse 23 And sayd, he would them waste; had not
Moses stood (whom he chose)
'fore him i'th breach▪ to turne his wrath,
lest that hee should waste those.
verse 24 Yet they despis'd the pleasant land:
nor did believe his word:
verse 25 But murmur'd in their tents: the voyce
they heard not of the Lord.
verse 26 To make them fall i'th desart then,
'gainst them he lift his hands.
verse 27 'Mongst nations eke to fell their seed,
and scatter them i'th lands.
verse 28 And to Baal-Peor they joyn'd themselves:
ate offrings of the dead.
verse 29 Their works his wrath did thus provoake:
the plague amongst them spread.
verse 30 Then Phineas rose, & judgement did:
and so the plague did stay.
verse 31 Which justice to him counted was:
to age and age for aye.
verse 32 At th'waters of contention
they angred him also:
so that with Moses for their sakes,
it very ill did go:
verse 33 Because his spirit they provoakt:
with's lips to speake rashly.
verse 34 The nations as the Lord them charg'd▪
they stroyd not utterly:
verse 35 But were amongst the Heathen mixt,
and learn'd their works to do:
verse 36 And did their Idols serve; which them
became a snare unto.
verse 37 Yea, unto divills, they their sonnes
and daughters offered·
verse 38 And guiltlesse bloud, bloud of their sons
& of their daughters shed,
Whom unto Canans Idols they
offred in sacrifice:
the land with bloud abundantly
polluted was likewise.
verse 39 Thus with the works were they defylde
which they themselves had done:
and they did goe a whoring with
inventions of their owne:
verse 40 Therefore against his folk the wrath
was kindled of the Lord:
so that he the inheritance
which was his owne abhorr'd.
verse 41 And he gave them to heathens hand;
their haters their lords were.
verse 42 Their foes thral'd them; under their hand
made them the yoake to beare.
verse 43 Oft he deliverd them; but they
provoakt him bitterly
with their coun • ell, & were brought low
for their iniquity.
verse 44 Yet, he regarded their distresse;
when he did heare their plaint.
verse 45 And he did to remembrance call
for them his Covenant:
And in hi • many mercyes did
verse 46 repent. And made them bee
pitty'd of all that led them forth
into captivitee.
verse 47 Save us, o Lord our God, & us
from heathens gath'ring rayse
to give thanks to thy Holy-Name:
to triumph in thy prayse.
verse 48 The Lord the God of Israell
from aye to aye blest bee:
and let all people say Amen.
o prayse Iehovah yee.
O Give yee thanks unto the Lord,
because that good is hee:
because his loving kindenes lasts
to perpetuitee.
verse 2 So let the Lords redeem'd say: whom
hee freed from th'enemies hands:
verse 3 And gathred them from East, & West,
from South, & Northerne lands.
verse 4 I'th desart, in a desart way
they wandred: no towne finde,
verse 5 to dwell in. Hungry & thirsty:
their soule within them pinde.
verse 6 Then did they to Iehovah cry
when they were in distresse:
who did them set at liberty
out of their anguishes.
verse 7 In such a way that was most right
he led them forth also:
that to a citty which they might
inhabit they might go.
verse 8 O that men would Iehovah prayse
for his great goodnes then:
& for his workings wonderfull
unto the sonnes of men.
verse 9 Because that he the longing soule
doth throughly satisfy:
the hungry soule he also fills
with good abundantly.
verse 10 Such as in darknes' and within
the shade of death abide;
who are in sore affliction,
also in yron tyde:
verse 11 By reason that against the words
of God they did rebell;
also of him that is most high
contemned the counsell.
verse 12 Therefore with molestation
hee did bring downe their heart:
downe did they fall, & none their was
could help to them impart.
verse 13 Then did they to Iehovah cry
when they were in distress:
who did them set at liberty
out of their anguishes.
verse 14 He did them out of darknes bring,
also deaths shade from under:
as for the bands that they were in
he did them break asunder.
verse 15 O that men would Iehovah prayse
for his great goodnes then:
and for his workings wonderfull
unto the sonnes of men.
verse 16 For he hath all to shivers broke
the gates that were of brasse:
& hee asunder cut each barre
that made of yron was.
verse 17 For their transgressions & their sins,
fooles doe affliction beare.
verse 18 All kinde of meate their soule abhorres:
to deaths gate they draw neare.
verse 19 Then did they to Iehovah cry
when they were in distre • s▪
who did them set at liberty
out of their anguishes.
verse 20 He, sent his word, & therewithall
healing to them he gave:
from out of their destructions
he did them also save.
verse 21 O that men would Iehovah prayse,
for his great goodnes then:
& for his workings wonderfull
unto the sons of men.
verse 22 And sacrifices sacrifice
let them of thanksgiving:
& while his works they doe declare
let them for gladnes sing.
verse 23 They that goe downe to'th sea in ships:
their busines there to doo
verse 24 in waters great. The Lords work see,
it'h deep his wonders too.
verse 25 Because that he the stormy winde
commandeth to arise:
which lifteth up the waves therof,
verse 26 They mount up to the skyes:
Downe goe they to the depths againe,
their soule with ill doth quaile.
verse 27 They reele, & stagger, drunkard like,
and all their witt doth faile.
verse 28 Then did they to Iehovah cry
when they were in distress:
and therupon he bringeth them
out of their anguishes.
verse 29 Hee makes the storme a calme: so that
the waves therof are still.
verse 30 Their rest then glads them; he them brings
to'th hav'n which they did will.
verse 31 O that men would Iehovah prayse
for his great goodnes then:
& for his workings wonderfull
unto the sons of men.
verse 32 Also within the peoples Church
him let them highly rayse:
where Elders are assembled, there
him also let them prayse.
verse 33 He rivers to a desart turnes,
to drought the springing well:
verse 34 A fruitfull soyle to barrennes;
for their sin there that dwell.
verse 35 The desart to a poole he turnes;
and dry ground to a spring.
verse 36 Seates there the hungry; who prepare
their towne of habiting,
verse 37 Vineyards there also for to plant,
also to sow the field;
which may unto them fruitfull things▪
of much revenue yield.
verse 38 Also he blesseth them, so that
they greatly are increast:
and for to be diminished
he suffers not their beast.
verse 39 Againe they are diminished
& they are brought downe low,
by reason of their pressing-streights,
affliction & sorrow.
verse 40 On Princes he contempt doth powre;
and causeth them to stray
i'th solitary wildernes,
wherin there is no way.
verse 41 Yet hee out of affliction
doth make the poore to rise▪
& like as if it were a flock
doth make him families.
verse 42 The righteous shall it behold,
and he shall joyfull bee:
in silence stop her mouth also
shall all iniquitee.
verse 43 Who so is wise, & who so will
these things attentive learne:
the loving-kindenes of the Lord
they clearely shall discerne.

div.head: Psalme 108. A song or psalme of David.

lg.l: O GOD, my heart's fixt, I'le sing; prayse
sing ev'n with my glory.
verse 2 Awake thou Psaltery & Harp;
I will awake early.
verse 3 O thou Iehovah, thee will I
the people prayse among:
within the midst of nations
thee will I prayse with song.
verse 4 For o're the heav'ns thy mercys great;
to'th skyes thy truth doth mount.
verse 5 Or'e heav'ns o God, be lift, all earth
let thy glory surmount:
verse 6 That thy beloved people may
be set at libertee:
with thy right hand salvation give,
& doe thou answer mee.
verse 7 God hath in his owne holines
spoken, r • joyce I shall:
of Shechem I'le division make;
& mete our Succoths vale.
verse 8 Mine Gilead, mine Manasseh is,
& Ephraim also hee
is of my head the strength: Iudah
shall my law-giver bee.
verse 9 Moab my wash-pot, I will cast
over Edom my shoo:
I'le make a shout triumphantly
over Philistia too.
verse 10 Who is it that will bring me to
the citty fortifyde?
who is it that into Edom
will be to mee a guide?
verse 11 Wilt not thou doe this thing, o God,
who didst us cast thee fro?
& likewise wilt thou o God,
forth with our armies go?
verse 12 From trouble give us help; for vaine
is mans salvation.
verse 13 Through God wee shall do valiantly;
for hee'l our foes tread downe.

div.head: Psalme 109. To the chief musician, a psalme of David.

lg.l: GOD of my prayse, hold not thy peace,
For mouth of the wicked,
& mouth of the deceitfull are
against mee opened:
Gainst mee they speake with lying tongue.
verse 3 And compasse mee about
with words of hate; & mee against
without a cause they fought.
verse 4 They for my love mine enemies are:
but I my prayer make.
verse 5 And ill for good rewarded mee;
& hate for my loves sake.
verse 6 A wicked person over him
doe thou make for to sit,
also at his right hand doe thou
let Satan stand at it.
verse 7 When he is judged, let him then
condemned be therin:
and let the prayr that hee doth make.
be turned into sin.
verse 8 Few let his dayes bee: & let his
office another take.
verse 9 His children let be fatherlesse,
and's wife a widow make.
verse 10 Let's children still be vagabonds,
begge they their bread also:
out of their places desolate
let them a seeking go
verse 11 Yea, let th'extortioner catch all
that doth to him pertaine:
and let the stranger spoyle what he
did by his labour gaine.
verse 12 Let there not any bee that may
mercy to him expresse:
nor any one that favour may
his children fatherlesse.
verse 13 The ishue also let thou be
cut off that from him came:
it'h following generation
out blotted be his name.
verse 14 Remembred with the Lord be his
fathers iniquitee:
and of his mother never let
the sin out blotted bee.
verse 15 Before Iehovah let them bee
continually put:
that from out of the earth he may
the mem'ry of them cut.
verse 16 Because that he remembred not
compassion to impart,
but did pursue the needy poore:
to slay the broke in heart.
verse 17 As he did cursing love, so let
cursing unto him come:
as he did not in blessing joy,
so be it far him from.
verse 18 With cursing like a robe as hee
cloath'd him: so let it go
like water to his bowels, and
like oyle his bones into.
verse 19 Garment like let it to him be,
himselfe for to aray:
and for a girdle, wherewith hee
may gird himselfe alway.
verse 20 Thus let mine adversaryes bee
rewarded from the Lord:
also of them against my soule
that speak an evil word.
verse 21 But God the Lord, for thy Names sake,
o doe thou well for mee:
because thy mercy it is good,
o doe thou set mee free.
verse 22 For poore & needy I: in mee
my heart's wounded also.
verse 23 Like falling shade I passe▪ I'me tost
Locust like to & fro.
verse 24 Through fasts my knees are weak: my flesh
it's fatnes doth forsake.
verse 25 And I am their reproach: they look
at mee, their heads they shake.
verse 26 Help mee, o Lord my God: after
thy mercy save thou mee:
verse 27 That they may know this is thy hand:
Lord that i'ts done by thee.
verse 28 Let them curse, but o doe thou blesse;
when as that they arise
let them be shamed, thy servant
let him rejoyce likewise.
verse 29 Mine adversaryes o let them
with shame be cloath'd upon:
& themselves cloath as with a cloak
with their confusion.
verse 30 I'le to Iehovah with my mouth
give thanks exceedingly:
yea him among the multitude
with prayse I'le glorify.
verse 31 For hee shall stand at right hand of
the poore & needy one:
from those that doe condemne his soule
to give salvation.

div.head: Psalme 110. A psalme of David.
div.l: THe Lord did say unto my Lord,
sit thou at my right hand:
till I thine enemies make a stoole
wheron thy f • et may stand.
verse 2 The Lord the rod shall of thy strength
send from out of Sion:
in middest of thine enemies
have thou dominion.
verse 3 Willing thy folk in thy dayes powre,
in holy beautyes bee:
from mornings womb; thou hast the de •
of thy youth unto thee.
verse 4 Iehovah sware, nor will repent,
thou art a Priest for aye:
after the order that I of
Melchizedeck did say.
verse 5 The Lord who is at thy right hand.
wounding shall strike through Kings
in that same day wherin that hee
his indignation brings.
verse 6 Hee shall among the heathen judge,
and fill with bodies dead
great places, & o're many lands
he shall strike through the head.
verse 7 Out of the torrent he shall drink
i'th way hee passeth by:
because of this therefore hee shall
lift up his head on hye.

lg.l: PRayse yee the Lord; with my whole heart
Iehovah prayse will I:
i'th private meetings of th'upright,
and publicke assembly.
verse 2 Great are the Lords works: sought of all
that in them have pleasure.
verse 3 Comely & glorious is his work:
aye doth his justice dure.
verse 4 To be remembred he hath made
his doings merveilous:
full of compassion is the Lord
as well as gracious.
verse 5 Meate hath hee given unto them
that fearers of him be • :
he evermore his covenant
doth keepe in memoree:
verse 6 The power of his works hee did
unto his people show:
that he the heathens heritage
upon them might bestow.
verse 7 Both verity & judgement are
the working of his hands:
yea very faithfull also are
each one of his commands.
verse 8 For ever & for evermore
they stand in stablenes:
yea they are done in verity
also in uprightnes·
verse 9 Redemption to his folk he sent,
that covenant of his
for aye he hath ordaind: holy
and reverend his Name is.
verse 10 Of wisdome the begining is
Iehovahs feare: all they
that doe his will have prudence good.
his prayse indures for aye.
PRayse yee the Lord. blest is the man
that doth Iehovah feare,
that doth in his commandements
his spirit greatly cheare.
verse 2 The very mighty upon earth
shall be that are his seed:
they also shall be blessed that
from th' upright doe proceed.
verse 3 And there shall be within his house
both wealth & much rich store:
his righteousnes it also doth
indure for evermore.
verse 4 In midst of darknes there doth light
to upright ones arise:
both gracious, & pittyfull,
righteous he is likewise▪
verse 5 A good man hee doth favour show
& ready is to lend:
and with descretion his affayres
he ca • ryes to an end.
verse 6 That man shall not assuredly
for ever moved bee:
the righteous man he shall be had
in lasting memoree.
verse 7 By evill tydings that he heares
he shall not be afrayd:
his trust he putting in the Lord.
his heart is fi • mly stayd.
verse 8 His heart is sure established,
feare shall not him surprise,
untill he see what hee desires
upon his enemies.
verse 9 He hath disperst, hath giv'n to poore:
his justice constantly
indureth: & his horne shall be
with honour lif • ed hye.
verse 10 The wicked shall see, & be griev'd;
gnash with his teeth shall hee
and melt away: and their desire

shall faile that wicked be •
▪

div.head: Psalme 113.
div.l: THe Lord prayse yee, prayse yee the Lord
his servants Gods Name prayse.
verse 2 O blessed be Iehovahs Name,
from henceforth & alwayes.
verse 3 From rising to the setting sun:
the Lords Name's to be praysd.
verse 4 The Lord a • l nations is above:
o're heav'ns his glory raysd
verse 5 Who is like to, the Lord our God?
who upon earth doth dwell.
verse 6 Who humble doth himselfe to view.
in heav'n, in earth as well.
verse 7 The needy from the dust he lifts:
the poore lifts from the dung.
verse 8 That hee with princes may him set:
his peoples Peeres among.
verse 9 The barren woman he doth make
to keepe house, & to bee
a joyfull mother of children:
wherefore the Lord prayse yee.

div.head: Psalme 114.
div.l: WHen Isr'ell did depart
th'Egyptians from among,
and Iacobs house from a people
that were of a strange tongue:
verse 2 Iudah his holy place:
Isrell's dominion was.
verse 3 The sea it saw, & fled: Iordane
was forced back to pass.
verse 4 The mountaine • they did leap
upwards like unto rams:
the litle hills also they did
leap up like unto lambs.
verse 5 Thou sea what made thee flye?
thou Iordane, back to go?
verse 6 Yee mountaines that yee skipt like ram • :
like lambs yee hills also?
verse 7 Earth at Gods presence dread;
at Iacobs Gods presence:
verse 8 The rock who turnes to waters lake:
springs he from flint sends thence.

lg.l: NOt to us, not unto us, Lord,
but glory to t • y Name afford:
for thy mercy, for thy truths sake.
verse 2 The heathen wherefore should they say:
where is their God now gone away?
verse 3 But heavn's our God his seat doth make:
Hee hath done whatsoe're he would.
verse 4 Their Idols are silver & gold:
the handy work of men they were.
verse 5 Mouths have they, speachlesse yet they be • :
eyes have they, but they doe not see.
verse 6 Eares have they but they doe not heare:
Noses have they, but doe not smell.
verse 7 Hands have they, but cannot handell,
feet have they but they doe not go:
And th • ough their throat they never spake.
verse 8 Like them are they, that doe them make:
& all that trust in them are so.
verse 9 Trust in the Lord o Israell,
he is their help, their shield as well.
verse 10 O Arons house the Lord trust yee:
Hee is their help, & hee their shield.
verse 11 Who feare the Lord, trust to him yield:
their help also their shield is hee.
verse 12 The Lord hath mindefull been of us,
he'le blesse us, he'le blesse Isr'ells house:
blessing he'le Arons house afford.
verse 13 He'le blesse Gods fearers: great & small.
verse 14 You & your sons, the Lord much shall
verse 15 increase still. You blest of the Lord
verse 16 which heav'n & earth made. Heav'ns heav'ns-bee
the Lords: but th'earth mens sons gives hee.
verse 17 The Lords prayse dead doe not afford:
Nor any that to silence bow.
verse 18 But wee will blesse the Lord both now
and ever henceforth. prayse the Lord.
I Love the Lord, because he doth
my voice & prayer heare.
verse 2 And in my dayes will call, because
he bow'd to mee his eare.
verse 3 The pangs of death on ev'ry side
about beset mee round:
the paines of hell 'gate hold on mee,
distresse & griefe I found.
verse 4 Vpon Iehovahs Name therefore
I called, & did say,
deliver thou my soule, o Lord,
I doe thee humbly pray.
verse 5 Gracious the Lord & just, our God
is mercifull also.
verse 6 The Lord the simple keeps: & hee
sav'd mee when I was low.
verse 7 O thou my soule doe thou returne
unto thy quiet rest:
because the Lord to thee himselfe
hath bounteously exprest.
verse 8 For thou hast freed my soule from death,
mine eyes from teares, from fall
my feet. Before the Lord i'th land
of living walk I shall.
verse 10 I did believe, therefore I spake:
afflicted much was I.
verse 11 That every man a lyar is
I did say hastily.
verse 12 What shall I render to the Lord,
to mee for's ben • fits all.
verse 13 I'le take the cup of saving health
& on the Lords Name call.
verse 14 In presence now of all his folk,
I'le pay the Lord my vowes.
verse 15 Of his Saints, in Iehovahs sight
the death is pretious.
verse 16 I am thy servant, truly Lord
thine owne servant am I:
I am the son of thy hand-maide,
my bands thou didst untye.
verse 17 Of thanksgiving the sacrifice
offer to thee I will:
Iehovahs Name I earnestly
will call upon it still.
verse 18 Vnto Iehovah I will pay
the vowes were made by mee,
now in the presence of all them
that his owne people bee.
verse 19 Within the Courts of the Lords house,
ev'n in the midst of thee
o thou citty Ierusalem:
o prayse Iehovah yee.
AL nations, prayse the Lord; him prayse
all people. For his mercies bee
great toward us: also alwayes
the Lords truth lasts. the Lord prayse yee.

lg.head: Another of the same.
lg.l: AL nations, prayse the Lord; all folk
prayse him. For his mercee
is great to us; & the Lords truth
aye lasts. the Lord prayse yee.
O Give yee th • nks unto the Lord,
because that good is hee;
because his loving kindenes lasts
to perpetuitee.
verse 2 For ever that his mercie lasts
let Israell now say.
