verse 3 Let Arons house now say, that his
mercie indures for aye.
verse 4 Likewise let them now say, who of
Iehovah fearers bee;
his loving kindenes that it lasts
to perpetuitee.
verse 5 I did lift up my voice to God
from out of streitnes great;
the Lord mee answerd, & mee plac't
in an inlarged seat.
verse 6 The Lord's for mee, I will not feare
what man can doe to mee.
verse 7 Iehovah takes my part with them
that of mee helpers bee:
Therefore upon them that mee hate
my wishes see shall I.
verse 8 'Tis better to trust in the Lord:
then on man to rely.
verse 9 'Tis better to trust on the Lord:
then trust in Princes put.
verse 10 All nations compast mee, but them
in Gods Name I'le off cut.
verse 11 They compast mee about, yea they
mee compassed about:
but in Iehovahs Name I will
them utterly root out.
verse 12 They compast mee like Bees, are quencht
like as of thornes the flame:
but I will utterly destroy
them in Iehovahs Name.
verse 13 Thou didst thrust sore to make mee fall:
the Lord yet helped mee.
verse 14 The Lord my fortitude & song:
& saving health is hee.
verse 15 The tabernacles of the just
the voice of joye afford
& of salvation: strongly works
the right hand of the Lord.
verse 16 The right hand of Iehovah is
exalted up on hye:
the right hand of Iehovah is
a working valiantly.
verse 17 I shall not dye, but live: & tell
what things the Lord worketh.
verse 18 The Lord did sorely chasten mee:
but gave mee not to death.
verse 19 O set wide open unto mee
the gates of righteousnes:
I will goe into them, & will
Iehovahs praise confess.
verse 20 This same Iehovahs gate at which
the just shall enter in.
verse 21 I'le praise thee, for thou hast mee heard,
and hast my safety bin.
verse 22 The stone which builders did refuse
head corner stone now lyes.
verse 23 This is the doing of the Lord:
it's wondrous in our eyes,
verse 24 This is the very day the which
Iehovah hee hath made:
wee will exceedingly rejoyce,
& in it will be glad.
verse 25 Iehovah I doe thee beseech,
salvation now afford:
I humbly thee intreat, now send
prosperity, o Lord.
verse 26 Hee that comes in Iehovahs Name
o let him blessed bee:
out of Iehovahs house to you
a bles • ing wish doe wee.
verse 27 God he Iehovah is, and hee
light unto us affords:
the sacrifices binde unto
the altars hornes with cords.
verse 28 Thou art my God, & I'le thee prayse,
my God I'le set thee hye.
verse 29 O prayse the Lord, for he is good,
and aye lasts his mercy.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (1) Aleph
lg.l: ALL-blest are men upright of way:
walk in Iehovahs law who do.
verse 2 Blest such as doe his records keepe:
with their whole heart him seek also.
verse 3 And that work no iniquitie:
but in his wayes doe walke indeed.
verse 4 Thou hast giv'n charge, with diligence
unto thy precepts to give h •• d.
verse 5 Ah that to keepe thy statutes: so
my wayes addressed were by thee.
verse 6 When I respect thy precep • s all,
then shall I not ashamed b • e.
verse 7 Whē I thy righteous judgements learne
with hearts uprightnes I'le thee prayse.
verse 8 Forsake thou mee not utterly:
I will observe thy statute-wayes.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (2) Beth
lg.label: verse 9
lg.l: By what may 'young man cleanse his way?
by heeding it as thy word guides.
verse 10 With my whole heart thee have I sought:
thy lawes let mee not goe besides.
verse 11 I in my heart thy word have hid:
that I might not against thee sin.
verse 12 Thou o Iehovah, blessed art:
thine owne statutes instruct mee in.
verse 13 All the just judgements of thy mouth
declared with my lips have I.
verse 14 I in thy testimonyes way
joy more then in all rich plenty.
verse 15 In thy precepts I'le meditate:
and have respect unto thy wayes▪
verse 16 My selfe I'le solace in thy lawes:
and not forget what thy word sayes.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (3) Gimel
lg.l: verse 17 Confer this grace thy servant to,
that I may live thy word to keep.
verse 18 Vnveile mine eyes, that I may see
out of thy law the wonders deep.
verse 19 I am a stranger in the earth:
do not thy precepts from me hide.
verse 20 My soule is broken with desire
unto thy judgements time & tide.
verse 21 Thou hast rebuk'd the proud, acu • st
which doe frō thy commandments swerve.
verse 22 Roll off from mee reproach & scorne:
for I thy records doe observe.
verse 23 Ev'n Princes sate & 'gainst mee spake;
but on thy lawes thy servant mus'd.
verse 24 Also thy records are my joyes:
and for men of my counsell us'd.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (4) Daleth
lg.l: verse 25 Downe to the dust my soule cleav, s fast:
o quicken mee after thy word.
verse 26 I show'd my wayes & thou mee heardst:
thy statutes learning mee afford.
verse 27 Thy precepts way make mee to know:
so I'le muse on thy wondrous wayes.
verse 28 My soule doth melt for heavines:
according to thy word mee rayse.
verse 29 The way of lying from mee take:
and thy law grant mee graciously.
verse 30 The way of truth I chosen have:
thy judgements 'fore mee layd have I.
verse 31 Thy testimonies cleave I to;
o • ord, on mee shame do not cast.
verse 32 Th • n shall I run thy precepts way,
when thou mine heart enlarged hast.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (5) He·
lg.l: verse 33 Enforme mee Lord, in thy laws path;
and I will keep it to the end.
verse 34 Skill give mee, & thy law I'le keep:
yea with my whole heart it attend.
verse 35 Cause mee to tread thy precepts path;
because therin delight I do.
verse 36 Vnto thy records bend my heart;
& covetousnes not unto.
verse 37 From vaine sights turne away mine eyes:
and in thy way make mee to live.
verse 38 Confirme thy word thy servant to,
who to thy feare himselfe doth give.
verse 39 My slander which I feare remove;
because thy judgements good they bee▪
verse 40 Loe for thy precepts I have lon'gd:
o in thy justice quicken mee.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (6) Vau.
lg.l: verse 41 Finde mee out let thy mercies Lord:
thy saving health as thou hast sayd.
verse 42 So I my taunters answer shall,
for on thy word my hope is stayd.
verse 43 Nor truths-word quite frō my mouth take:
because thy judgements I attend.
verse 44 So I thy law shall alway keep,
to everlasting without end.
verse 45 And I will walk at libertie,
because I doe thy precepts seek.
verse 46 Nor will I blush, when before Kings
I of thy testimonies speak.
verse 47 In thy commands, which I have lov'd,
also my selfe delight I will.
verse 48 And lift my hands to thy commands
belov'd: & minde thy statutes still.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (7) Sajin.
lg.l: verse 49 Good to thy servant make the word,
on which to hope thou didst mee give.
verse 50 This was my comfort in my griefe,
because thy word doth make mee live.
verse 51 The proud have much derided mee:
yet have I not thy law declinde.
verse 52 Thy judgements Lord, that are of old,
I did recall, & comfort finde.
verse 53 Horrour hath taken hold on mee:
for lewd men that thy law forsake.
verse 54 I, in my pilgrimages house,
of thy statutes my songs doe make.
verse 55 By night remembred I thy Name,
o Lord: & I thy law observe.
verse 56 This hath been unto mee, because
I from thy precepts did not swerve.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (8) He • h.
lg.l: verse 57 Hee, ev'n the Lord, my portion is,
I said that I would keep thy word.
verse 58 With my whole heart thy face I begg'd:
thy promis'd mercies mee afford.
verse 59 I thought upon my waies, & turn'd
my feet into thy testaments.
verse 60 I hasted, & made no delaies
to keepe with heed thy commandments.
verse 61 The bands of wicked men mee robb'd:
of thy law I am not mindeless.
verse 62 Ile rise at midnight thee to praise;
for judgements of thy righteousnes.
verse 63 Companion am I to all them,
that feare thee, & thy laws doe heed.
verse 64 Thy mercie fills the earth, o Lord:
teach mee the lawes thou hast decreed.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (9) Teth.
lg.l: verse 65 Iehovah, with thy servant thou
after thy word, right-well hast done.
verse 66 Good taste & knowledge, teach thou m •• ,
for I believe thy precepts on.
verse 67 Before I was chastis'd, I stray'd:
but I thy word observ'd have now.
verse 68 Thou art good, & art doing good:
thy statutes teach mee, oh doe thou.
verse 69 The proud against mee forg'd a lye:
thy laws I'le keepe with my hearts-might.
verse 70 The heart of them is fat as grease:
but in thy law I doe delight.
verse 71 It's good for mee, I was chastis'd:
that so thy statutes learne I should.
verse 72 Better to mee is thy mouths-law,
then thousands of silver & gold.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (10) Iod.
lg.l: verse 73 Know make mee, & I'le learn thy lawes:
thy hands mee formed have, & made.
verse 74 Who feare thee, mee shall see, & joy:
because hope in thy word I had.
verse 75 Thy judgements Lord, I know are just;
& faithfully thou chastnedst mee.
verse 76 As thou hast to thy servant spoke,
now let thy grace my comfort bee.
verse 77 Send mee thy grace, that I may live;
for thy law as my joy I chu • e.
verse 78 Shame proud ones, that mee falsly wrong:
but I will in thy precepts muse.
verse 79 Let them that feare thee turne to mee;
and such as have thy records knowne.
verse 80 Let my heart bee in thy lawes sound
that so I shame may suffer none.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (11) Caph.
lg.l: verse 81 Look for thy word I doe, when as
my soule doth faint for help from thee.
verse 82 Mine eies have failed for thy word,
saying, when wilt thou comfort mee?
verse 83 I like a smoake-dride-bottle am;
yet doe I not thy laws forgoe.
verse 84 what are thy servants daies? when wilt
on my pursuers judgement doe?
verse 85 The proud have digged pits for mee,
which doe not unto thy law sute.
verse 86 All thy comands are truth▪ help mee,
they wrongfully mee persecute.
verse 87 They nigh had wasted mee on earth,
but I thy laws did not forsake.
verse 88 To keep the records of thy mouth,
mee in thy me • cie lively make.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (12) Lamed.
lg.l: verse 89 Made fast i'th heavens is thy word,
o Lord, for ever to endure.
verse 90 From age to age thy faithfullnes:
thou form'dst the earth, & it stands-sure.
verse 91 As thou ordain'dst, they still abide;
for all are servants thee unto.
verse 92 Had not thy law been my delight:
Then had I perisht in my wo.
verse 93 Thy statutes I will ne're forget:
because by them thou quicknedst mee.
verse 94 Thine owne am I, save mee, because
I sought thy precepts studiou • lee.
verse 95 The wicked watch mee, mee to stroy:
but I thy testimonies minde.
verse 96 Of all perfection, end I see:
but very large thy law I finde.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (13) Mem.
lg.l: verse 97 Now how much doe I love thy law?
it is my study all the day.
verse 98 Thou mad'st mee wiser then my foes
by thy rule: for it's with mee aye.
verse 99 I'me wiser then my teachers all▪
for thy records my study are.
verse 100 I more then ancients understand;
because I kept thy laws with care.
verse 101 From each ill path my feet I stay'd:
that so I might thy word observe.
verse 102 Bec • use thou hast instructed mee,
I did not from thy judgements swerve.
verse 103 How sweet are thy words to my taste?
to my mouth more then honie they.
verse 104 I from thy precepts wisdome learne:
therefore I hate each lying way.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (14) Nun.
lg.l: verse 105 Of my feet is thy word the lamp:
and to my path the shining light.
verse 106 Sworne have I, & will it performe,
that I will keep thy judgements right.
verse 107 I am afflicted very much:
Lord quicken mee after thy word.
verse 108 Accept my mouths free-offrings now:
& mee thy judgements teach o Lord.
verse 109 My soule is alwaies in my hand:
but I have not thy law forgot.
verse 110 The wicked laide for mee a snare:
yet from thy laws I strayed not.
verse 111 Thy recods are mine heritage
for aye: for my hearts joy they bee.
verse 112 I bent my heart still to performe
thy st • tues to eternitee.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (15) Samech.
lg.l: verse 113 Pursue-I doe with hatred, all
vaine thoughts: but love thy law doe I.
verse 114 My covert & my shield art thou:
I on thy word wait hopefully.
verse 115 Depart from mee, lewd men, that I
may keepe my Gods commandements.
verse 116 By thy word stay mee, & I live:
nor shame mee for my confidence.
verse 117 Susteine mee, & I shall be safe:
and in thy law still I'le delight.
verse 118 thou tread'st downe all that from thy laws
doe stray: for false is their deceit.
verse 119 All th'earths lewd ones l • ke drosse thou-stroyd'st
therefore thy records love I do.
verse 120 For feare of thee my flesh doth quake:
I doe thy judgements dread also.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (16) Hajin.
lg.l: verse 121 Quite to oppressors leave mee not:
I judgement doe, & righteousnes.
verse 122 thy servants suretie be for good:
let not the proud ones mee oppress.
verse 123 Mine eyes for thy salvation faile:
as also for thy righteous word.
verse 124 In mercie with thy servant deale:
& thy lawes-learning mee afford.
verse 125 I am thy servant, make mee wise,
thy testimonies for to know.
verse 126 Time for thee Lord it is to work,
for men thy law doe overthrow.
verse 127 Therefore doe I thy precepts love,
above gold, yea the finest gold.
verse 128 All false paths hate I: for thy rules
of all things, are all right, I hold.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (17) Pe·
lg.l: verse 129 Right-wondrous are thy testimonies:
therefore my soule keeps them with care.
verse 130 The entrance'of thy words gives light:
and makes them wise that simple are.
verse 131 I gape & pant for thy precepts;
because I longed for the same.
verse 132 Look on mee, & such grace mee show,
as thou dost them that love thy Name.
verse 133 My steps by thy word guide: & let
no wickednes beare rule in mee.
verse 134 From mens oppression mee redeem:
and thy laws-keeper will I bee.
verse 135 Make thy face on thy serva • t shine:
and mee to learne thy statutes cause.
verse 136 Mine eies run floods of waters downe:
because they doe not keep thy laws.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (18) T • ade.
lg.l: verse 137 Sincerely-just art thou, o Lord,
thy judgements upright are also.
verse 138 Thy testimonies thou commandst
are right, yea, very faithfull too.
verse 139 My zeale consumed mee, because
mine enemies thy words forget.
verse 140 Thy word it is exceeding pure:
therefore thy servant loveth it.
verse 141 Small am I, & contemptible:
yet thy commands forget not I.
verse 142 Thy justice, justice is for aye:
also thy law is verity.
verse 143 Distresse & anguish seas'd on mee:
yet thy commands delights mee give.
verse 144 Thy records justice lasts for aye:
make thou mee wise, & I shall live.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (19) Koph.
lg.l: verse 145 To mee that cry with my whole heart
Lord heare: thy statutes keep I will.
verse 146 I unto thee did cry: save mee,
& I shall keep thy records still.
verse 147 The dawning I prevent, & cry:
I for thy word doe hopefull-wai • e.
verse 148 Mine eyes prevent the night-watches,
in thy word for to meditate.
verse 149 Lord, of thy mercy heare my voice:
after thy judgements quicken mee.
verse 150 Who follow mischiefe, they draw nigh:
who from thy law afarre off bee.
verse 151 But o Iehovah, thou art neere:
and all thy precepts verity.
verse 152 I long since of thy records knew:
thou laid'st them for eternity.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (20) • esch.
lg.l: verse 153 View mine affliction, & mee free:
for I thy law doe not forget.
verse 154 Plead thou my cause, & mee redeem:
for thy words sake alive mee set.
verse 155 Salvation from lewd men is far:
sith they thy laws to finde ne're strive.
verse 156 Great are thy bowell-mercies Lord:
after thy judgements mee revive.
verse 157 Many my foes and hunters are:
yet I not from thy records swerve.
verse 158 I saw transgressors, & was griev'd,
for they thy word doe not observe.
verse 159 See Lord, that I thy precepts love:
graunt, of thy bounty live I may.
verse 160 Thy word's beginning it is truth:
and all thy right judgements for aye.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (21) Schin.
lg.l: verse 161 Without cause Princes mee pursue:
but of thy word my hearts in awe.
verse 162 As one that hath much booty found,
so I rejoyce doe in thy law.
verse 163 Lying I hate, & it abhorre:
but thy law dearly love doe I.
verse 164 Seven times a day I prayse thee, for
the judgements of thine equity.
verse 165 Great peace have they that love thy law:
& such shall finde no stumbling-stone.
verse 166 I hop't for thy salvation, Lord:
and thy commandments I have done.
verse 167 My soule thy testimonies keeps:
and them I love exceedinglee.
verse 168 I keep thy rules & thy records:
for all my waies before thee bee.

lg.head: 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 (22) Thau.
lg.l: verse 169 Yield Lord, my cry, t'approach thy face:
as thou hast spoke, mee prudent make.
verse 170 Let my request before thee come:
deliver mee for thy words sake.
verse 171 My lips shall utter forth thy prayse:
when thou thy lawes hast learned mee.
verse 172 My tongue shall forth thy word resound:
for all thy precepts justice bee.
verse 173 To help mee let thy hand be neere:
for thy commandments chose have I.
verse 174 I long for thy salvation, Lord:
and my delights in thy law ly.
verse 175 Let my soule live, & shew thy prayse:
help mee also thy judgements let.
verse 176 Like lost sheep strayd, thy servant seeke:
for I thy laws doe not forget

div.head: Psalme 120. A song of degrees.
div.l: VNto the Lord, in my distresse
I cry'd, & he heard mee.
verse 2 From lying lipps & guilefull tongue,
o Lord, my soule set free.
verse 3 What shall thy false tongue give to thee,
or what on thee confer?
verse 4 Sharp arrows of the mighty ones,
with coales of juniper.
verse 5 Woe's mee, that I in Mesech doe
a sojourner remaine:
that I doe dwell in tents, which doe
to Kedar appertaine.
verse 6 Long time my soule hath dwelt with him
that peace doth much abhorre,
verse 7 I am for peace, but when I speake,
they ready are for warre.

div.head: Psalme 121. A song of degrees.
div.l: I To the hills lift up mine eyes,
from whence shall come mine aid.
verse 2 Mine help doth from Iehovah come,
which heav'n & earth hath made.
verse 3 Hee will not let thy foot be mov'd,
nor slumber; that thee keeps.
verse 4 Loe hee that keepeth Israell,
hee slumbreth not, nor sleeps.
verse 5 The Lord thy keeper is, the Lord
on thy right hand the shade.
verse 6 The Sun by day, nor Moone by night,
shall thee by stroke invade.
verse 7 The Lord will keep the from all ill:
thy soule hee keeps alway,
verse 8 Thy going out, & thy income,
the Lord keeps now & aye.

div.head: Psalme 122. A song of degrees.
div.l: I Ioy'd in them, that to mee sayd
to the Lords house go wee.
verse 2 Ierusalem, within thy gates,
our feet shall standing bee.
verse 3 Ierusalem, it builded is
like unto a citty
together which compacted is
within it selfe closely.
verse 4 Whether the tribes, Gods tribes ascend
unto Isr'ells witnes;
that they unto Iehovahs Name
may render thankfullnes.
verse 5 For there the judgements thrones, the thrones
of Davids house doe sit.
verse 6 O for Ierusalem her peace
see that yee pray for it:
Prosper they shall that doe thee love.
verse 7 Peace in thy fortresses
o let there be, prosperity
within thy Pallaces.
verse 8 For my brethren & for my friends,
I'le now speake peace to thee.
verse 9 I'le for our God Iehovahs house,
seek thy felicitee.

div.head: Psalme 123. A song of degrees.
div.l: O Thou that sittest in the heav'ns,
I lift mine eyes to thee.
verse 2 Loe, as the servants eyes unto
hand of their masters bee:
As maides eyes to her mistresse hand,
so are our eyes unto
the Lord our God, untill that hee
shall mercy to us show.
verse 3 O Lord be mercifull to us,
mercifull to us bee:
bec • use that filled with contempt
exceedingly are wee.
verse 4 With scorne of those that be at ease,
our soule's fill'd very much:
also of those that great ones are,
ev'n with contempt of such.

div.head: Psalme 124. A song of degrees▪ of David.
div.l: HAd not the Lord been on our side,
may Israell now say,
verse 2 Had not God been for us, when men
did rise against us they:
verse 3 They had then swallow'd us alive,
when their wrath on us burn'd.
verse 4 Then had the waters us o'rewhelmd,
the streame our soule or'e turnd.
verse 5 The proud waters then, on our soule
had passed on their way:
verse 6 Blest be the Lord, that to their teeth
did not give us a prey.

verse 7
〈◊〉 soule, as bird, escaped is
out of the fowlers snare:
the s • are asunder broken is,
•• d wee delivered are.
verse 8 The succour which wee doe injoye,
is in Iehovahs Name:
wh • is the maker of the earth,
and of the heavens frame.

div.head: psalme 125. A song of degrees.
div.l: THey that doe in Iehovah trust
shall as mount Sion bee:
which cannot be remo'vd, but shall
remaine perpetuallee.
verse 2 Like as the mountaines round about
Ierusalem doe stay:
so doth the Lord surround his folk,
from henceforth ev'n for aye.
verse 3 For lewd mens rod on just mens lot
it shall not resting bee:
lest just men should put forth their hand
unto iniquitee.
verse 4 To those Iehovah, that be good,
gladnes to them impart:
as also unto them that are
upright within their heart.
verse 5 But who turne to their crooked wayes,
the Lord shall make them go
with workers of iniquity:
but peace be Isr'ell to.

div.head: psalme 126. A song of degrees.
div.l: WHen as the Lord return'd againe
Sions captivitee:
at that time unto them that dreame
compared might wee bee.
verse 2 Then was our mouth with laughter fill'd,
with singing then our tongue:
the Lord hath done great things for them
said they, t'heathens among.
verse 3 The Lord hath done great things for us▪
wherof wee joyfull bee.
verse 4 As streames in South, doe thou o Lord,
turne our captivitee.
verse 5 Who sow in teares, shall reape in joy.
verse 6 Who doe goe forth, & mourne,
bearing choise seed, shall sure with joye
bringing their sheaves returne.

div.head: psalme 127. A song of degrees for Solomon.
div.l: IF God build not the house, vainly
who build it doe take paine:
except the Lord the citty keepe,
the watchman wa • es in vaine.
verse 2 I'ts vaine for you early to rise,
watch late, to feed upon
the bread of grief: so hee gives sleep
to his beloved one.
verse 3 Loe, the wombes fruit, it's Gods reward
sonnes are his heritage.
verse 4 As arrows in a strong mans hand,
are sons of youthfull age.
verse 5 O blessed is the man which hath
his quiver fill'd with those:
they shall not be asham'd, i'th gate
when they speake with their foes.

div.head: Psalme 128. A song of degrees.
div.l: BLessed is every one
that doth Iehovah feare:
that walks his wayes along.
verse 2 For thou shalt eate with cheare
thy hands labour:
blest shalt thou bee,
it well with thee
shall be therefore.
verse 3 Thy wife like fruitfull vine
shall be by thine house side:
the children that be thine
like olive plants abide
about thy board.
verse 4 Behold thus blest
that man doth rest,
that feares the Lord.
verse 5 Iehovah shall thee blesse
from Sion, & shalt see
Ierusalems goodnes
all thy lifes dayes that bee.
verse 6 And shalt view well
thy children then
with their children,
peace on Isr'ell.

div.head: Psalme 129. A song of degrees.
div.l: FRom my youth, now may Isr'ell say,
oft have they mee assaild:
verse 2 They mee assaild oft from my youth▪
ye • 'gainst mee nought prevaild.
verse 3 The ploughers plough'd upon my back,
their furrows long they drew:
verse 4 The righteous Lord the wickeds cords
he did asunder-hew.
verse 5 L • t all that Sion hate be sham'd,
and • urned back together.
verse 6 As grasse on hou • e tops, let them be,
which ere it's • rown, doth wither:
verse 7 Wherof that which might fill his hand
the mower doth not finde:
not therewith hee his bosome fills
that doth the sheaves up binde.
verse 8 Neither doe they that passe by, say,
Iehovahs blessing bee
on you: you in Iehovahs Name
a blessing wish doe wee.

div.head: Psalme 130. A song of degrees.
div.l: LORD, from the depth I cryde to thee.
My voice Lord, doe thou heare:
unto my supplications voice
let be a • tent thine eare.
verse 3 Lord, who should stand? if thou o Lord,
shouldst mark iniquitee.
verse 4 But with thee there forgivenes is:
that feared thou maist bee.
verse 5 I for the Lord wayt, my soule wayts:
& I hope in his word.
verse 6 Then morning watchers watch for morn,
more my soule for the Lord.
verse 7 In God hope Isr'ell, for mercy
is with the Lord: with him
verse 8 there's much redemption. From all's sin
hee Isr'ell will redeem.

div.head: Psalme 131. A song of degrees, of David.
div.l: MY heart's not haughty, Lord,
nor lofty are mine eyes:
in thi • gs too great, or high for mee,
is not mine exercise.
verse 2 Surely my selfe I have
compos'd, and made to rest▪
like as a child that weaned is,
from 〈◊〉 his mothers brest:
Im'e like a weaned child.
verse 3 Let Israell then stay
with expectation on the Lord,
from henceforth and for aye▪

div.head:
Psalme 132.
A song of degrees.
div.l: REmember David, Lord,
and all's affliction:
verse 2 How to the Lord he swore, & vow'd
to Iacobs mighty one.
verse 3 Surely I will not goe
my houses tent into:
upon the pallate of my bed,
thither I will not go.
verse 4 I will not verily
give sleep unto mine eyes:
nor will I give to mine eye-lidds
slmber in anywise,
verse 5 Vntill that for the Lord
I doe finde out a seate:
a fixed habitation,
for Iacobs God so great.
verse 6 Behould, at Epratah,
there did wee of it heare:
ev'n in the plain-fields of the wood▪
wee found it to be there.
verse 7 Wee'l goe into his te • ts:
wee'l at his footstoole bow.
verse 8 Arise, Lord, thou into thy rest:
and th'Arke of thy strength now.
verse 9 Grant tha • thy priests may be
cloathed with righteousnes:
o let thy holy ones likewis •
shout forth for joyfullnes.
verse 10 Let not for Davids sake a part ▪
a servant unto thee,
the face of thine annoynted one
away quite turned bee.
verse 11 The Lord to David sware
truth, nor will turne from it;
thy bodyes fruit, of them I'le make
upon thy throne to sit.
verse 12 If thy sons keep my law,
and covenant, I teach them;
upon thy throne for evermore
shall sit their children then.
verse 13 Because Iehovah hath
made choise of mount Sion:
he hath desired it to bee
his habitation.
verse 14 This is my resting place
to perpetuity:
here will I dwell, and that because
desired it have I.
verse 15 Blesse her provision
abundantly I will:
the poore that be in her with bread
by mee •• all have their fill.
verse 16 Her Priest • with saving health
them also I will clad:
her holy ones likew • se they shall
with shouting loud be glad.
verse 17 The horne of David I
will make to bud forth there:
a candle I prepared have
for mine annoynted deare.
verse 18 His enemies I will
with shame apparrell them▪
but flourishing upon himselfe
shall be his Diadem:

div.head: Psalme 133. A song of degrees, of David

lg.l: HOw good and sweet o see,
i'ts for brethren to dwell
together in unitee:
verse 2 It's like choise oyle that fell
the head upon,
that downe did flow
the beard unto,
beard of Aron:
The skirts of his garment
that unto them went downe;

verse 3
• ike Hermons dews descent,
Sions mountaines upon,
for there to bee
the Lords blessing,
life aye lasting
commandeth hee.

lg.head: Annother of the same.
lg.l: HOw good it is, o see,
and how it pleaseth well,
together ev'n in unitee
for brethren soe to dwell:
verse 2 I'ts like the choise oyntment
from head, to'th beard did go,
downe Arons beard: downeward that went
his garments skirts unto.
verse 3 As Hermons dew, which did
on Sions hill descend:
for there the Lord blessing doth bid,
ev'n life without an end.

div.head: Psalme 134. A song of degrees.
div.l: O All yee servants of the • ord,
behold the Lord blesse yee;
yee who within Iehovahs house
i'th night time standing bee.
verse 2 Lift up your hands, and blesse the Lord,
in's place of holines.
verse 3 The Lord that heav'n & earth hath made,
thee out of Sion bless.

lg.l: THe Lord praise, praise ye the Lords Name▪
the Lords servants o praise him yee.
verse 2 That in the Lords house stand: the same
i'th Courts of our Gods house who bee.
verse 3 The Lord prayse, for the Lord is good▪
for sweet its to his Name to sing.
verse 4 For Iacob to him chose hath God:
& Isr'ell for his pretious thing,
verse 5 For that the Lord is great I know:
& over all gods, our Lord keeps.
verse 6 All that he wills, the Lord doth do:
in heav'n, earth, seas, & in all deeps.
verse 7 The vapours he doth them constraine,
forth from the ends of th'earth to rise;
he maketh lightning for the raine:
the winde brings from his treasuries.
verse 8 Of Egipt he the first borne smit:
and that o • man, of beasts also.
verse 9 Sent wondrous sign • s mi • st thee, Egipt:
on Pharoah, on all's servants too.
verse 10 Who smote great natiōs, s • ew great Kings:
verse 11 S • ew Sihon King of th'Amorites,
Og also one of • aīhans kings:
all kingdomes of the Cananites,
verse 12 An • gave their land an heritage:
his people Isr'ells lot to fall.
verse 13 For aye thy Name, Lord, through each age
o Lord, is thy memoriall.
verse 14 For his fol • s judge, the Lord is hee:
and of his servants he'le repent.
verse 15 The he •• hens Idols silver bee,
& gold: mens hands did them invent.

verse 16 Mouths have they, yet • hey never spak •
▪
eyes have they, but they doe not see:
verse 17 Eares have they, but no hearing take:
& in • h • ir mouth no breathings bee.
verse 18 They that them m • ke, have their likenes:
that trust in them so is each one.
verse 19 The Lord o house of Isr'ell bless;
the Lord blesse, thou house of Aaron.
verse 20 O house of Levi, blesse the Lord:
who feare the Lord, blesse ye the Lord.
verse 21 From Sion blesse • be the Lord;
who dwells at Salem praise the Lord.

div.head: Psalme 136.
div.l: O Thank the Lord, for hee is good:
for's mercy lasts for aye.
verse 2 Give thanks unto the God of gods:
for's mercy is alway.
verse 3 Give thanks unto the Lord of lords:
for • s mercy lasts for aye.
verse 4 To him who only doth great signes:
for's mercy is alway.
verse 5 To him whose wisdome made the heav'ns:
for's mercy &c.
verse 6 Who o're the waters spread the earth:
for's mercy &c.
verse 7 Vnto him that did make great lights:
for's mercy &c.
verse 8 The Sun for ruling of the day:
for's mercy &c.
verse 9 The Moone and Stars to rule by night:
for's mercy &c.
verse 10 To him who Egipts first-borne smote:
for's mercy &c.
verse 11 And from amongst them Isr'ell brought:
for's mercy &c·
verse 12 With strong hand, & with stretcht-out arme:
for's mercy &c.
verse 13 To him who did the red sea part:
for's mercy &c.
verse 14 And through i'ts midst made Isr'ell go • :
for's mercy &c.
verse 15 But there dround Ph • ro • h & his hoast:
for's mercy &c.
verse 16 His people who through desart led:
for's mercy &c.
verse 17 To him which did smite mighty Kings:
for's mercy &c.
verse 18 And put to slaughter famous Ki • gs:
for's mercy &c.
verse 19 Sihon King of the Amorites:
for's mercy &c.
verse 20 And Og who was of Bashan King:
for's mercy &c.
verse 21 And gave their land an • eritage:
for's mercy &c.
verse 22 A lot his servant Israell to:
for's mercy &c.
verse 23 In our low 'state who minded us:
for's mercy &c.
verse 24 And us redeemed from o • r foes:
for's mercy &c.
verse 25 Who giveth food unto all flesh:
for's mercy lasts for ay.
verse 26 Vnto the God of heav'n give thanks:
for's mercy is alway.

div.head: Psalme 137.
div.l: THe rivers on of Babilon
there when wee did sit downe:
yea even then wee mourned, when
wee remembred Sion.
verse 2 Our Harps wee did hang it amid,
upon the willow tree.
verse 3 Because there they that us away
led in captivitee,
Requir'd of us a song, & thus
askt mirth: us waste who laid,
sing us among a Sions song,
unto us then they s • id.
verse 4 The lords song sing can wee? being
verse 5 in strangers land▪ Then let
loose her skill my right hand, if I
Ierusalem forget.
verse 6 Let cleave my tongue my pallate on,
if minde thee doe not I:
if chiefe joyes or'e I prize not more
Ierusalem my joy.
verse 7 Remember Lord, Edoms sons word,
unto the ground said they,
it rase, it rase, when as it was
Ierusalem her day.
verse 8 Blest shall hee bee, that payeth thee,
daughter of Babilon,
who must be waste: that which thou hast
rewarded us upon.
verse 9 O happie hee shall surely bee
that taketh up, that eke
thy little ones against the stones
doth into pieces breake.

lg.l: WIthall my heart, I'le prayse thee new:
before the gods I'le sing to thee.
verse 2 Toward thine holy Temple bow,
& praise thy Name for thy mercee,
& thy truth: for thy word thou hye
or'e all thy Name dost magnify.
verse 3 It'h day I cride, thou answredst mee:
with strength thou didst my soule up-beare.
verse 4 Lord, all the earths kings shall praise thee,
the word when of thy mouth they heare.
verse 5 Yea, they shall sing in the Lords wayes,
for great's Iehovahs glorious prayse.
verse 6 Albeit that the Lord be hye,
respect yet hath he to the low:
but as for them that are lofty,
he them doth at a distance know·
verse 7 Though in the midst I walking bee
of trouble thou wilt quicken mee,
Forth shalt thou make thine hand to go
against their wrath that doe me 〈◊〉 ,
thy right hand shall me save also.
verse 8 The Lord will perfect mine estate:
thy mercy Lord, for ever stands:
leave not the works of thine owne hands.

lg.head: Annother of the same.
lg.l: WIthall my heart, I'le thee confess:
thee praise the gods before.
verse 2 The Temple of thine holines
towards it I'le adore:
Also I will confesse thy Name,
for thy truth, & mercy:
because thou over all thy Name
thy word dost magnify.
verse 3 In that same day that I did cry,
thou didst mee answer make:
thou strengthnedst mee with strength, which I
within my soule did tak • .
verse 4 O Lord, when thy mouths words they heare
all earths Kings shall thee praise.
verse 5 And for the Lords great glory, there
they shall sing in his wayes.
verse 6 Albeit that the Lord be high,
yet hee respects the low:
but as for them that are lofty
hee them far off doth know.
verse 7 Though I in midst of trouble go,
thee quickning mee I haue:
thy hand thou wilt cast on my foe,
thy right hand shall mee save.
verse 8 The Lord will perfect it for mee:
thy mercy ever stands,
Lord, doe not those forsake that bee
the works of thine owne hands.

div.head: Psalme 139. To the chief musician, a psalme of David.

lg.l: O LORD, thou hast me searcht & knowne.
Thou knowst my sitting downe,
& mine up-rising: my thought is
to thee afarre off knowne.
verse 3 Thou knowst my paths, & lying downe,
& all my way • s knowst well·
verse 4 For loe, each word that's in my tongue,
Lord, thou canst fully tell.
verse 5 Behinde thou gird'st mee, & before:
& layst on mee thine hand.
verse 6 Such knowledge is too strange, too high,
for mee to u • derstand
verse 7 Where shall I from thy presence go?
or where from thy face flye?
verse 8 If heav'n I climbe, thou there, loe thou,
if downe in hell I lye.
verse 9 If I take mornings wi • gs; & dwell
where u • most sea-co • sts bee.
verse 10 Ev'n there thy hand shall mee conduct▪
& thy right hand hold mee.
verse 11 That veryly the darknes shall
mee cover, if I say:
then shall the night abou • mee be
like to the lightsome day.
verse 12 Yea, darkn • s hideth not from thee,
but as the day shines night:
alike unto • hee both these are,
the darknes & the light.
verse 13 Because that thou poss • ssed hast
my reines: and covered mee
within my mothers wombe thou h • st.
verse 14 My prayse shall be of thee,
Because that I am fashion • d
in fear • ull wondrous wise:
& that thy works are merveilous,
my soule right well descries.
verse 15 From thee my substance was not hid,
when made I was closely:
& when within th'earths lowest par ••
I was wrought curiously.
verse 16 Thine eyes upon my substance yet
imperfected, did look,
& all the me • bers that I have
were written in thy booke,
What dayes they should be fashioned:
none of them yet were come.
verse 17 How pretious are thy thoughts to mee,
o God? how great's their summe?
If I should count them, in number
more then the sands they bee:
& at what time I doe awake,
still I abide with thee.
verse 19 Assuredly thou wilt o God,
those that be wicked slay:
yee that are bloody men, therefore
depart from mee away.
verse 20 Because that they against thee doe
speake wickedly likewise:
thy Name 〈◊〉 doe take up in vaine
who are •• ine enemies.
verse 21 Thy ha • ers • ord, doe I not hate?
& am not I with those
offended grievously that doe
up-rising thee oppose?
verse 22 Them I with perfect ha • red hate:
I count them as my foes.
verse 23 Search mee o God, & know my heart:
try mee, my thoughts disclose:
verse 24 And see if any wicked way
in mee there bee at all:
& mee conduct within the way
that last for ever shall.

div.head:
Palme 140
To the chief musician, a psalme of David,

lg.l: LORD, free mee from the evill man:
from violent man save mee▪
verse 2 Whose hearts thinke mischief: ev • ry day
for war they gathred bee.
verse 3 Their tongues they have made to be sharp
a serpent like unto:
the poyson of the Aspe it is
under their lipps also. Selah.
verse 4 Keepe mee, Lord, from the wickeds hands,
from violent man mee save:
my goings who to overthrow
in thought projected have.
verse 5 The proud have hid a snare for mee,
cords also: they a net
have spred abroad by the way side:
grins for mee they have set. Selah.
verse 6 Vnto Iehovah I did say,
thou art a God to mee:
Lord, heare the voice of my requests,
which are for grace to thee.
verse 7 O God, the Lord, who art the stay
of my salvation:
my head by thee hath covered been
the day of battell on.
verse 8 Those mens desires that wicked are,
Iehovah, doe not grant,
their wicked purpose furher not,
lest they themselves doe vaunt.
verse 9 As for the head of them that mee
doe round about inclose,
o let the molestation
of their lips cover those.
verse 10 Let burning coales upon them fall,
into the fire likewise
• et them be cast, into deep • pits,
that they no more may rise.
verse 11 Let not i'th earth establisht bee
men of an evill tongue:
evill shall hunt to overthrow.
the man of violent wrong.
verse 12 The afflicteds cause, the poore mans right,
I know God will maintaine:
verse 13 Yea, just shall praise thy Name: th'upright
shall 'fore thy face remaine.

div.head: Psalme 141. A psalme of David.
div.l: O GOD, my Lord, on thee I call,
doe thou make hast to mee:
and harken thou unto my voice▪
when I cry unto thee.
verse 2 And let my pray'r directed be
as incense in thy sight:
and the up-lifting of my hands
as sacrifice at night.
verse 3 Iehovah, oh that thou would'st set
a watch my mouth before:
as also of my lips with care
o doe thou keepe the dore.
verse 4 Bow not my heart to evill things;
to doe the wicked deed
with wicked workers▪ & let no •
mee of their dainties feed.
verse 5 Let just-men smite mee, kindenes 'tis;
let him reprove mee eke,
it shall be such a pretious oyle,
my head it shall not breake:
For yet my prayr's ev'n in their woes.
verse 6 W • en their judges are cast
on rocks, then shall they heare my words,
for they are sweet to taste.
verse 7 Like unto one who on the earth
doth cutt & cleave the wood,
ev'n so our bones at the graves mouth
are scattered abroad.
verse 8 But unto thee o God, the Lord
directed are mine eyes:
my soule o leave not destitute,
on thee my hope relyes.
verse 9 O doe thou keepe mee from the snare
which they have layd for mee;
& also from the grins of those
that work iniquitee.
verse 10 Together into their owne nets
o let the wicked fall:
untill such time that I escape
may make from them withall.

div.head: Psalme 142. Maschil of David, a prayer when he was in the cave.
div.l: VNto Iehovah with my voice,
I did unto him cry:
unto Iehovah with my voice
my sute for grace made I.
verse 2 I did poure out before his face
my meditation:
before his face I did declare
the trouble mee upon.
verse 3 O'rewhelm'd in mee when was my spirit,
then thou didst know my way:
I'th way I walkt, a snare for mee
they privily did lay.
verse 4 On my right hand I lookt, & saw,
but no man would mee know,
all refuge faild mee: for my soule
none any care did show.
verse 5 Then to thee Lord, I cryde, & sayd,
my hope thou art alone:
& in the land of living ones
thou art my portion.
verse 6 Because I am brought very low,
attend unto my cry:
from my pursuers save thou mee,
which stronger bee then I.
verse 7 That I thy Name may praise, my soule
from prison oh bring out:
when thou shalt mee reward, the just
shall compasse mee about.

lg.l: LORD, heare my prayr, give eare when I
doe supplicate to thee:
in thy truth, in thy righteousnes;
make answer unto mee.
verse 2 And into judgement enter not
with him that serveth thee;
for in thy sight no man that lives
can justified bee.
verse 3 For th'enemie hath pursude my soule,
my life to'th ground hath throwne:
& made mee dwell i'th dark like them
that dead are long agone.
verse 4 Therefore my spirit is overwhelmd
perplexedly in mee:
my heart also within mee is
made desolate to bee.

verse 5 I call to minde th •
• ayes of old,
I medita on use
on all thy wo ••• : upon the work
of thy hands I doe muse.

verse 6
〈◊〉 I doe unto thee
reach mine out-stretched hands:
so after thee my soule doth thirst
as doe the thristy lands. Selah.
verse 7 Hast, Lord, heare mee, my spirit doth faile,
hide not thy face mee fro:
lest I become like one of them
that downe to pit doe go.
verse 8 Let mee thy mercy heare i'th morne,
for I doe on thee stay,
wherin that I should walk cause mee
• o understand the way:
For unto thee I lift my soule.
verse 9 O Lord deliver mee
from all mine enemies; I doe • lye
to hide my selfe with thee.
verse 10 Because thou art my God, thy will
oh teach thou mee to doe,
thy spirit is good: of uprightnes
lead mee the land into·
verse 11 Iehovah, mee o quicken thou
ev'n for thine owne Names sake;
And for thy righteousnes my soule
from out of trouble take.
verse 12 Doe thou also mine enemies
cut off in thy mercy,
destroy them that afflict my soule:
for thy servant am I.
O Let Iehovah blessed be
who is my rock of might,
who doth instruct my hands to war,
and my fingers to fight.
verse 2 My goodnes, fortresse, my hye towre,
& that doth set mee free:
my shield, my trust, which doth subdue
my people under mee.
verse 3 Ieho • ah, what is man, that thou
knowledge of him dost take?
what is the son of man, that thou
account of him dost make?
verse 4 Man's like to vanity: his dayes
passe like a shade away.
verse 5 Lord, bow the heav'ns, come downe & touch
the mounts & smoake shall they.
verse 6 Lightning cast forth, & scatter them:
thine arrows shoot, them • out,
verse 7 Thine hand o send thou from above,
doe thou redeeme mee out:
And rid mee from the waters great:
from hand of strangers brood:
verse 8 Whose mouth speaks lyes, their right hand is
a right hand of falsehood.
verse 9 O God, new songs I'le sing to thee:
upon the Psaltery,
and on ten stringed instrument
to thee sing praise will I.
verse 10 It's hee that giveth unto Kings
safety victorious:
his servant David he doth save
from sword pernitious.
verse 11 Rid mee from hand of strange children,
whose mouth speakes vanity:
& their right hand a right hand is
of lying filsity:
verse 12 That like as plants which are growne up
in youth may be our sons;
our daughters pallace like may be
pollisht as corner stones:
verse 13 Our garners full, affording store
of every sort of meates;
our cattell bringing thousands forth,
ten thousands in our streets:
verse 14 Strong let our oxen bee to work,
that breaking in none bee
no • going out: that so our streets
may from complaints bee free.
verse 15 O blessed shall the people be
whose state is such as this:
o blessed shall the people be,
whose God Iehovah is.

div.head: Psalme 145. Davids psalme of praise.
div.l: MY God, o King, I'le thee extoll:
& blesse thy Name for aye.
verse 2 For ever will I praise thy Name;
and blesse thee every day.
verse 3 Great is the Lord, most worthy praise:
his greatnes se • rch can none.
verse 4 Age unto age shall pr • ise thy works:
& thy great acts make knowne.
verse 5 I of thy glorious honour will
speake of thy majesty;
& of the operations
by thee done wondrously.
verse 6 Also men of thy mighty works
shall speake which dreadfull are:
also concerning thy greatnes,
it I will forth declare:
verse 7 Thy great goodnesses m • mory
they largely shall express:
and they shall with a shouting voice
sing of thy righteousnes.
verse 8 The Lord is gracious, & hee is
full of compassion:
slow unto anger, & full of
commiseration.
verse 9 The Lord is good to all: or'e all part (2)
his works his mercies bee.
verse 10 All thy works shall praise thee, o Lord:
& thy Saints shall blesse thee,
verse 11 They▪le of thy kingdomes glory speake:
and talk of thy powre hye;
verse 12 To make mens • o • s his great acts know:
his kingdomes majesty.
verse 13 Thy Kingdome is a kingdome aye:
& thy reigne lasts alwayes.
verse 14 The Lord doth hold up all that fall:
and all downe-bow'd ones rayse.
verse 15 All eyes wayt on thee, & their meat
thou dost in season bring.
verse 16 Opnest thy hand, & the desire
fill'st of each living thing.
verse 17 In all his wayes the Lord is just:
& holy in's works all.
verse 18 Hee's neere to all that call on him:
in truth that on him call.
verse 19 Hee satisfy will the desire
of those that doe him feare:
Hee will be safety unto them,
and when they cry he'le heare.
verse 20 The Lord preserves each one of them

tha •
lov • r • of him bee:
but whosoever wicked are
abolish them doth hee.
verse 21 My mouth the prayses of the Lord
by speaking shall express:
also all flesh his holy Name
for evermore shall bless.

div.head: Psalme 146.
div.l: THe Lord praise: praise (my soule) the Lord,
So long as I doe live
I'le praise the Lord; while that I am,
praise to my God I'le give.
verse 3 Trust not in Princes; nor mans son
who can no succour send.
verse 4 His breath goe's forth, to's earth he turnes,
his thoughts that day doe end.
verse 5 Happie is hee that hath the God
of Iacob for his ayd:
whose expectation is upon
Iehovah his God stayd.
verse 6 Which heav'n, earth, sea▪ all i • them made:
truth keeps for evermore:
verse 7 Which for th'oppressed judgement doth,
gives to the hungry store,
verse 8 The Lord doth loose the prisoners.
the Lord ope's eyes of blinde,
the Lord to'th just is kinde.
verse 9 The Lord saves stangers, & relievs
the orphan, & widow:
but hee of them that wicked are
the way doth overthrow.
verse 10 The Lord shall reigne for evermore,
thy God, o Sion, hee
to generations all shall reigne:
o prayse Iehovah yee.

div.head: Psalme 147.
div.l: PRayse yee the Lord, for it
is good praises to sing,
to our God for it's sweet,
praise is a comely thing.
verse 2 Ierusalem
the Lord up-reares,
outcasts gathers
of Isre'll them.
verse 3 The broke in heart he heales:
& up their wounds doth binde.
verse 4 The stars by number tells:
hee calls them all by kinde.
verse 5 Our Lord great is,
& of great might,
yea infinite
his knowledge 'tis.
verse 6 The Lord sets up the low:
wicked to ground doth fling.
verse 7 Sing thanks the Lord unto
on Harp, our Gods praise sing.
verse 8 Who clouds the skyes,
to • arth gives raines:
who on mountaines
makes grasse to rise.
verse 9 Beasts, hee & ravens young
when as they cry feeds then.
verse 10 Ioyes not in horses strong:
nor in the leggs of men.
verse 11 The Lord doth place
his pleasure where
m • n doe him feare,
& hope on's grace.
verse 12 Ierusalem, God praise:
Sion thy God confess:
verse 13 For thy gates barres he stayes▪
in thee thy sons doth bless.
verse 14 Peace maketh hee
in borders thine:
with wheat so fine
hee filleth thee.
verse 15 On earth sends his decree:
swiftly his word doth pass.
verse 16 Gives snow like wool, spreds hee
his hoare frost ashes as.
verse 17 His yee doth cast
like morsels to:
'fore his cold who
can stand stedfast?
verse 18 His word sends, & them thaws:
makes winde blow, water flows.
verse 19 His word, Iacob; his laws,
& judgements Isr'ell shows.
verse 20 Hee hath so done
no nation to,
judgements also
they have not knowne.
Hallelujah,

div.head: Psalme 148. Hallelujah.
div.l: FRom heav'n o praise the Lord:
him praise the heights within.
verse 2 All's Angells praise afford,
all's Armies praise yee him.
verse 3 O give him praise
Sun & Moone bright:
all Stars of light,
o give him praise.
verse 4 Yee heav'ns of heav'ns him praise:
or'e heav'ns yee waters cleare.
verse 5 The Lords Name let them praise:
for hee spake, made they were.
verse 6 Them stablisht hee
for ever & aye:
nor shall away
his made decree.
verse 7 Praise God from th'earth below:
yee dragons & each deepe.
verse 8 Fire & haile, mist & snow:
whirl windes his word which keepe.
verse 9 Mountaines, also
you hills all yee:
each fruitfull tree,
all Cedars too▪
verse 10 Beasts also all cattell:
things creeping, foules that flye.
verse 11 Earths kings, & all people:
princ • s, earths judges hye:
doe all the same.
verse 12 Young men & maids:
old men & babes.
verse 13 Praise the Lords Name,
For his Name's hye only:
his glory o're earth & heav'n.
verse 14 His folks horne he lifts hye
the praise of all's Saints, ev'n
the sons who bee
of Israell,
his neere people,
the Lord praise yee.

div.head: Psalme 149.
div.l: PRaise yee the Lord: unto the Lord
doe yee sing a new song:
& in the congregation
his praise the Saints among.
verse 2 Let Israell now joyfull bee
in him who him hath made:
children of Sion in their King
o let them be full glad.
verse 3 O let them with melodious flute
his Name give praise unto:
let them sing praises unto him
with Timbrell, Harp also.
verse 4 Because Iehovah in his folk
doth pleasure greatly take:
the meek hee with salvation
ev'n beautifull will make.
verse 5 Let them the gracious Saints that be
most gloriously rejoyce:
& as they lye upon their beds
lift up their singing voyce.
verse 6 Let their mouths have Gods praise: their hand
a two edg'd sword also:
verse 7 On • eathen vengeance, on the folk
punishment for to do:
verse 8 Their kings with chaines, with yron bolts
also their peers to binde:
verse 9 To doe on them the judgement writ:
all's Saints this honour finde·
Hallelujah.

div.head: Psalme 150.
div.l: PRaise yee the Lord. praise God
in's place of holines:
o praise him in the firmament
〈◊〉 his great mightines.
verse 2 O praise him for his acts
that be magnificent:
& praise yee him according to
his greatnes excellent.
verse 3 With Trumpet praise yee him
that gives a sound so hye:
& doe yee praise him with the Harp,
& sounding Psalterye.
verse 4 With Tim • rell & with Flute
praise unto him give yee:
wi • h Organs, & string'd instruments
prais'd by you let him bee.
verse 5 Vpon the loude Cymballs
unto him give yee praise:
upon the Cim • alls praise yee him
which hye their sound doe raise.
verse 6 Let every thing to which
the Lord doth breath afford
the praises of the Lord set forth:
o doe yee praise the Lord.

div.head: An admonition to the Reader.
div.p: THe verses of these psalmes may be red • ced to six kindes, the first wherof may be 〈…〉 neere fourty common tunes; as they 〈…〉 , out of our chief musicians, by Tho. Ravenscroft.

The second kinde may be sung in three tunes as Ps▪
• 5.50. & • 7. in our english psalm books. The third. may be sung indifferently, as ps. the 51.100. & ten cōmandements, in our english psalme books. which three tunes afor • said, comprehend almost all this whole book of psalmes 〈◊〉
•• ing tunes most familiar to us.
The fourth. as ps. 148. of which there are but about five.
The fift. as ps. 112. or the Pater noster, of which there are but two. viz. 85. & 138.
The sixt. as ps. 113. of which but one, viz. 115.

div.head: Faults escaped in printing.
div.p: The rest, which have escaped through oversight, you may amend, as you finde them obvious.
